column2: Breynolds, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I started Chantix February of 2011 and completed a 3 months trail of the drugs. It definitely help me slow down/stop smoking for a few months, but there are many reasons why I discontinued my use of the drug. First I would like to point out that the urges are somewhat repressed once you stop taking the drug, but they are still there, it's the change of habit that helps you continue to be smoke free. As for the side effects, all taking into consideration there is no history of anger, depression, etc before taking Chantix. I realized after 2-3 weeks I became on edge, intense dreams 1-2 times a week, and over thought everything. Never experience this before in my life, but continued taking the drug. Week 3, I had completely quite smoking beside 1-2 a week while in a bar setting. After taking the drug for 3 months, I decided to stop taking the drug, due to the side effects that were occurring, and simply not being worth it. I had always been the happy go lucky, laid back, care free person, but quickly realized that had all changed. I always seemed on edge, ready to snap at a moments notice, emotions suddenly going from one extreme to another for no reason, not be able to depicted certain dreams from reality, and gaining a since of depression and anxiety. (Again no history prior to taking Chantix) During this time frame I spoke with my doctor about the changes and he stated all of these are common side effects and I should not be worried and they effects should go away once I stop taking the drug. I took his word, and repressed a lot of what I noticed had changed. Now that it has been over a year since I have stopped taking Chantix, I am still dealing with most of the side effects. Talking with my doctor again, the drug can alter some brain receptors and cause long term effects. The effects are not a severe as they were, but the effects of this drug are long lasting. I thought I would post this for others to see, and realize the true side effect.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I am very impressed with Chantix and would recommend it to anyone who wants to quit and has stuggled with other methods.

I hope switching to .5 twice a day will not increase side effects, but I am determined to get through this. I want to quit smoking sooo badly. Thanks for reading.

I will monitor that progress.

column2: netnotes, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Chantix is the greatest medication ever! I smoked for 40 years before using Chantix...Now I'm smoke free! The first time using Chantix I allowed myself only 3 months using the medication. While my smoking was curbed the fact was I still smoked. So I tried again taking it for 6 months. I would recommend this product to anyone who wants to stop smoking!

column2: subby19, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This is my second go with Chantix. Althogh it did work for me the first time, I assumed I was ready to stop taking the drug after the first month. I relapsed a month later. This time I plan on taking the medication the full three months. I have not smoked in two days and honestly I have little or no cravings. The days prior to stopping all together I was only smoking three to four a day, I feel I smoked those just to smoke not due to cravings. I have experienced a few side effects headaches, nausea, and a few dreams(not nightmares.) I would take all the side effects over and over again if it meant not smoking. Chantix is a life saver I know with the help of chantix I will stop smoking and that is a good feeling!!!!

column2: courage to quit, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: After 15 years of smoking with asthma I decided it was time to quit. I talked my mother into trying Chantix with me; she had been smoking for 30 years.  We set our quit date and started the medication. First thing I noticed was severe nausea if I didn't drink copious amounts of water when taking it. Mom didn't have that problem; hers was horrible gas. We both had vivid dreams but they weren't nighmarish.  We were both able to quit on our quit date and had very little urge to smoke; I think we both slipped one or two times. We stopped taking Chantix at month #2 because we felt like we didn't need it. 8 months later, we both are back smoking (and hiding from the world) So, back on Chantix we went. Side effects were about the same with me; I decided it was the amount of liquid you drink when taking, not the amount of food in your stomach that makes a difference in the nausea. The dreams did not get bad this time either. Mom had the same effects; none of which were bothersome enough to stop the medicine.  This was June 2010 and I haven't had a cigarette since. Mom quit a couple months later for good. I have never felt better. I still have an occasional craving, but it doesn't last long and I'm distracted before it even really sets in. People need to realize that while their bodies are detoxifying, the MAY NOT FEEL GOOD. Look up withdrawal symptoms and you will see that some things you are experiencing are probably NOT caused by the medicine. Its your body healing itself and getting out all those impurities!! Also, mom and I both have depressive tendencies, and take mild medication for it; neither of us had any adverse mental side effects while on Chantix. Hopefully, your insurance will help with the cost (mine didn't the first go around) but even if they don't; call around to the pharmacies, they all have competitive pricing; you can get it for around $ 100; MUCH less than a cigarette habit for a month. Stop taking when you can confidently NOT SMOKE and not before.

I HAD MINOR CRAVINGS, BUT IT WAS EASY TO TALK MYSELF OUT OF IT. I HAD SMOKED FOR OVER 30 YEARS 1 1/2 PACK A DAY. I'VE NOW BEEN SMOKE FREE FOR 2 YEARS. LOVE YOU CHANTIX!!!!

column2: Amy, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This drug has been a life saver, I just don't want them anymore. The weird dreams are less frequent, my mood has actually improved and so has my attention span (I have severe ADD). column2: Trav, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am 46 year-old male and smoked for over 30 years.  I took the Chantix as prescribed for 2 weeks and it stopped the urge to smoke.  But, the side-effects I have are the dreams-some are nightmares that I remember clearly and the worst side effect is a constant massive headache.  I am stopping Chantix after 2 weeks.  It made me feel horrible.  I am a stable person and I would recommend this to others but only if you are not depressed or mentally ill. I only wander what the irreversible effects to my brain are? The nausea and gas were things I could tolerate, but the headache that won't go away and the more than vivid dreams are not for me.  I did quit smoking and I will never smoke again.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver)
column9: After 10 days on Chantix I ceased to even consider smoking no matter how stressful a day I was having. I took Chantix for aproximately 6 weeks. I stopped taking it when I realized I had forgotten three doses and had no desire to smoke.I experiernced mild nausea which was relieved by taking the drug with food. Strange dreams occurred occasionally the first three weeks.I smoked for 18 years and tried several times to stop. Cold turkey was always a failure. I did try nicotine patches and Wellbutrin but the cravings for a cigarette never ceased until I used Chantix. My opinion is this medication saved my life.

column2: Anners, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I started Chantix a little over a week ago.  I felt like I didn't need a cigarette after only a few days!  It was amazing.  I did keep smoking, but only occasionally until my quit day.  It's been a few days now and I still don't feel the urge to smoke!  It has been tough because smoking is such a part of my routine, but I'm optimistic that'll change.  As far as side effects, my dreams have been normal, no mood swings or depression.  However, I have had some terrible nausea.  I highly, highly recommend eating something substantial before you take a pill.  The nausea is still present for me, but not so bad that I hover over the toilet.  If this is the worst I can expect, I'll be fine.  To be honest, the side effects scared me so much that I put off trying Chantix for months.  Give it a try.  If it bothers you, stop.  But at least give it a chance.

column2: WickedWanda, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Chantix is the ONLY smoking cessation treatment that has worked for me. This is my second attempt, the first being in 2008. I have been smoke free for two months now and hope this time I can do it for good. Side effects I have experienced are nausea, insomnia, constipation, water retention, weight gain. I will discontinue taking the pills today as I no longer feel I need to take another month supply and really want to get back to normal.

column2: Koby Taylor, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: MY wife and i used Chantix to stop smoking.We took it for 2 weeks, then stopped. The pills do take away the desire to smoke. But stopping was still difficult,but we did it with Chantix help. we have been smoke free for 2 months almost. I smoked for 30 years, never thought i would be able to stop. One side effect for me and wife was constipation, we had to get prescription to deal with that, but well worth the extra meds to stop. One key thing to remember, when stopping smoking, the medicine cannot do it all, you HAVE TO WANT TO STOP first.

column9: Chantix killed my urge to smoke in a few days. I continued to smoke for 2 weeks then quit. Haven,t started again for 5 years after a 40 year habit. Only side effect was tremendous intestinal gas the last week of taking Chantix.

column2: Happy Camper, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Hello again, I just thought I would come back and update my results with this drug. I am currently on day 7 and it's almost lunch. I haven't touched a cigarette this morning and I have not wanted to at all. I did smoke a few yesterday, maybe 5 total, but I only smoked half of them and then had to put them out. I still don't taste a difference, but I have noticed that the smell of them really bothers me. I also can't stand the smell of my clothes that I have worn while smoking. I mentioned it in my previous post, but there is still absolutely no change in my mood or behavior. If anything, it has improved because I am quitting smoking without the terrible withdrawals that I usually have trying to quit cold turkey. This drug has made me not want to smoke, so I don't crave them, I don't get mean because I "can't" have them, instead I just don't WANT them. My husband is also using Chantix to quit smoking and I believe he smokes more than I do still. He works in an environment where he is able to smoke whenever he wants to, but I am not sure how many he actually smokes a day. Overall, I am very pleased with my results so far.

column2: Happy Camper, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Hi. I'm 26 years old. I have been taking this medicine for 3 days. I have not had any side effects yet after taking this rx. Maybe some of the dreams, but I have always had nightmares. My husband and I are quitting together. We have 3 young children and are ready to stop smoking. I have read a lot of the comments on here and some of them don't make sense to me. You should know the side effects before taking any medicine. I don't know why some are saying they didn't know that this could worsen depression. How did you even find out about this medication? The commercial, right? Have you heard the long list of side effects throughout the entire commercial? MAY INCREASE DEPRESSION AND THOUGHTS OF SUICIDE. I really do not understand. Some people blame the doctors for not checking them out before prescribing it. That is absurd. I went to a nurse practitioner and she ran blood tests and asked plenty of questions before she would prescribe it. The same with my husband. But as far as my husband and I are concerned, we have definitely cut back on smoking. I believe tomorrow will be my quit date. I have had 2 cigs today and have not wanted to finish either one. I put it out before I smoked half of it. It doesn't taste bad, I just don't want it. I'm very sorry to those of you who have experienced the negative side effects. If you are on this site because you are thinking of starting it, please understand prior to taking it that it may negatively affect you. I still will recommend this medication to anyone who is interested, as my friend recommended it to me.

column2: faemich, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: On the PLUS side: Chantix works! By day 8 (February 9, 2012) I was smoke free. On the NEGATIVE side, the side effects are so scary I've modified my dosage and will quit taking Chantix in about a week.I take Chantix just after eating yogurt. I've never had the nausea. However, my appetite increased and I was gaining (on average) two pounds a week.Hot flashes, feeling light headed, muscle aches, insomnia, lack of energy are all reasons I'm weaning myself off the drug. What scared me the most was what my daughter-in-law called "the homicidal day." That was the day I lost my temper and went into a rage. Fortunately the only person I hurt was myself. Started lowering the dosage the next day. Here's MY schedule to wean myself off of Chantix if anyone is interested. Remember, this is MY schedule and you may need to modify it for your own needs:If you're taking two pills a day, lower that to ONE pill per day (take the pill in the morning with food if possible). Take ONE pill per day for ONE week. Cut the pills in half and take one HALF pill per day for ONE week. Cut the pills into QUARTERS and take one QUARTER pill for a week. The take one QUARTER pill EVERY OTHER day. Then every three days. See if you can go four days without a pill. From what those in my support group say, you should be able to quit Chantix altogether by then.Chantix is extremely addictive. If you just quit cold turkey you could have withdrawal. Please be careful and talk to your doctor BEFORE you run out of Chantix!

column2: Daddy mike , 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Wellive been on the chantix for 19 days, I have not smoked in 11 days, I stopped the chantix yesterday! Just felt like I didn't need it any more, I still sometimes want a cig just for the simple fact but I just say no, but still only side effects I had were the dreams, they were all good dreams! But I hope the cravings don't get stronger cause it wouldn't be hard to go get a pack of Marlboro:-) but I'm gonna stay strong....it is what it is

column2: VIPeezy, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I took Chantix the second time around anticipating I would be a moody person and go through the previous side effects, but more importantly I created my own plan, which may or may not work for you but it was PERFECT for me. I knew that 1-1.5 months in was when I started getting the worse side effects. The first week of using Chantix is the most cruical part in this whole process. You set that date - and the first 7 days go by and you get ready and ready and ready and ready and BOOM by the end of the 7th day you (or I should be saying I ) was so excited for day 8 to be cigarette free! Cigs started tasting so bad by the end of that first week, it completely removed my desire for a  cigarette . The mental obligation I had to smoke a cigarette dissapeared. I changed my environment because I hate being around cigarettes. I can handle it now, but am I sill dreaming? I dont even remember my last but what I do remember is chain smoking 4 ciggerrets on a 20 minute ride to work every morning! I can only Imagine how bad I always smelled! This second chance I gave  Chantix was completely different then the first. I took Chantix as directed for the first couple weeks, took advice off the website, recieved there afternoon call every day at 5pm to check in and after a full week without any ciggarettes I started my wend off plan. After the first week of smoking + chantix, your chantix mg dose increases. After my second week of chantix's normal dose 2mg a day, I cut back .5 mg - therefore 1.5 a day, the following week 1mg, the following week .5mg a day  until nothing. The week after that it was to such an advantage that the desire had  disappeared. It was amazing I avoided the severe side affects and overall reached my goal.            I am so grateful for Chantix, honestly so far I have saved  over 1200$ from not smoking, and I have a long way to go. If it weren't for Chantix I still would be eating tastless food, wasting presious money, and most importlantly killing myself

column2: hapE2bme, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I took chantix 12 days before I stopped smoking only because I wanted to finish off my carton. Had nausia with the morning pill, then I began eating 2 pieces of toast & half glass of milk & waited 20 minutes before taking it & I never had it again. Have had some dreams. I'm on day 36 without smoking & only taking pill once a day.  I admit that I've used an e-cig (0 nicotine) occasionly that has really helped alot. I keep it put away so I don't see it (out of sight, out of mind) & may use it a couple times a day now. If that's the worst thing I do then so be it. It's cheaper & better for me than regular cigs!  So I say if you can live with some side effects for three months to be smoke-free for life, then by all means it's worth it!

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: thank you chantix.im a former smoker of 26 years.i have been smoke free for 3 years now!i did have some side effects like vivid dreams,insomnia,and a lil depression but it was all worth it to be smoke free,and i dont miss smoking at all,even when i drink.i never thought i could shake the habit,and have tryed to quit before over and over again.chantix was the only thing to help me stop.i took the pills for 3 months which is a little long compared to most people but i guess i needed that because i was a long time smoker.everone is different so if you need to keep getting refills then so be it.whatever works for you.good luck people in your success to stop smoking.whats it worth to you?some side effects or never smoking again?

column2: carolynviola, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: The first week on Chantix I took 1/2 a pill in the morning and 1/2 a pill at night.  No real ill effects, so I took the medication as perscribed the second week.  As my desire to smoke ceased, I cut way back on the cigarettes and by the end of the third week I stopped smoking.  I had read all the warnings about this drug, so I decided to taper off of the pills in the 4th week and I had no side effects whatsoever.I am a stress patient with Graves disease and high blood pressure.  My adjustment to thyroid medication was traumatic for a full year because of my sensitiviy to very slight adjustments to my chemical imbalance.  Having no adverse effects was very surprising to me, considering all the press about this drug.  From my experience, I seriously considered that the warnings were more suggestive to the patients that tried to quit smoking with Chantix.  I believe I had more adverse mental experience when I tried to quit smoking years ago with the nicotine gum.I believe in cold-turkey with most things, but that didn't work with the smoking.  I am also a recovering alcoholic with 34 years of sobriety thru AA, so I am totally aware of the cold-turkey approach.Chantix helped me reduce the need to smoke.  After quitting for a day or two is when the concept of knowing that I was only 1 smoke away from 1.5 packs a day again.I've been smoke-free for 5 years.

column2: happydog, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This is slightly effective but essentially it is poison. Known and personally experienced side effects are; blisters in the mouth, rash on the body, constant state of ague and exhaustion coupled with waking up every hour and therefore being unable to get a decent nights sleep, change in taste buds responses, sleeplessness, difficulty breathing and swallowing, blistering skin, numbness in the arms and legs, light-headedness, achy muscles and more. This is TOXIC!Did it help me quit smoking? Yes. It helped stifle the craving. But who wants to smoke when you feel like crap due to the side effects of the drug? In fact, who wants to do anything? The manufacturer (Pfizer) has been instructed by the FDA to change the maximum amount of time you take it to 35 days...FROM THEIR RECOMMENDED UP TO 12 WEEKS!!The day after I quit taking it,I was able to breathe and swallow more easily. After 2 days of not taking it my rash began to go away and the aches in my upper torso began to ease. It has now been 3 days and I feel 1000% better than I have for the past 2 weeks. I DID quit smoking. I also HAD to quit, after having experienced throat and neck cancer surgery and treatments from July through September. If I had known how this drug would have made my body react I would not only have completely avoided it, but I know I would have recovered more quickly from the reactions I experienced due to my chemo and radiation treatments.My advice? THROW OUT YOUR CHANTIX and try the patch, hypnosis, nicotine gum...anything you can!Pfizer has been challenged many times over this drug and lawsuits have been filed.Please beware...and good luck quitting...some other way please!

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: This is probably one of the most dangerous drugs on the market.  It may help a patient to stop smoking but the risk to one's mental health is not worth the price.  I had the most severe reaction to this drug and I know that I am not the only one or they wouldn't list all the possible side effects on the commercials.  Besides the constant nausea and horrible nightmares, this drug put me into the deepest depression, and I have never been depressed.  It completely destroyed my mental health and almost killed me.  It did help me quit smoking but not because it worked as it promised, I just was so motivated to quit on my own because of the horrific side effects because I knew I could never risk taking this poison again.The FDA should be investigated for allowing Pfizer to release this drug to the public.I'm lucky that I am alive today to write this review.

column2: lifeisgood45, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I quit on 10/11/11. I took Chantix 30 days and quit taking because I feared negative side effects.  I only had weird dreams and lack of interest in anything except going to work and coming home while I took Chantix, so I figured it was a small price to pay to be able to finally quit.  I wasn't prepared for what happened AFTER I quit taking it.  I have been quit for 58 days now and have no joy in life, am depressed, cry for no reason, get mad and irate over little insignificant things.  My husband has been so patient, but he finally said, "you're always in a bad mood".  I feel like I have no control at all over my mood and depression. I manage to function normally at work weirdly enough, but after that I just loose it.  I have never taken any drugs besides prescribed thyroid meds.  I have never had psych issues.  I still am not smoking but it's a miracle.  The disappointment I feel daily makes me want to go back to my old self including smoking if that's what it take to feel normal again. Of course, that will be a last resort.  I am praying daily for God to get me thru this and have faith it will end eventually.  I plan to have a talk with my Dr. at my next appt. in about 2 weeks about these issues.  Good luck to all who are trying to quit and congrats to those who have.  If you haven't used this drug yet, I would recommend you try everything else first.

column9: I suffered all of these and as a result may have just lost my job:     nausea (may persist for several months);stomach pain, indigestion, vomiting, constipation, gas; weakness, tired feeling; increased appetite; unpleasant taste in your mouth; headache; or sleep problems (insomnia) or unusual dreams.difficulty breathing; mood or behavior changes, feel agitated, hostile, depressed, or have thoughts about suicide or hurting yourself.

column2: Mike, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Im in the army this is my 2nd time using chantix the 1st my worst side effects were the terrible stomach pains so i got off the meds as soon as i lost the urge to smoke and quit successfully for about 2 months but a combination of Army life, binge drinking and some personal issues got me smoking again. this time is totally different pertaining to dreams. i am having the craziest VIVID dreams i have ever had... and thats saying something. i saw some crazy and traumatic things over seas and had experience with nightmares over there and for a period when i got back but i wouldn't usually remember them as much as i would wake up feeling like i gotta get my gun and it was "game on" mode all over again. but now, a week on Chantix, the last few nights have been pretty crazy to say the least. my dreams have included themes of nuclear war/holocaust, devastating floods, dead bodies especially children, murder, helping friends commit and cover up murder, intense fights (both physical and verbal) with family members & friends i havnt talked to in years. and heres the weirdest thing... making ppl up, ill have dreams about ppl iv never seen before but in my dream they are my gf/best friend/family and i have real feelings for them ill wake up scared for them or mad at them & its takes a few mins to realize that person doesnt exists.. i can remember every detail of every dream which i can rarely do naturally. i will say i DO feel rested and i can get a full nights sleep and sleep in when i want but iv seen death and destruction 1st hand and i dont like seeing it every night especially how real they feel while im in them theres no differentiation between the real world and these nightmares. ill keep taking it cuz i really do want to quit. they do stop the craving and make smoking unenjoyable. i just dont like feeling confused, scared, guilty, angry and traumatized every time i wake up. i wish it would make good dreams

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: After smoking for 30 years I have been smoke free for 2 months. I am on my last month of Chantix and hope the urges aren't too strong when I finish my last pack. Overall I am very pleased, it definately took the physical cravings away.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I smoked the 1st month I took Chantix and was amazed at the diminished desire to smoke.  I read the side effect warnings but felt good and thought Chantix was a miracle. I quit without a problem the 2nd month.  The dreams were wild beyond belief, but not grim or too scary and I figured a small price to pay to be rid of a 30 year addiction.  I prayed daily for help also. I stopped taking Chantix after 4.5 months.  The depression crept up on me bad!  You don't realize how much of your life gets infiltrated by the effects of the drug.  It has been one week and I am still aware of being down.  I never had suicidal thoughts, but have been unmotivated and feeling some things are too hopeless to change.  I don't regret taking the Chantix and thank God for the help in quitting, but be aware that the depression is more than a possible side effect!

column2: meo, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver)
column9: Wasn't pleasent...

column2: wanttohelp, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been smoking for 6 years (late starter) and today is day 8 on Chantix, and I was scared of this being my quit date but so far it has been smooth. My side effects are gas - tons of gas! A little constipation, and fatigue. I have had a few of the vivid dreams but I consider that the best side effect! The weirdest thing for me is I also haven't had a drink since I started - I used to love wine almost every day and the idea of it sounds gross to me. I'll post further updates after I finish the 30 days, but so far, the benefits far outweigh being a nasty, smelly smoker.

column2: tom_k1948, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: i think this med has caused erectile dysfunction

column2: TamaraViney, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I got very depressed and aggrevated on this drug only after the first few days.  I stopped it immediatly after feeling like this.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Has helped diminsih my desire to smoke.  I have some nausea, but nothing serious.I have had incredibly strong food urges!

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: chantix does work but side effects can be rough.  It has caused constipation(11 days) with no releif from laxatives.  Mood swings were extremely high.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am in week 3 of taking Chantix. The product definitely decreases my urge to smoke, but I am experiencing terrible side effects. I have severe gastrointestinal problems, I want to sleep all the time, my appetite has increased, and my "taste" and "temperature gauge" are both off. I also am having vivid dreams and experiencing wakefulness during the night. Today I started to wean myself off in the hope that I can stop smoking on my own without taking this drug.

column2: Gnico09, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Please use extreme caution while taking this medication! After a pack a day for 10 years, I figured id try this drug since patches/gum didn't help. The side effects severely outweigh the benefits. I had a total mental breakdown with this drug with attempted suicide. Gastrointestinal problems were rather severe and disrupted my daily function. And the agitation and lack of sleep due to extreme lucid dreams/nightmares have caused severe strain on my relationships with friends and family (aiding in the breakdown). I have completely stopped this nightmare of a drug and have had to start taking hearty doses of Valium to get my anxiety, panic, and depression under check. If I knew then what I know now about this drug I would have never ever started it in the first place. Keep in mind that all of these side effects happend all within 3 weeks of taking this drug! Please please try alternative ways of quitting smoking instead of taking this drug. It is not worth the side effects what so ever.

column2: ChelsieSLC, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month
column9: I have been a 'half a pack smoker' for almost 8 years now. Today is day 7 of the pills & my first day smoke free! The pill has worked wonders. Each day the urge got smaller and smaller, and today was the day I didn't buy a pack. I haven't really even thought about it! Also, i haven't had a single side effect. I will complete my month of pills, but at this point, I absolutely recommend this to everyone! I'm so excited about the money I will save, and years i will add back onto my life!

column2: jd4jesus7, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I am 42 and been smoking for 37 years. I tryed everyting on the market to stop for the last 11 years. It was easier to stop drugs and drinking. I am now free from smoking and even though the habit might enter my minde I do not crave at all. I havent had a smoke in 8+ week and wy wifem is proud that I finaly dont smoke any more   Thank you for making somthing that works without nicatine or feeding the habit of hand to mouth.

column2: cele_graves, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: this medication gives me really bad headaches.  i get them so bad that i get nausiated and dizzy.

column2: QFMO28, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I took Chantix for only 4 weeks and was able to quit smoking.  It should be noted that I have adopted a workout program that utilizes INSANSE cardio!  I was playing ice hockey while still smoking, but that was the only exercise I had before I quit smoking.

column2: Babs, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had smoked for 53 years and now have COPD.  In 2008 I took the drug for 3 months and have been smoke free for over 3 years now.  I had no bad side effects with the drug, although I had vivid technicolor dreams.  Since I took this drug it is like I have never smoked. I can sit next to someone who smokes and I still don't crave a cigarette.  I have highly recommended this drug to my friends.  My Dr. suggested that since I had smoked for so many years to smoke for 3 weeks rather than the 1 week suggested with the directions and I think that is one of the reasons I had no bad side effects.

column2: janice, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: I am 65 yrs.old. I smoked 3 packs a day and planned to retire at age 62, but didn't want to smoke aftr retirement. A friend told me about Chantix , so I went to my dr.,got the pills and on March 2,2007, took the 1st. pill. There were no side effects for me, and haven't smoked since. I would and have recommended Chantix to several friends.It worked for them too. Chantix is the best thing I ever did for myself. It's a great product!!!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I smoked for 14 years and tried quitting several times. Nothing stuck until I took Chantix. The side affects were terrible - joint and muscle pain that I'm STILL feeling, but it did what it's supposed to do ; I quit smoking. Not only did I quit smoking, but I don't even miss it. Both of my parents smoke, and I don't mind being around it.  I like the smell of cigarettes better now than when I smoked... but I still don't want one.It's weird, but it's great. I'm really proud of myself, and despite the side affects I'd recommend it to anyone who wants to quit.A friend of mine took it to quit and said, "I'll never smoke again, so I never have to take Chantix again."  It's a pretty good analogy.

column2: nowakmac, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Chantix has helped me quit two times, but my own willpower didn't stop me from starting again. My husband is a smoker, and having cigarettes around the house was just too tempting for me.  I'm determined to do it this time!  I'm on day 9 and my smoking has cut way back.  My husband has decided to join me and he picks up his prescription today!  Yeah!  The one thing I noticed this time, is the smell of smoke.  After taking my bath the other night, I put on the pajamas I was wearing the night before.  I had to go change because I could smell the smoke in my pajamas.  Last night we went to dinner.  As soon as I walked in the house, I could smell the stench of smoke.  My house smelled like an ashtray!  I hope it's just a side effect of Chantix and my house doesn't really smell that bad to people who come to visit!!  Wish me luck people.

column2: stephweathers76, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I took this medicine for 1 month 1 year ago this month to quit smoking.  I had been smoking since the age of 13 and I am now 35.  I had very few side effects and this medicine works.  I was extremely moody during the month that I took this medicine to quit smoking but again, it works if you take it as prescribed.  My BF also took this medicine to quit 3 years ago and it worked for him and he is still smoke free today.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Okay, week two, on day 12, and down to about a cigarette and a half a day, and even that is not satisfying anymore. However, the last few days I have been experiencing hallucinations, and really questioning whether some of the things that I have been experiencing are real or not. The nausea and headaches have not subsided, and are getting worse actually. The medication does work, but it's just not for me because of the side effects, and I don't want to continue with it because of what else I may experience. I am going to try the patch and lozenges to finish out my quest in quitting smoking, but so far I am doing quite well.

column2: WickettWI, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been taking this medication for about a week (hence the low star ratings so far) now and I have noticed that the taste of ciagrettes and the cigarette itself is no longer that "satisying" to me anymore. I can already feel the medication working. I do also feel nauseated after smoking. However,I myself, have had some side effects. I have had trouble sleeping, and staying asleep, nausea, headaches, dry mouth, sore throat,dizziness and a little irritability, but I think the mood changes have to do with less nicotine as I have smoked less, and ones body needs to adjust to something being taken aeway that it has had for many years, and I have vivid dreams, not bad ones, but vivid, and some are actually kind of cool. This drug has really worked for a lot of people, so don't let the reviews scare you off. Everyone reacts to medication differently, and I personally do not want to stop taking this med because of what other people say or experience as I know it will work for me. Hopefully some of the side effects will subside, if not I can deal, because quitting smoking is worth more to me and I can deal with an upset stomach and losing a few hours of sleep!

column2: Rips241, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I decided to give it a try with no prep at all. My mind WASN'T right and all that. I just hoped it worked. A week into it I actually began to miss cigarette breaks. Just forgot to have a smoke. I didn't set a quit date like they say you should. I instead set a slow down to quit date. I would smoke just a few puffs and butt the cigarette for later. The few puffs were enough to satisfy me each time I wanted a cigarette. Before long I was taking only a couple cigarettes to work for the day. Eventually stopping all together. Stopped in my mid 3rd week. No kidding it works to lessen the craving. If you keep busy you won't miss cigarettes. Today, 45 days without a cigarette, I still have the occasional craving. Probably always will but there's no way I'm going back to smoking now. One final tip.. It can make you feel sick. 15 or 20 minutes after taking it you sometimes feel a little sick. It passes quickly though. Sometimes after having a cigarette break you'll feel a little sick. This passes also. Its all worth it and easier than you might think.... Try it.

column2: stoeast, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Seem to be having kidney pain during 1mg2x daily. Stopped for one day, pain subsided, restarted, pain returned. Don't see anything of this in side effects, anyone else have similar issues?

column2: WWL23, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: i took this med. for about two weeks, not to quit smoking but to quit chewing. only side effect i had was i slight pain in my side, least im done with nicotine.

column2: K-MacK, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Like the majority of users, I wanted to stop smoking.  The first few days, there was some nausea but it went away after the fifth day on the medication.  I didn't have any other problems with the medication.  I STOPPED SMOKING.After completing the treatment, I was smoke-free for almost six months.  Then a "natural and organic" cigarette given me by a friend undid everything.  I started smoking again.Now, I'm back on Chantix.  I will stop smoking again.  This time I will know that I cannot even smoke one cigarette without re-starting the addiction.  I will have to stay a non-smoker for life.  There is no give-and-take; cessation has to be total and unbroken.  I am just glad Chantix makes it so discomfort-free for me.  I also realize that no medicine is safe for everyone, but Chantix works safely for me.  Honestly, that's what I care about, and I'm honestly sad for those who were unable to use this medication.  For those who can use it, it works wonderfully.

column2: Gypsy , 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Three times is a charm.  My first time was short because I was not ready to quit smoking.  I tested the effectiveness of Chantix by having one cigarette and started smoking again.  The second time, I tested the product again and started smoking again.  This is my third time and I am ready now. I noticed that the product acts more swiftly every time I started using it again.  I have taken the product as prescribed and it really does help to eliminate the cravings.  I remind myself that "I don't do that anymore" when I want to have a cigarette because I am on the phone or in the car.  I remind myself that I have a new lifestyle now, so I think of something else and easily forget that I want the cigarette. My friends and family are a great support system for me and I am working on the weight I am gaining from quitting.  I follow a 1,200 calorie a day eating program and exercise to detox my system of nicotine.  I support Chantix and hope not to smoke ever again, but if I do, I will return to Chantix as my tool.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I'm in my second go-round of taking this.  The first time I took it was for 3.5 months the way I was supposed to take it.  The only side effect was severe nausea and sleepiness (I missed work a few times having to "sleep it off").  It worked great for the cravings.  I moved and ended up not keeping up with the pills (every once in a while I would remember to take them), but iI started smoking again a few a day. When I started back in my regular pack-a-day habit  I started back on them regularly but only once a day.  This time around I have been tired, anxious (moreso than usual), angry angry angry (almost hatred towards fiance and family).  My fiance has asked me to give up the Chantix and I'm hoping this will fix it because I do not want to be an unhappy angry person! I will try to quit on my own.

column2: Carol, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Chantix swiftly and definitely eliminates the desire to smoke--the few urges for a cigarette one might feel are easily brushed aside. HOWEVER, after three weeks, I had to get off the stuff. Even on a doctor-approved reduced dosage (1/2 mg., 3x day), I suffered from continual low-level nausea and fluctuated between either diarrhea or constipation. I was bloated and extremely gassy. I became unable to sleep through the night; I'd wake up several times each night, drenched in sweat and unable to fall back to sleep for at least an hour; sometimes I couldn't fall asleep again at all. Worst of all--I developed an attitude of crabbiness and impatience that quickly mushroomed into out-and-out senseless hostility toward everyone and everything. In my roles as a mom and at work, I deal with all kinds of situations and people, and my suddenly "bad attitude" was really crippling my ability to do my jobs. In other words, I felt sick all the time, was sleep deprived, and was becoming a real bitch on wheels. I'm happy for people for whom Chantix is a good solution, but I'm not one of them. My advice: prescribers should inform themselves on the possible side effects of this drug and closely monitor their patients. My side effects were bad--if I hadn't decided to quit Chantix on my own, and the hostility had escalated any further, really bad things might have happened. I think I was skating on the edge of psychosis.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month
column9: I'm on day 10 and the only side effects have been a sore throat/heartburn during the night.  I've started taking an antiacid and it seems to help.  Forgot last night and paid for it.  Other than that I'm very satisfied with Chantax.  I'm very happy as I've been a smoker for about 30 years.  I hated the cost of cigarettes, the smell on my clothes, etc.  I have had quite vivid dreams but I've always had strong dreams.  Good luck to us all and I hope anyone who tries to quits succeeds!!

column2: snmyr, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Chantix saved my Life. I had no side effects. I took it for 3 months and have been free of smoking for 3 years. It dose work.

column2: Free@58, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: First let me say that Chantix DOES work.  If you want to quit and you take the medicine as prescribed, it will be a significant factor in helping you quit.  I quit using Chantix at the 2 month mark, earlier than recommended, because I could not deal with the cumulative side effects.  At the time I quit taking it, I was totally smoke-free for 6 weeks. I am still smoke free.  The side effects I experienced included:  (1) vivid dreams (but not what i would consider nightmares) that did impact my quality of sleep; (2) significant gas, so I had to get creative with excusing myself; (3) moodiness, ranging from lack of interest (mild depression?) to outright intolerance (quick to anger; (4) constipation, which is easy to fix but contributed to my moodiness; (5) weight gain, even when carefully monitoring what goes in my mouth and 50 mins of daily exercise, which also contributed to my moodiness, and (6) nausea, regardless of when I took it.  In the end, it was the nausea and mood swings, coupled with the fear that I was experiencing some level of depression, that caused me to stop taking Chantix.    I experienced minimal withdrawal symptoms, I think, with the most significant being short intense but infrequent. This lasted for about 3-4 days.  My mood is much better, I can focus, but weight is still a problem for me, but I'm working on that too.  And since I do not have my Chantix crutch, my new mantra is "There is no such thing as "just one" (cigarette)."  I do not want to go through quitting again, and having to make a choice about which "aid" to use - I probably would not start with Chantix the next time.  Good luck!

column2: dlucas050, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have thanked Chantix for saving my life! I smoked 1-2 packs a day . I had tried everything to quit smoking. I would recommend Chantix to anyone! It works!!!

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: my whole body hurts . if i walk i get cramps so bad i have to stop. i gat head aches. i lost my train of thought. i do have to say i did stop smoking, but did not finish due to side affects.

column2: Trish, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been a pack-a-day smoker for 25 years and desperately want to QUIT!  I am considering trying Chantix for the second time although my first experience was NOT a good one, it did help me to quit until I failed and gave in 8 months later.  I know first hand that Chantix WORKS...I'm just not sure that the side effects are worth it.  I was not under a Dr's care when I tried it the first time...I was using someone else's prescription when they decided NOT to use it due to the side effects.  I weined myself onto it as directed on package....but then experienced horrible nightmares...the worst of the worst nightmares...I was attending the funeral of both of my children...it was so vivid and so real that I carried that hurt around with me for days.  Although I had quit smoking for 3 weeks already, after my 5th horrible nightmare I decided to completely stop using Chantix...in fact, I was so discusted with it that I actually picked up the bottle and walked outside and threw it as far into the woods as I could!  I was DONE with it!  This is when the WORST part begins...When I stopped using Chantix cold turkey is when the panic attacks began.  The panic attacks turned into PHYCHOTIC RAGE!  I have never had a panic attack in my life so this was very scary for me.  I would be at work and start to feel very sweaty and uncomforitable not knowing where I was or what I was doing.  They didn't last more than an hour or so but stil was horrible.  The psychotic rage came one day when my son made me angry...I got myself so worked up over something little that I had NO controll over my actions.  This was, by far, the scarriest thing that has ever happened to me!  I knew I was out-of-controll breaking things in the house and screaming at the top of my lungs at my son, but I could NOT controll my anger.  My son sat on the bathroom floor and cried with me until it passed.  I will never forget that experience.  I am still considering trying Chantix again cuz I know it works. Crazy?

column2: Jen, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was scared to death of Day 8 when you are actually supposed to stop.  But that morning I woke up, and did not smoke.  I finished my pack the night before and I was surprised that I was not full of anxiety and tension and cravings.  To be honest, you just don't want to smoke.  I can't really describe it any other way.  The hardest thing to keep in mind, is that the behavioral habits are the "reminders" that you used to smoke.  When I woke, got in my car, drank coffee, drank alcohol.  Now, I just think, oh yeah, I don't do that anymore.  Side effects were most harsh in the first 3 days and in the first 3 days of the second week.  I think my body is getting used to it though.  I've dealt with major stomach cramps, gas, and the dreams - I can't really complain about those.  They are pretty fun - many of my old schoolmates from 20 years ago are in them.  Today is only day 3 of not smoking, but I feel confident and great.  My mood is just fine too - but I know to keep a look out.

column2: rob8543, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had been a smoker for almost 35 years. I realized about 10 years ago that I had to quit and as many smokers, tried and failed repeatedly.  I saw the tv ads for Chantix and ended up buying the 1st pack.  After reading the inserts and investigating the drug on the internet, I threw the pack in the garbage.  Several weeks later I spoke to a friend of mine that was diagnosed with lung cancer, she had been a smoker for over 45 years.  My friend told me that she had quit smoking using Chantix with absolutely no side effects.  I purchased another Chantix start pack.  I am thankful that I did not experience any side effects whatsoever.  I ended up buying the 2nd pack and am still smoke free today.  I have to say that the only effort I put forth to actually quit smoking was remembering to take the pills.  After 35 years, I have been smoke free since March 7th, 2011!!

column2: JAN, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I quit smoking after 2 weeks and had no desire to smoke again. the only side effect that I had was strange dreams, tireness. I tryed so many times to quit smoking with other products.  Chantex worked the best. I smoked for 35 years and its great not to smoke anymore.

column2: saved, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: After 40 years of smoking off and on it was two and as half years ago I made up my mind that i was never going to smoke again. My doc prescribed Chantix for me. I was a little concerned at first but was deseperate to kick the habit. After just two months on this product I stopped smoking and have continued to be smoke free every since. I would advise anyone to take Chantix. I feel that it has saved my life.

column2: saltymouth, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: the only side effect i had and still have after 3 months of no smoking is everything tastes nasty , like saalt i might as well drink salt because that is what everything i eat or drink tastes like i'm tempted tosmoke again because of this horrifying taste in my mouth YUCK

column2: Yuck, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Yuck! I experienced nausea, lethargy, nightmares, constipation and aggressive behavior. I was like a sick time bomb. I stopped after day 12. Not a good experience for me.Nicole~

column2: GG61, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am on my second week of Chantix.  I am no longer smoking and don't have the desire to.  Side effects are mild bloating, slight nausea and tiredness.  Vivid dreams - not scary, just weird.  So far no menatl issues beyond whay a typical quitter may experience.  Looking forward to being a non-smoker.  A little discomfort is well worth it.

column2: adesrosier, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: After reading about some of the serious side effects oc this drug, it dawned on me that they pale in comparison to the side effects of smoking cigarettes. 21 days of no smoking so far! Feel nausea sometimes...but the other option is much worse...I can live with that for 3 months...no brainer

column2: diva1963, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I'm a 47 year old female that has smoked since age 12 (about 1pack/day). My mother died of lung cancer in 2006 (smoker for 40+ years) however nicotine addiction is so powerful that I still was not motivated to quit.  Initially I was afraid to take Chantix because of the side effects but a friend had taken it and he stopped smoking. Very encouraging so I got a prescription and set quit date of 4/4/2011.  Doing fine until I had a glass of wine 4/9/2011 and smoked.  Didn't give up though - chalked it up as an experience and kept it moving.  The side effects were mild for me - lots of gas, vivid dreams, headaches,  troubling sleeping and drowsiness (how you can have both simultaneously is baffling); at any rate I was tobacco free so I figured it's not that bad.  Got really sick when I did not eat enough food - didn't make that mistake again.  After taking it for 30+ days it dawned on me that when you stop taking the drug there was not a "step down" process which I found troubling; the starter pack has a "step up" process.  Contacted Chantix and was told the same thing.  I found this to be alarming so I decided to wean myself off Chantix and pray that I did not begin to smoke.  Started taking 1 pill/day and eventually went to every other day and finally I didn't take it anymore.  It should be noted that the urges to smoke got a wee bit stronger but I had learned good coping skills and did not smoke.  I took a calculated risk and it paid off - I'm tobacco  free and off Chantix.  I would recommend this drug to anyone who wants to stop smoking.  The side effects were mild for me but that is not the case with everyone.

column2: tonyjoseph, 55-64 Male  (Patient)
column9: I have used Chantix.. slight rash in my ears but that was caused in part by a bug bite.  Had a few weird dreams.. have gained a little weight.. but that happens when you quit smoking anyway.  Been quit for 1 month cravings are slight but tolerable.. I was severly addicted (3 packs a day) So far it's working for me.. hope withdrawal works too. (from Chantix that is)

column2: rnlcomp, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Chantix is EVIL!!!!!!! I stopped taking it after 3 weeks, still not smoking but ya have to want to quit anyway, early on it did help with the urges but for all the side effects I had using it, WOW they need to ban this drug!!!

column2: Optimistic, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been taking this product for about a month now. No real cravings for a smoke anymore. The first 1 week I smoked regualrly, but noticed I was cutting back subconciously. The 2nd week I didnt smoke at all until late in the evening when I had a few drinks (maybe 3 cigs with drinks). Then I just stopped all together.I have friends that have successfully quit as well with no problems. So I figured I would give it a shot. I only really get nauseous in the mornings, even if I eat something. But it is not a daily thing, maybe just didn't eat enough with it. I dream now (never did before that I recalled later), but nothing horrible. My attitude, taste and appetite remain the same, and my sleep is fine as well.I read all these reviews and hear stories of the suicidal tendencies and such and laugh. If you have had issues with depression in the past, are not a strong willed and solid minded person THIS IS NOT FOR YOU. I don't believe it creates these issues, I believe if you have them, or had them, they will get worse/return. If you get upset easily, are not humble, think people are against you, get offended easily, hold grudges, etc then don't even bother. Just my opinion but do as you like.Best of luck quitting.

column2: Pamela Sue, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I started taking the recomended dose and quit smoking on the 7th day as directed. Everything seemed ok until the 3rd week, had gained 10 lbs and was very nervous and then by the middle of the 4th week I thought I was loosing my mind. I quit taking the Chantix and I think the withdraw as worse than the nicotine withdraw. Very depressed. I am now just 4 weeks off the Chantix and my mood and outlook is improving. Smoke free for 55 days but also still get cravings but I do have the will power to say no.  The Chantix was very scary for me. I have never had the kind of mind set I had while taking it.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I too am on day 8. No desire to smoke, in fact I don't feel like I ever smoked! 30+ years and THANK YOU CHANTRIX!!!!  I am completely confident that I have succeeded in something I have wanted to do for at least 16 years and that's quitting.

column2: Erin, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Have been very pleased with Chantix. I am on day "8", and have very little desire to smoke. I have smoked for about 35 years, and never thought my desire to smoke would diminish. With Chantix, the desire has faded. No crazy side effects so far, just a little upset stomach when I take my pill in the morning, and have been sleeping really well.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: The only side affect I experienced was insomnia. I took it for 13 weeks and had to stop so I could sleep. It worked then and have started it again 2 yrs later. Doctor prescribed Lunesta this time. Smoke free at last! I've been smoking for 25 years and tried everything out there available to quit. This is the only medication that worked for me.

column2: Gwen, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: In September 2009 my husband and I both began on our Chantix adventure.  I am almost 66 years old and have smoked probably from the age of 12.  I remember dreaming of having a cigarette when I got off the school bus.  Chantix was so easy I can't believe it.  I had tried patches a couple of times just to see if I could quit but I still had nicotine in my system and would take the patch off at night and have a cigarette.  By the time I tried Chantix it was on a fluke because I smoked 2-3 packs a day. A lovely enthusiastic 58-year-old woman who worked at Ace Hardware raved about Chantix and she stopped after 29 years.  The first week when I began the Chantix I smoked less right away.  I did have some personality changes I am told.  When I reported that to my doctor he told me to stop taking it but I just started taking it every other day until I just forgot to take it.  The first month I would tell my husband to leave me 3-4 cigarettes and I might sneak and smoke one cigarette at three intervals during the day until I just threw them all away.  I am stopping!  I did and by end of November 2009 I no longer smoked.  I don't tell anyone that I QUIT smoking, I just say I haven't had a cigarette for a year and a half.  I would still like to have a cigarette.  Every day I would like to have one.  I know that if I picked one up I would be hooked again.  The life saver for me was taking Xanax for anxiety and to sleep at night.  My husband who is a few years younger than me could not stop.  He had sleeping problems and because of his job he could not afford to take sleeping aids or be any thing other than totally alert for his job.  It's unfortunate that our VERY good insurance did not pay for this and I do not understand why because they pay for many other smoking cessation aids. I am more than satisfied with my experience with Chantix and after more than 50 years of smoking, I am now cigarette free.  I did not use a support group other than my husband who is very proud of me.

column2: old nurse, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I'm now smoke free for 3 years. After 40 plus years of smoking and numerous tries to quit I believe I finally did it! As a nurse of course I knew better but I was addicted. At a friend's suggestion I gave it a try, the desire melted away after about 2 months. The only side effect I experienced was mild nausea after taking the pill. I noticed I was calmer and I had a new lease on life. No more hiding or looking for a spot to smoke!

column2: Old nurse14dpi3, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: It is now 3 years! I am a believer. Smoked for 40 plus years tried several times to quit. I'm a nurse I should know better but I was addicted. A friend was successful so I gave it a try.The only problem I encountered was mild nausea after taking the pill. If anything I noticed I was calmer. I truly have a new lease on life!

column2: ZEKE, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am on day 14 and today is my quit day. The only "side effect" I am having is eating everything that isn't nailed down. No crazy dreams, upset stomach or suicidal feelings. I do tend to get upset easier than usual, but that is about the only differences I am experiencing.

column2: mike, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I'm 62 years old.  I've smoked since I was about 15.  On March 10, 2011 I started taking Chantix.  I quit smoking on March 16, 2011.  It's now been four weeks since I've smoked.  It's been easier than I expected with no side effects from the drug.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I really thought that this was a great drug. I quit after two days. continued taking it for two months.after 4 days i started getting heart palpitations.. went to the dc and my blood pressure was high (never had been before) then I had trouble sleeping. then I felt i was dieing. quit taking the chantix. it took me two years to feel half normal again.. my health has been up and down every sence.

column2: quitterquitter, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This is a great drug for quitting smoking but after 3 months of taking it, all I can think about is suicide.  I quit taking it.  I think I'd rather die from cancer than by my own hand.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This worked for me. The side effects for me were weird dreams, swelling of the extremeties and body aches like the flu coming on every afternoon. I never was depressed or moody, and it did take away cravings. The only issue was the habit of when I smoked and trigger of the habit. I quit and only used for a month currently coming off of drug.

column2: Seven, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: The first week was not so good.  Full of mood swings, and crying.  Now on week 3, and have been 8 days without a cigerette.  I am a social smoker, only with a few drinks.  Never throughout the day, so I wondered if it would actually work for me.  So far so good.  Dreams are vivid, but I sleep like a baby!  Great sleep!  If I take the pill before eating I get nauseated, but with food, I am fine.  I have noticed this week my hands/fingers are aching for no reason.  I am assuming that is from the medicine.  Let's not forget the hunger!!!  I am hungry all the time, and everything tastes GOOD.  Hopefully that will go away once I get off Chantix.  Overall I recommend this, it works.  Everyone I know that has taken it has stopped smoking for good.  Good luck!

column2: baley, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: waken up  with a erection

column2: kweirpc, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: The worst side affect for me was the vivid dreams, sometimes pleasant, sometimes not.  They seemed to ease up after about 2 1/2 weeks, and then I missed them in a way.  All and all, it did it's job after the 3rd prscription attempt.  If you think you have smoking beat and stop before finishing the entire cycle you stand a real good chance of relapsing.  I went the entire cycle this last time and am going on 3 months now smoke free.  I still have moments where I feel a craving, but if I busy myself for 3 -5 minutes, it goes away.  I never did have use for their support line...good luck, I feel great!!

column2: Female
column9: My sister took chantix and became psychotic. This medication was prescribed by a doctor in Sweden for her; the doctor did not know my sister at all, and was ignorant of her alcoholism.  The drug caused her to become enraged with everyone and everything, even after she stopped taking it. The danger of this drug is dire. My sister has not smoked since taking it, but her personality is forever changed and our relationship has been ruined. BE VERY CAREFUL with this drug. My own doctor refused to give it to me last year, because of its horrific side effects. Don't let Chantix (Champix) ruin your life.

column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I quit for good two weeks into treatment. Haven't looked back since. Only psychological side-effect I experienced was a deeper sleep (not bad/vivid dreams). I just slept better while I was on it (full 7-8 hours without interruption every night).

column2: CindyLindt, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: although I have quit smoking and the medicine and quit plan worked great .. I almost killed myself and am undergoing counseling to get my life back in order .. I would never recommend this medication to anyone and right now, at this particular time, I hate the fact that I took this medication in the 1st place

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Chantix works!! I don't even think about smoking anymore. It doesn't even pop into my head. However, it makes me very sick to my stomach. My doctor recommended that I take only 1 of the pills a day, but if I do that, then I want to smoke. My suggestion is to eat something 30 mins before taking it. Despite the feeling of wanting to throw up, I have stopped smoking. I don't even want one anymore ever, and I'm always around other people who smoke, so I smell it daily. IT WORKS if you can deal with the sick feeling.

column2: TommyRay, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Gee, do I trade well being to stop smoking? It caused severe depression and constipation and internal bleeding as a result. Add a large dose of cramps and that's Chantix for me despite it taking the edge off and the desire to smoke somewhat, I don't think I should continue use of it as I am NOT poductive at ALL. COncentration even seriously lacks now as well. I sleep ALOT and have been missingt my college classes due to the pain from cramps. I DO NOT recommend this for anyone but the FULLY physically fit, maybe they can fend off these side effects better than I. I am almost 50.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This is a horrible drug.  I should have listened to one of my friends who is a dr and stayed away.  While my smoking did decrease, my irritability was off the charts.  Week 3 so was my depression.  I cried for 2.5 days AFTER i quit taking the crap.  Evidently it BLOCKED my antidepressant (Lexapro) and ADD meds (Adderall).  that is the only way to explain it.  First we had to adjust my Lexapro (double the original dosage) and then my Adderall (also doubled) and so far so good.  I quit taking the Chantix on 12/5/10.  HORRIBLE depression for a month...then mood swings.  Once we adjusted the meds...i leveled out...but would rather smoke forever..the nausea was there but i didn't care - and it did affect my taste buds...including the taste of cigs...

column2: drakesmama, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Took for about 40 or so days.....threw up a couple of times if I did'nt eat with them....but the dreams were great still smoke free....

column2: kokopelli, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Two years ago I decided to stop smoking after 56 years. I had retired and didn't work all those years to hand over my pension to the cigarette company. I got the first month of Chantix and decided this was for me. I had some financial problems and couldn't get the second month but a friends husband had used it to quit and he had about two weeks worth left. He sent it to me and in the next two weeks I was completely off smoking. I won't say it was easy doing it that way but it was very effective. I had no side affects and only slightly craved a cigarette about once a day. I did try one about a month after quitting and found them to be horrible tasting and have never gone back. Chantix is a wonderful crutch to use and it works and works fine. After smoking for so many years I was doubtful I could quit but to do it in 6 weeks was wonderful and easy.Thank you for a product that worksSally Freshwater

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I can not sleep,depression is worse.Taking for 6 weeks.Feeling angry and thoughts of suicide. I'm DONE.

column2: pixiedust, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: It made me crazy..I took it for a week before I had to stop because I was in a maniacal rage and wanted to hurt someone. I have NEVER had any psychiatric problems and returned to 'normal' after taking it. This is a dangerous drug that should not be freely prescribed.

column2: nkuhn@altru.org,  Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This is the worse pill I have ever taken.  The side effects are beyond horrible.  Everybody I have talked that has taken it says the same thing. Do your research b4 taking this pill.

column2: camplady, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was a 2-3 pack smoker per day for 37 years, had a very stressful life, and easily agitated. I had tried everything that was offered and all they did was slow me down alittle. I had to have a quad-bypass at fifty years old which made me think of trying again. I started Chantix a year later and about 2 weeks into the program I said this was the day for me to not smoke again. It is now 2.5 years later and have not picked up or tempted to have a cigarette since. During the program there were times I wanted one but all I had to do was take a few deep breaths and let it out very slowly (just like taking a drag) and/or to suck on a sugarless cinnamon disk candy (do not chew it). I also had some very vivid  dreams. Most of the dreams were about me cheating and smoking a cigarette - I would panic and had to ask my husband if I did and he would say "no, it was a dream" (thank God).There was no more smoking in the house allowed. My husband and both children smoke (which I blame myself for the children - they are adults now). My husband and son are very supportive - my husband will wash his hands before coming near me (it was like he was smoking a cigarette next to me). My husband is going to try shortly.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I quit smoking on Oct 18th 2010. I have not had a cigarette since. I do not know for sure if I would recommend this treatment for others! I have experianced Extreme anger and aggressive behavior. I nearly fly into a rage over the smallest things. I am happy that I have quit smoking but I may lose my marriage as well as other close relationships. I am not sure it was worth the outcome!!!

column2: Swanqueen, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I took Chantix for 4 months.  I still smoked but much less.  I thought I could take it for 6 months but my insurance ran out.  The last couple weeks I was taking it I smoked about 3 cigs a day and didn't enjoy it.  When the pills ran out so did the pack of cigarettes.  I was very happy when I went to the store and actually DIDN'T buy another pack.  I don't miss smoking but I still think about it.  I had no bad side affects but it was hard for me to remember to take two pills a day and with a full stomach.  So I missed quite a few doses or took them on an empty stomach... not a good thing.  Now I am only 1 week completely smoke free.  Probably about a month of less than 5 cigarettes a day.  I am starting to think of myself as a non-smoker.  I like that.

column2: moxiesma, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I'm only on day 9 and have no cigarette cravings. Dreams, yes, nightmares, no.  I find myself in need of consuming lots of water. I'm sleeping fine and experiencing no mood changes. I was happy to find out my insurance paid for Chantix and the coupon on the website paid for my co-pay. I would recommend this drug to anyone who seriously wants to refrain from smoking.

column2: Lisa79, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I started Chantix 2/6 and had my last cigarette on 2/14. I have taken Chantix twice before, but only for 4 weeks each time b/c my insurance at the time didn't cover it. I felt fine after 4 weeks and didn't think I needed to take it any longer. Soon enough the cravings came back and I began to smoke regularly. This time my insurance covers the pills and I have committed to the 12 weeks regardless if I don't think I need it. FYI, there is a $40 off coupon on the Chantix site that is available to print for a limited time, but is good through March 2011 I believe. I have smoked since I was 13 and I am now 31. In regards to side effects, I experience a bit of nausea for about 20 minutes after my morning pill, constipation here and there, and longer more vivid dreams (not scary). I dont have the same nausea with my evening pill when I usually have more than a full stomach! I have not had any of the anxiety, panic, bad thoughts, or rage as other people have had. Here's the deal, your body is still withdrawing from nicotine...if you look up the effects of quitting cold turkey, you will see irritability, rage, mood swings, cold sweats, etc just like some people experience on Chantix, but I guess it is easier to assume the drug is causing the side effects. I don't doubt there are some undesirable side effects, but I know a few people that have tried Chantix and say "It didn't work" or "I had bad dreams" and my response is that the receptors in your brain are blocked so you are smoking out of habit and still have to say no to the cigarette. If you are having bad dreams, those dreams are temporary and sure beat the feelings your family will have when they are burying you due to your addiction to cigarettes. I actually feel like I am being a nicer person now b/c I am forcing myself to deal with situations differently as getting angry and having a cigarette is not an option. Take a deep breath and ask yourself if it is really worth getting upset over...probably not. Good luck!!

column2: Ms.Kia,  Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Oh my this pill is not a the scary experience others made it out to be. just like anything else its your attitude that dictates what happens.  I had mood swings I only gained 3 pounds (but I ate what I wanted just kept active) I had strange dreams, I had mood swings because i just broke up with my best friend for over 23years.  No matter what that Ciggerate was always there so the loss was huge at first. I just pushed through broke up with my boyfriend alot and just felt what i was feeling.  I am on the other end of things now and do NOT regret my choice.  I tried so many times to quit and this is the only time I feel like I am done! oh did i mention that i had to pay for these pills beccause my insurance did not cover?  178 a month also a good motivator its the same amount for ciggerates in a month. But guess who doesn't have to buy either this month?  ME!! and I smell so good just in time for my grandkids! But like I said it is up to you!!!! Good luck. and hang in there its soo worth it!

column2: Anon, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Absolutely hated this med. It made me angry, anxious, paranoid, gave me suicidal thoughts, terrible dreams, made my skin crawl. I lost a good relationship due to it.

column2: tallsweetdee, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: It's been 47 weeks since I had a cigarette, and I smoked for 34 years! I tried Chantix once before. It didn't work, but I don't think I gave it a fair chance. I really wanted to quit this time, which helped tremendously, but I couldn't have done it without the Chantix and the support of my family, friends and my doctor. By the 4th or 5th day on Chantix, the cigarettes started to taste bad and I wasn't enjoying them. So for the first few weeks, my memories of cigarettes weren't good, which made me not want to smoke one. The only real side effect I had was the dreams, but they were very vivid, wonderful, colorful dreams. My parents were young again and we traveled together. I do miss the dreams. I still crave a cigarette but the cravings are brief and getting further and further apart. I still cannot believe I've made it almost a year. I never, ever, ever thought I could do it!

column2: pixiedust, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Chantix almost made me lose my mind. Yes, it reduced my desire to smoke, but I was so angry I was almost in a rage. Everything made me angry, the phone would ring and I would want to throw it across the room, the dog would bark, I would feel like kicking him (and I have never harmed an animal) I was spending most of the day with my fists clenched feeling like I wanted to hurt someone. I quit taking it after about 3 weeks. I didn't try to stop smoking again until recently when a friend introduced me to electronic cigarettes, after trying it, I quit regular cigarettes completely and didn't feel like I was going crazy

column2: diane, 45-54 Female  (Patient)
column9: I have tried EVERYTHING before without success. Now on my 20th smoke-free day after 35 years of smoking. I waited until 2 weeks of Chantix before my quit date, think that helped me.
