I tried it before after 1 week, and failed on first day. I still occasionally think about getting a smoke, but it passes quickly. Yeah for me!!!

column2: susan l, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: chantix is dangerous. my husband took this drug and i almost had him arrested for violent behavior. one night he started screaming, yelling and throwing things. i told him he was crazy he told me he wanted to kill me and our 10 year old son.

column2: airasalt, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Excellent some minor side effects nothing compared to smokings damage. Little nausea right after taking for about 15 minutes.  Cravings for smoking sometimes occure you gotta have some will power. Gums are very sensitive,  I cant find that as a symtom but I will check with dentist.

column2: Pool_isCool, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: First for anyone to be totally successful you need to want to quit. No mystery drug will make you a non smoker. Chantix blocks the pleasure sensor in your brain from the nicotine you smoke. Eventually you can smoke a pack and not get pleasure from it. I saw things out of the corner of my eye that wasn't there. I did sleep good though, continued after I put the cigerettes down to take the drug for an additional week. I am now up on 4 years without a smoke. Nicotine replacement drugs just give you nicotine in a different form they don't address the nicotine addiction. I was addicted and am now cured. I still think about a Cigerette from time to time but I smoked for over 30 years. I wanted to quit and won't start again. That is your first choice you must want to quit deep down inside other wise you can not be successful.  Side not I had to quit Drinking beer as it goes hand in hand with smoking. I can drink beer today without an issue.

column2: Smokey, 35-44 Male  (Patient)
column9: It really does help the smoking craving. I get bad headaches and sometimes stomach aches. I thought the wild dreams were fun but sometimes disturbing. During very high stress I feel very violent, homicidal, and suicidal and wonder if i will snap. Being a rational person I don't act on that impulse but need to vent somehow. I recommend lots of exercise to focus your aggression and take your mind off smoking. I am cutting back on the dose to 1mg a day. I have to quit smoking and feel this product will make most people successful.

column2: YouCanDoItWithoutChantix, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I started taking Chantix and everything was great the 1st week, but after 3 week, I had swelling and deep purple bruising in my lips and SEVERE anxiety became an issue. I have never had anxiety or panic attacks before. My PCP told me to stop taking the Chantix immediately, and I did. It's now been 2 weeks since I've stopped the Chantix, I am back to smoking (less than before but still smoking) and I am on Prozac and Xanax (never needed that ebfore either) for the SEVERE panic attacks and anxiety that I'm having just trying to do daily activities like drive to work, take a shower or brush my teeth. Chantix may work for some, but the negative effects of that medicine has made my life miserable. I can't stand to be near people, wear a seatbelt or even in the worse case actually swallow water. I feel like I'm goinig to stop die, I can't speak, I can't breathe and I completely panic. I ahve smoked for 17 years (I'm 32) and I will keep smoking IF this is what I have to deal with in order to quit. It's not worth it. It actually got bad enough to the point that I even considered doing something "final" and "everlasting" in order to stop the panic. That is no way to live when you have a 10 yr old who depends on you. I WOULD NEVER SUGGEST THE MEDICINE TO ANYONE! My PCP said the only side effect would be upset stomach. Now I can't even stand to wear a winter coat because I feel constricted. IF YOU REALLY WANT TO QUIT, MAKE IT UP IN YOUR MIND THAT YOU WANT TO QUIT AND DON'T LET THE CIGARETTES WIN, YOU ARE STRONGER THAN ANY CIGARETTE!!!!!! I know it's hard but the Chantix did not take away the urge for wanting to smoke for me, I just had to say to myself NO, don't so it. And look what it got me....on Prozac and Xanax in order to make through a day.

column2: cakey1953, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: In the first few days it made me feel nauseous, but I stopped taking it on an empty stomach, and the nausea went away. My cravings haven't been nearly as intense as they would have been without this drug. I have tried quitting cold turkey many times, but hated how I felt. Chantix makes me almost forget about cigarettes. I have had no wierd dreams or any other side effects at all. I have felt a bit gassier, but I think that is because I have been eating more fruits and vegetables lately. I am on day 7of my Chantix, and each day is better than the one before.

column2: cbragg, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been using Chantix for 3 days now and have been smoking since I was 17 years old and am now 25, I have a three year old daughter and decided I needed to quit for her, I was smoking a pack a day and am already down to about 3 cigarettes a day. This medication really helps with the urge to want to go outside and take a smoke break, the only side effect I have had thus far is gas, and an upset stomach if I don't eat before I take the medication. My quit date is set for Friday and I am really looking forward to it, if things keep going the way they do I think I may quit sooner because I have no need or want for a cigarette anymore. Good luck to everyone out there who is trying Chantix or wants to try it, and REMEMBER: medication reacts to EVERYONE differently, not everyone will have the same side-effects, I figure if I can handle the gas, upset stomach, vivid dreams, and tiredness than I will take that over lung cancer or dying early anyday! Good luck again to everyone! :)

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been smoking for over 35 years and had attempted quitting at least 5 times with no success. I started Chantix and by day 6 I had almost quit, by day 8 I was done and have not smoked a ciggerette yet and it has been 2 months. The side affects are easy to manage and I am thrilled with this medication.

column2: 55-64 Female  (Patient)
column9: I have done very well on this but now i am afraid to come off of it wondering if it can be use as a maint drug for a few yrs oe rest of life

column2: on Treatment for less than 1 month
column9: I am nearing the end of my second week of Chantix now, I have been smoke free for about 6 days and I'm quite pleased with this medication so far. I have had very mild side effects such as gas, irritability, dry mouth, and vivid dreams. These side effects are more than manageable. I have had a few urges to smoke the last couple of days but they are so mellow and go away in a matter of minutes.About 3 days ago I had a hard time falling asleep but it was only for one night and it was only because my body was adjusting to the medication. I smoked a pack a day for 22 years. You really do have to have the desire to quit smoking, people need to stop thinking about it as "I've got to stop smoking" and start thinking about it as "I want to stop smoking". Cause let's be honest, smoking does'nt do a damn thing for you, it does'nt relax you, it does'nt make you life any better. Don't listen to the bad things you've heard about Chantix, true it does not work for everyone, but try it for yourself and have your own experience with it, otherwise your just looking for reasons to keep smoking.

I just started my second week on Chantix, I am currently at the maximum dose required. Chantix has been amazing for me so far. I was suppose to quit on Sunday, Jan. 16th but decided to quit on the 15th instead because I ran out of smokes. The urges are all gone now, I have not had any major side effects, I have'nt even gotten nausuas from it, but I also make sure that I eat a full meal and a glass of water when taking it. I have been getting some weird dreams but nothing bad, their actually kind of cool, I can remember dreams from 3 days ago they are that vivid. I smoked for 22 years, I'm 35, I started when I was 13, hell I was'nt even in the 8th grade yet. I just hope that this little miracle pill continues to work well for me, so far it is saving my life, thank you, Chantix.

column2: gmc44, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Started taking Chantix of 1/1 and had my last cigarette on 1/11 after smoking over 46 years. Stopped last year for 2 months but started back. Tried to quit earlier this fall but no luck so I thought I would try Chantix. The only side effect I've had is constipation. Just hope I can stay quit after the 12 weeks.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Caregiver)
Justbnme45, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I will start to take this Med in the morning. I've smoked for 30yrs & I really do what to stop!

column2: gturck, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: On NOV.14,2008 I had my last cigarett. I had started taking chantix.I had gone through the VA. And they recomended I use chantix. I had used other drugs and patches with no results. Within 8 weeks I had kicked the habit. I have been smoking since I was 16YRS old. I am now 60YRS old.I have tried various different methods of quiting but to no avail. I have now been smoke free for 2YRS and two months. Thanks chantix,It feels great.

column2: Karrie, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Chantix gave me terrible stomach upset.I cut back on the dosage and was able to quit smoking on 1/4 the recommended dosage. It's been 6 months since I quit and feeling great. I smoked for 20 years and don't miss it.

column2: KristinHonan,  Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I smoked for 15 years and took chantix because there was no way I was going to quit cold turkey. Within a week, I went from smoking 20 cigarettes a day to abour 4 or 5. The second week, I had the mentality that I still NEEDED to smoke so I kept buying them, even though they tasted disgusting. One day, I decided not to buy any more and that day was Jan 20th, 2009. I have not had a craving, or smoked since that day.The side affects were minimul such as:-weird and vivid dreams, but not heart stopping or nightmares- i tossed and turned alot in my sleep- I was irritable during the 3rd week. I don't know if I can blame it on Chantix or the overall withdrawl of not smoking.- skin irritation on my right palm - I developed a rash which needed topical medicine. As soon as I stopped taking chantix, it cleared up. I have my taste senses back! I no longer have to oversalt my food and to me, that is beneficial. I would recommend Chantix to anyone that is trying to quit smoking because it really DOES work.

column2: frv, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I tried to quit so many times using every way imaginable - cold turkey, patches, gum, Zyban, but I could never keep a quit until Chantix.  The only side effects I had were some very entertaining dreams.Chantix is the best aid available, but it doesn't make you quit.  You have to make it happen by using all the tools available - online free help (quitnet.com), deep breathing, exercise, lots of water, and education.  Learn about N.O.P.E. - not one puff ever.  Learn about PAWS and how nicotine changes how your brain controls dopamine, hormones and acetylcholine.Quitting is hard, but dealing with the effects of years of smoking is so much harder.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I did the starter pack then the 1mg continuing pack and found 1mg 2x's a day was too strong a dosage and gave up. The next time I tried I requested just the .5mg tabs of which I would take one at about 7am and another around 3pm. I was almost there then to find our my doctor only prescribed .5mg for once a day and would not give me more at that dosage but wanted to prescribe the 1mg continuing pack. This means I would have to start cutting the pills. I will look for another doctor and keep trying. I really believe the smaller dosage 2x's a day will work for me.

column2: zachary, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
25-34 Male  (Patient)
column9: The only thing that I had to deal with was occupying my hands, stress balls work well.

column2: djr0125, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: A number of folks have had really bad side effects from this drug, and they should not be taking Chantix.  For me, this has been a miracle drug.  I can't count the number of times I've tried to quit smoking.It took a little more than 2 weeks for the Chantix to 'kick in'.  I know the packet says to quit on day 7, but we (friend and I) were still having bad withdrawal symptoms on day 7, so we continued to smoke. We were reading the comments of other users and found that sometimes it took several weeks to start working on some people. After about 14-17 days on Chantix, the urge to smoke was drastically reduced to the point where we were only having occasional smokes and not enjoying them, so we finally quit.  This drug eases withdrawal symptoms so much that I was actually able to go out and have a drink and a meal without even thinking about having a smoke. What a sense of freedom!One side effect was nausea for about an hour or so after taking the pill. The nausea can be lessened by eating a light meal or snack before taking your pill.  The nausea decreases over time. Lots of flatulence that, unfortunately, did not respond to anti-gas pills.  The flatulence took a long time to go away -- about 5 to 6 weeks -- but it did finally go away.A bit into week #2 dreams became more vivid and memorable.  Actually, they were quite amusing and entertaining.  No nightmares.  We have no history of mental illness nor mood disorders, and Chantix did NOT cause any depression or mood swings or strange behaviors for either of us.  No sleep problems, either.The biggest drawback, aside from the flatulence, is the fact that not smoking has slowed metabolism and, despite trying to be careful, we have packed on 5-10 pounds.  If only Pharma had a solution for that side effect.  :-)[No, food does not taste any better than it ever has, so we can't blame it on the urban legend that food tastes better when you're no longer smoking.]

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This is the first time we know of that aggression/violence has been clearly documented as a side effect in a peer reviewed scientific journal. This raises the question of whether (Chantix) is suitable for use in the military, by police and others who are already in stress situations. One key characteristic of these events is uncontrollable rage. Not a good side effect for people paid to carry guns.I want this drug off the market. It is only a substitute for nicotine with more dangerous withdrawal. Sure it may help some people but what about the ones who end up taking lives as a result of taking a pill? Where has the neuroethics of prescription drugs taken us?

column2: deckhandmav, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I took Chantix a couple years ago and was able to quit almost immediately.  It blocks the effects of nicotine and allows you to see smoking for what it is: gross.  After about 4-5 months of being off the Chantix, I had a relapse.  17 months later, even though I didn't want to quit again, I knew I had to, so I started the Chantix again.  Like before, it started to work almost immediately.  I also noticed that the nausea symptoms are not as severe as when I used it the first time.  After your body gets used to the side effects, it's permanent, so if you're scared of taking Chantix a second time because of the side effects, don't worry--your body will remember.  The emotional side effects--ie mood swings, anger, bitterness, jealousy, hopelessness, loss of motivation, general idleness, strange dreams, etc.--I can say with confidence are from nicotine withdrawal and not the Chantix as I experienced them when I tried quitting cold turkey as well.  They persisted long after I took the Chantix and, to a certain extent, continued after I started smoking again (not the cure-all you imagine when you have cravings)!  This time around, I've found that regular exercise and self-affirmation are key and I hope not to make the same mistake I did before.  Bottom line: the side effects of Chantix are nothing compared to the effects of nicotine withdrawal in general.  Taking Chantix is a great way to get started, but don't forget that you will have to deal also with nicotine withdrawal for a year or two or three.  But it will be worth it and you will learn to solve your emotional problems without the aid of nicotine or other drugs.

column2: JWC, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: After 7 days on the medication I quit smoking and it's been 2 months since I had my last cigarette. It worked great for quitting, however I'm not sure the side affects are worth it. On my second week of taking the medication, I wasn't able to sleep, waking up at least once an hour, and I couldn't keep focus on anything. By week 3, my emotionalal state was all over the place. I would be laughing one minute and then crying the next. I started seeing a therapist because I thought I was loosing my mind. The anxiety attacks were scary. One night I was having suicidal and homocidal thoughts and that's when I realized that it had to be the medication that was causing this. I stopped taking the chantix 3 weeks ago. I still can't sleep thru the night and I continue to get minor anxiety attacks. My advise, if you are taking chantix, please have someone you see on a daily basis monitor you and your behavior. Thank god I still had my senses to realize that it was the medication that was driving me crazy.

column2: HOPFUL, EX NICO ADDICT, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I stopped smoking taking the drug about 3 years ago.  I was out drinking one night and made the stupid mistake of having a smoke.  The next day I was again a pack a day smoker.  I then smoked again for a year and a half.  Dissapointed in myself for starting up again I went and got another script for the drug.  Yes the dreams are vivid, very vivid.  However, I will take that as a trade off to quit again, and have.  The thing is, is that once your body gets introduced to nicotine, it becomes accustomed to it.  I have tried to quit cold turkey and and the side effects coincide with that.  This drug eliminates many of the side effects.  However, initially taking the drug I find myself smoking more because apparently I am not getting my nicotine fix.  After a couple of weeks though the urge to smoke is only a habbit that needs to be broken.

column2: blr0408, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I smoked for 15 years and thought quitting would be impossible.  I used the Chantix for five months and found it very helpful.  I only took half the daily dosage (1 pill cut in half instead of 2 per day).  The side effects were too intense for 2 pills a day.  I did experience crazy dreams but was ok with the side effects once I lowered the dosage.  I haven't smoked in over 6 months and that is partly due to the Chantix.  I did attend a smoking cessation class and other support groups which were hugely helpful.  I am honestly starting to feel like a nonsmoker and would recommend Chantix.  The side effects can be minimized if you work with your doctor on dosing.

column2: NomoreSmokieforMe, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I've been on Chantix for two weeks. I quit smoking after the 6th day. I have had no side effects whatsoever like nausea, dreams, depression. It has killed the urge to smoke so far. I am also using the 12 step reinforcement concept of "one day at a time". I've thought about quitting a million times, this time I actually did it, and I tell everyone I know to keep building my support group. But the Chantix has been wonderful in eliminating the urge and helping reduce the nicotine withdrawal symptoms.

column2: Gert, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: The drug worked wonderfully in making me quit smoking, but the side effects...Starting week 1 using the 0.5mg chantix oral tab was fine, but now at the end of week 3, I feel horrible. I have one more week worth of the 1.0mg tabs. I have NEVER had a reaction to any drugs whether this side of the law or not.  That said, my side effects with chantix include:- lack of appetite- change in palate- nausea- Diarrhea (week2-to present and also the WORST cases ever in my life)- intense thirst/dry mouth- flu like symptoms- debilitating muscle pains (neck)- muscle pains (back & forearms)- random sweats & shivers- dry skin - increased acid reflux- labored breathing- irascibility (w/disturbing malefic thoughts)- dizziness- mental stuporI don't discount the possibility of nicotine withdrawl, or compounding effects of symtpoms bringing on others (i.e. diarrhea can = dry mouth), but from my previous "cold turkey" attempts to quit smoking, I know I only experienced irascibility absent of the thoughts.I have only been able to stomach roughly 2000 calories in 3 days... lest muscle atrophy begins, and side effects increase, I am discontinuing my chantix use.   I hope this information was beneficial somewhere for someone.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: So disappointed. My reaction to Chantix was negative. I looking forward to becoming a non smoker. My husband and I started Chantix together. After a few days I was not my perky self, after a week everything was bothering me. I was told "stay aware that I could have some mood swings" so I paid attention. By day 8 I was becoming reactive to things that normally would not bothering me enough for a reaction. Day 10 my emotions were on sensative overload. Anger, sadness, frustration and irritability took over. I know people who have had success. At first I said I'de stick it out, once I was done with the meds I knew the side effects would pass and I would be back to myself. The last day my mood scared me. I felt I had no control over my emotions and that is not my personality. Maybe I will try again one day or try another alternative. I am 1 in few. The odds are in favor of Chantix and I am in Favor of Chantix. I am one of the unfortunate ones whom the medication doesn't agree with. :-(((

column2: suniblue, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Been on it two weeks.  Now 7 days since my quit date.  I'm amazed how the craving is almost gone.  Have moments, like coffee, when I have a mental urge.  I feel tired and somewhat queezy but I really think this is going to work!

column2: playbrnbrn, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: i wasent able t quit right away. i was on the chantix for about 4 months before i actually quit.  dident sleep very well while takin it.  and i gained 20 lbs even though i was on a strict 1000 cal diet.

column2: Nogood, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Bad gastro symptoms, night tremors, would not recommend to anyone

column2: MA5566, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: its the only stop smoking aide that i used that actually worked and i have stopped smoking but ive had a few side effects but in the end its worth it i gave my self a health life and a lot less chance of lung cancer and heart disease

column2: jomoore123, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver)
column9: I did not have any of the side effects that we're talked about in the adds I have seen. I am now on day 48 of not smoking. I am only taking the Chantrix now every other day. The only question I have is just how long does the drug stay in your system. I am trying to ease off the chantix. I am very happy with how well it worked for me.

column2: immacop, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I've been on Chantix for 2 weeks. The first week you can still smoke but by the end of that week, I just didn't get anything out of it. Im having some wild dreams, and some very sexual :) I still have craving but they are manageable. First two days on week two I had a couple of crying spells but no more. Im so glad Im doing this for myself! Good luck

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: I never thought I would be able to quit.  Today is 1 year without smoking for me - a minor miracle!!  I know that there are potential side effects and, of course, a person should have discussions and be in contact with their doctor throughout the process.  That is true with ANY drug and that is what Chantix is - a drug.  When my doctor first suggested it and gave me a script, I did not have it filled for over a month.  Ya see I came to the internet and read all the "horror stoiries" and it scared the hell out of me!!  When I finally decided to try it, the side effects (for me) were minor.  Occasional constipation and upset stomach if I forgot and took it on an empty stomach.  I had some vivid dreams but it was actually a bonus as I normally do not rememjber dreams.Bottom line for me is that Chantix is not magic.  I have to participate in the process.  I have had to make some significant life changes.  I now run 4 miles most days and have lost about 40 lbs.  I even go to some nic anon meetings on-line.  For me, Chantix was a great starting point and I would recommend it as long as it is under doctors supervision.

column2: Chris, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Personally I have mixed feelings about this drug. While I was taking it I felt absolutely fantastic and didn't want to smoke at all. I was in a great mood all the time and actually quit caffiene at the time as well and didn't have any of the previous withdrawal symptoms. The problems started after I stopped taking it. The day after stopping it I became violently ill and two days later I suffered a dissociative panic attack (I didn't know what it was at the time. I just thought I was dying). The next three weeks I felt normal, then suffered another large panic attack but this time the anxiety stayed. For the next week straight I always felt anxious, kind of like I was falling, and had to keep my mind occupied to keep from getting ill. I went to a doctor who told me I was having panic attacks and general anxiety and was prescribed my another drug to control it. I'd never had any issues like this in the past and had always been the headstong person others came to to help solve their problems. Now I take Citalopram (30mg) daily to help keep things under control and Xanax as needed when things get out of control. Fortunately, I've been able to function somewhat normally but it's been 20 months since I quit taking it and I still have panice attacks occassionaly. Before taking this drug, be sure to ask your doctor lots of questions about side effects and potential problems. I assumed side effects went away when you stop taking a drug. I founf out the hard way that's not true at all as mine didn't start until I stopped taking the drug. Also, if you have any family history of anxiety (social or otherwise), panic, or depression issues, I would NOT recommend taking this drug.

column2: Jade130, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I unfortunately was one that developed type 1 diabetes after taking this drug.

column2: Believer, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: My wife and I started this at the same time. Took it for a month before we even tried to reduced the amount of cigarettes per day. After a month we didn't feel any physical "buzz" from the nicotine so we knew all that remained was the psychological addiction. Within another couple of weeks we tapered off to zero cigs. We have been smoke free for over 2 1/2 years now. Chantix does affect your brain chemistry. With other tries at quitting the craving never went away resulting in a return to smoking. With Chantix there is virtually no craving remaining. Fresh tobacco smoke still smells good, unlike stale smoke, but it does not trigger any significant craving. Did have minor side effects: vivid dreams (technicolor and humorous); need to take on a full stomach to avoid cramps; gas (not smelly just noisy and at surprising times. We have friends who've also used Chantix. Out of the six of us, 5 have remained smoke free for over 2 years. I think this is one drug for which the manufacturer deserves to make as much profit as they are. After all, it costs less than the tobacco it replaces and after a couple of months it starts to save you a ton of $. P.S. I smoked for 35 years the last ten at over 2 packs per day.

column2: hiztime, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I started taking the pills and I stopped smoking in a week.  But I am having trouble breathing, I am always short of breath.  My doctor said it is anxiety due to depression caused by the chantix. So I stopped taking it.  Still smoke free, Chantix gave me a good start to bad I had to give it up, but I still not smoking. I think this side affect was to dangerous and it scared me

column2: Nubian, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This is a little miracle pill. I took it for 10 days (smoke free) and I have not taken it in the last 15 days still smoke free Plus Chantix free. You have to want to have the will to try and Chantix will get you over the first few days of withdrawal. Then it seemed to work similar to a Paxil with small mood changes and huge sexual side affects, so I stopped taking it myself. I have smoked for 20 years and did not think it was going to work but it has. I did not experience any nightmares or nausea. I will continue my quit because I also started eating better and exercising.  I am also reading Quitting for Dummies Book.   My husband is a diabetic has been on Chantix for 2 months smoke free but he has complained of nausea. My review is give this one a try, I have also tried the patch and gum this has no nicotine, you owe it to yourself.  I thank GOD for Chantix everyday because I can breathe like never before!

column2: now iam done, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: well i said i would check in every year that i wasn't smoking. Well it has been 2 YEARS! now.  I haven't even had a puff of a cigarette.  Be peristant but drop this drug if you have powerful reactions to it.  I didn't but you may

column2: nazz, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I took this pill for 9 weeks.  The first couple of weeks, I felt this was a miracle pill, I could never see myself not being a smoker.  At week 7-9, my co-workers, husband, and friends noticed a difference in me (confused alot, sad, fuzzy, and not me)and told me to stop.  I stopped at the ninth week and that's when all hell broke loose.  I don't know if it was the build up of the drug or the stopping but I uncontrollably cried for a week and a half.  I almost put my self in the hospital.  I did have suicidal thoughts but never admitted that to anyone for fear of being locked up somewhere.  But the pain of the depression and complete helplessness made me want to drive off a cliff to make it go away.  I know everyone reacts different to medication but please, it is NOT worth it.  Still depressed and extremely anxious.  Waiting to be normal again but i have hopes it will happen now when as before I thought I'd never be normal again.  Been out of work for 2 and a half weeks trying to get better.  Please don't use Chantix.

column2: chris, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I can't believe this medication actually worked. I have never wanted to stop smoking or ever tried to stop before. Honestly I just thought I'd give this a try to please my 12 yr old son who has been begging me to stop. I was a smoker for 21+yrs and am proud to say that I have not had 1 cigarette in over a month now. The only side effect I had was some pretty bad nausea once I started taking the 1mg pills in the morning and night. It did get better with a small meal, and went away completely in 4 or 5 days. Totally worth it if you ask me. Coming from someone who didn't truely want to stop smoking, this stuff works.

column2: janeanne, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I love the fact I don't smoke after one week, but can't stay awake to live. I am dizzy, anger easily, just wiped out completely and take adderral and its not working the way it should using this med. I think I am going to stop it. I hope I can stay clean though..

column2: disappointed, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I took Chantix for 4 1/2 days before my Dr. told me to stop taking it ( I would have stopped anyway).  By the second day, I was a little tired but didn't contribute it to the Chantix.  Each day the tiredness got a little worse until the 4th day.  That's when I was stuck in bed, sleeping all day and so dizzy I could barely see straight.  I've been off the Chantix for 4 full days now and I'm still sleeping 12 hrs a night, am so dizzy I wouldn't think of driving and I just sit around all day in a fog. Honestly, I cannot live like this.  I will be calling my Dr. again tomorrow.  Something has to be done about this dizziness as I can't function.  I really wish this would have worked for me.  It worked for my mom, who smoked for 45 yrs.  She didn't have any problems other than nausea and vivid dreams.  It works for many people but not for me.  If I had known that if I experienced nasty side effects, they might not go away after stopping this drug, I never would have tried it.

column2: lorealred3, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: other than some vivid dreams and a few sleepless nights i love the fact i am smoke free right now.  Been taking it for 17 days and haven't smoked for 9. I don't want a cigarette. I never thought i would say that. I smoked a pack a day for 30 years. This is a miracle drug and it gave me my life back. Looking forward to being able to breathe again.

column2: Annabella, 35-44 Female  (Patient)
column9: Very bad dreams!!!!  Tired, stomach upset

column2: frank, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: the only issue i really had is higher level of aniexty which has led to mood swings and sleep issues.overall it is and will be worth the issues to now be smoke free.the rest will improve overtime.i know this because this is my second time having to use the drug to quit smoking.

column2: chantix lover, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Chantix saved my life!! Smoked 1.5 packs a day for 17 years. Chantix is the best thing out there by farrrrrrrrrrrrrr. I heard all these bad things about Chantix. First off I did not have 1 crazy dream and I mean not 1! Nor did it make me " crazy " I think the people that go crazy on it are already a few screws short and are on other types of meds for mental problems I am not being mean just mean they are mixing too many meds together. And I took Chantix on a empty tummy many times in the 6 months I was on it and did not make me sick not once. Just give it a chance it worked for me.

column2: DavidThompson, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I could only take it for 3 weeks as it made me sick to my stomach.  Although for 2 weeks i did not smoke, and i still do not smoke.  its been a month now, sure i crave a smoke, but for some reason its easier to turn away from the cravings.  Although I still smoke in my dreams, yes i dream about smoking, In my dream i realize i quit and get mad at myself... then i wake up and am happy it was only a dream.

column2: Kathycharney62,  Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Ive smoked for 31 years and I never thought I could quit smoking, but with Chantix Ive been smoke free for ten days. But the aggresiveness, agitation nauses, having problems sleeping, and seeing things are there. I guess everything comes with a price. But Im going to stick with it.

column2: Zash, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I took it for two weeks, I did not notice any reduction in the urge to smoke but I did have horrible gastric side effects.Heart burn and severe gastritis by the time I stopped taking it I was in horrible pain .. my diaphragm felt like it was constantly contracting .. I had to stop taking it and now, almost 3 weeks later still have some lingering gastric issues.

column2: Julie, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Helped me to quit smoking but once off if started smoking again and am now on prozac and valium made me feel like I was going crazy. scary drug!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I just started my 4th week of taking Chantix.  It helped me cut down way down, with no side effects.  Then last night went to bed and started to feel dizzy.  Today still dizzy, but not wanting to smoke at all!!  Called the doctor and they told me that dizziness is a side effect that can happen anytime during treatment.  So cutting back dosage.  But feels good not to smoke.

column2: amiller, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I just started chantix 7 days ago and have had no side affects. The doctor said for me to set my quit date in 7 days so today is my quit date. So far I'm okay but when I get bored I just want to walk outside. But I'm not... I started smoking at 16 so I've smoked for 20 years. That's a long time and this is the hardest thing to do. The key is to keep busy... Good luck with everyone trying!!! we can do this and hopefully our children want pick up this nasty habit.

column2: scorpio17, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have smoked for 17 years, have a history of depression which I have been prescribed meds for on and off for 15 years, and I have had horrible dreams and insomnia for years.  I have experienced some side effects, stomach pain and nausea (but not as long as eat something before hand, which I learned VERY quickly!), and unusual dreams.  No nightmares, humorous entertaining, strange dreams.  Completely different from what I am used to.  No insomnia, no headaches (I also usually get horrible tension headaches a few times a week) THEY ARE GONE!  I'm on week 6 now, and I still have about 3 cigarettes a day, but I don't have cravings for them, it's just out of boredom usually.  Even when I've been out drinking, I'm not smoking. Myself and others have noticed I'm in a better mood, (and I'm not normally a "happy" person). I have seen nothing about this, but I am curious if this has happened for others, but my sex drive has been through the roof!!  Has that happened for anyone else?  Has your mood changed for the better?  I know everything else says all these negative mood changes, but I have had the complete opposite result.

column2: MommyDrogalis@aim.com, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Me and my husband both have just been prescribed Chantix. This morning was our first does of taking the .5 miligram of chantix . We BOTH noticed that we usually smoke about a pack a day or MORE and we both have only smoked about a pack aday today . After reading all the other patients reviews i am concerned about the random side-effects but willing to try anything to quit smoking. My husband has been smoking for 10 yrs and myself 7 yrs. We need to quit smoking for our children, we have 4 beautiful kids that we want to live and be there for. After reading about the crazy dreams we are waiting to see what happens after we fall asleep tonight (will post another review tomm.) But since we have been taking it for 24 hrs , my husband claims he has experienced low energy followed right by lots of energy , kinda an up and down in energy spike. Myself i have experienced headaches and lpss of energy for a few hours today. But chantix has definatly worked so far , we cant wait to follow through with the program and see how it turns out. Hopefully we become NON-smokers :DWe wish to everyone else who is trying to quit smoking with chantix  the best of luck & sweet dreams and mild side effects if any !

column2: sad in tx, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I took the Chantix one tablet daily after eating dinner because of the nausea it worked best for me. I quit smoking in less than one month. I stopped the chantix even though my doctor suggested I continue. I've been smoke free for 15 months and have not had any cravings. Shortly after stopping the Chantix I began experiencing extreme dizzness, insomina, and depression. I told my doctor that I wasn't feeling better after I quit smoking and was told that I would. I don't regret quitting because I smoked for 43 years and I wouldn't start smoking again. But the side effects have really affected my life. I went from being a healthy 53 year old to a dizzy, sluggish, depressed 54 year old and now my doctors can't seem to figure out the cause, I believe it's from the Chantix. I'm glad I don't smoke anymore just wish I felt better now that I don't.

column2: Bunny, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Apparently, this works for some people.  When I started taking it, I immediately became severely depressed.  I got up at night and just cried uncontrollably.  I have no history of depression.  The drug was absolutely not worth it to me.

column2: tamasyn62, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Started itching uncontrollably after two weeks . Still itching after three years

column2: Wifeofasmoker, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: I work in a surgical environment and was very concerned about many of the side effects.  In only a week we are seeing a few side effects.  I would encourage those with health problems, especially, to seek other treatment options.  I feel Chantix is too dangerous and their one year success rates are pretty low.  I would be interested in seeing more comments from those who have had long term success.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been smoking for about 3 years now. I do not want to end up hooked for life. I have tried several times to put the cigarettes down but I always fail, picking them back up in a week max. I have been quit so far for 4 weeks. Thanks Chantix! It has truly helped me !!

column2: Bullet 54, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: I tried  everything to quit from smoking, but it did not work for me. I wasted a lot of my time and money, only Chantix helped me quit and of course with the help of my doctor. Did not experienced any side effect. Thank you Chantix...

column2: rlpinsky, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Other than the nausea and weird dreams (which I have anyway), I've noticed that not only am I not smoking, I'm not craving more food.  It's almost like that thing in the back of your mind that says, "I feel bad, so I want to eat, smoke or drink" doesn't exist. I haven't felt the need to replace the cigarettes with something else that's bad for me. I'm actually eating less.  I haven't experienced the depression, but I've noticed that I am a little non-emotional, maybe a little numb feeling, not good or bad.  I guess that's better than being depressed.  I wonder if this medication could be used for other possible addictions like eating disorders or other possible drug addictions in addition to nicotine addiction.  People with drug addictions must increase their intake of what they are addicted to, to feel normal.  This medication blocks the release of dopamine when nicotine is introduced to the body, maybe it would do the same thing with other addictive drugs.  Just a thought.

column2: vinnie, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Am grateful that I was a NON-smoker before I had my 2 children.  Came to the US and started hanging out with smoking friends and picked up the habit and smoked for 28 years.  Tried once before with the patch but that didnt last very long.  Decided it was just time to try again. Had my DR prescribed Chantix and had a nonchalant attitude of if it works, it works.  Did the starter kit but could not handle the 1 mg so did split in 1/2 , which worked great for me.  Had no problems with taking it with just coffee and no problems with dreams since I made sure to take the 2nd dose at around 2PM.  Still smokeded for the next 3 weeks and noticed that I was smoking less (about ½ each time).  At the end of 3 weeks, I went home after work and it occurred to me that I did not smoke the entire day.  I just did not notice or had any cravings for one, actually I forgot that I needed a smoke.   AMAZING!  That was November 23rd, 2009 and have not looked back. I thought the holidays would have been hard to get thru with being a non-smoker, but Chantix really worked.  I did not follow thru with the full 3 months, I only took it for 6 weeks and that was enough for me.  Chantix is a very powerful drug. When I smell smoke, it does make me feel nauseus and when I see someone smoking in their car or outside, I am happy to report that I seldom get the cravings.  Today is 7months 22 days of being a non smoker.  I have gained 15lbs but not b/c I dont exercise, but now I have hypothyroidism and am dealing with new meds and hope to be optimized in the near future.  Thank you Chantix!  One step at a time.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I started smoking as a young teenager and smoked a pack a day for 23 years.  I did not want to quit, but felt that I had to for my daughter.  On her 1st birthday, I said enough is enough.  I talked to the doc and got a prescription for Chantix.  I smoked on it for the 1st two weeks and at the end of 2 weeks, I said, this just isn't working and was going to talk to my doctor the next day to start taking me off of it.  The next morning, I went outside as usual to smoke my morning cig, lit it, and said.....ewwwww.  I put it out and haven't touch one yet.  I have been 3 1/2 years without a cigarette and NO cravings.  I did have cravings around the 6 months mark, but they weren't too bad.  The craving always went away very fast.  I cannot believe now how disgusting people smell after the smoke, it's the grossest smell ever and I'm glad I don't smell like that anymore!    Good luck to everyone/anyone who is reading this with the thoughts of quitting smoking!Chantix works - even if you don't want to quit.

column2: BFRIEDMAN, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I HAVE NIGHTMARES, VERY AGGRESSIVE BEHAVIOR & ANXIETY THESE SYPTOMS ARE BAD SHOULD I QUIT TAKING THIS DRG ? CANT GET IN TOUCH WITH DR !!!

column2: Judy S, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I had no problem with Chantix until the seventh day when I suffered an extreme anxiety attack - racing heart, trouble breathing.  I stopped taking it but the following day woke up with canker sores in my mouth and a sore throat.  Wouldn't recommend it... too scary!!

column2: theslicknessyo, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Thank you chantix!!!  I have been free of cigarettes for 1 year and 6 months!!!  I used to smoke one and half packs a day!!!!  I smoked everywhere---my home, my car, my work....With chantix, i quit smoking after 8 days!!!!!!  omg!!!!  Awesome!!!  But I quit taking chantix after only 2 weeks!  It gave me horrible gas and I hated that!  But I loved the dreams it gave me!  I have done so well even though I took it for 2 weeks!  1 year and 6 months free of smoking! Try it.  it changed my life for the better!!!

column2: Eric71625, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: When I was prescribed Chantix, I was never told by my doctor not to drink while on the drug.  Based on my experience described below, I strongly recommend to everyone that reads this to abstain 100% from drinking any alcohol while taking Chantix.My experience:After drinking with friends (4 or 5 drinks) one evening while on Chantix for approximately 1 week (I was on the lowest dosage at that point), I had a significant black-out period of 8 hours, where I had almost complete memory loss during that time, suffered hallucinations, and put myself in potentially dangerous and strange situations (like hiding in bushes, changing clothes repeatedly, and stalking my own house and family members) all without any conscious decision making.  I awoke from this black-out in a panic at 2am, shaking and shivering, scared to death.Before this alcohol/chantix event, I had normal side effects, limited to trouble sleeping, strange dreams and mood swings.During my first week on the drug, it really helped with my cravings and I successfully quit for that week.  The drug works.  However, the side effects that many experience while taking this drug could be harmful to themselves or others.  I can only tell the users of WebMD that read these reviews to be very careful when taking Chantix, talk to your doctor regularly about the side effects, do not drink any alcohol while on the drug and only increase dosages when you have successfully accepted and handled the side effects from the lower dosage.I wish everyone the best in their quit attempts.

column2: FDJess, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: I'll start by saying I'm very sensitive to medications of any kind. Secondly as a nurse, I have seen this medication work wonders for my patients as well as friends. My dissatisfaction is entirely my own personal experience. Yes, it curbed cravings for cigarettes. However, I couldn't keep up the treatment d/t the serious side effects. The initial discomfort was the nausea which I tried to tolerate. After a week, however, I vividly remember driving to work and I was hallucinating. I won't recap the details of the hallucination, but it took me three days to get back to normal after ceasing the medication. I will say my best friend had no side effects whatsoever and has been quit for almost two years now after smoking for over 30 years. Also take special care if you have had mood/anxiety issues in the past as it did amplify anxiety. That could also have been attributed to nicotine withdrawals, but it is something to consider prior to taking.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I started my 1st does on June 13th and as of today I have not had the urge to smoke  and have not had one in 4 day.  The only side effect I have had is an upset stomach with my morning dose and it passes after about an hour.  My mood is GREAT, I am happier and less moody and have a ton of energy.  I am also enjoying all the attention i am getting from my friends and family!!

column2: MELISSA, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I JUST STARTED TAKING CHANTIX AND I AM DOING OK SO FAR. I HAVE BEEN IRRITABLE AND HAD CRAZY DREAMS FOR THE FIRST TIME TODAY. I HAVE NOT EXPERIANCED THE UPSET STOMACH OR ANYTHING ELSE I HAVE JUST BEEN IN A BAD MOOD FOR THE PAST 3 DAYS AND TODAY IS NOW MY 7TH DAY. I DO FEEL THAT I AM SMOKING LESS AND NOT REALLY HAVING THE URGE TO SMOKE AS MUCH. TOMORROW IS MY QUITING DAY AND I HOPE NO MORE SIDE EFFECTS ARISE.

column2: jjhilkert, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: My doctor prescribed a drug for my high blood pressure.  It costs too much...so I decided I would quit smoking.  My BP is BETTER than normal...and...I'm not smoking.  The only side affects..wild dreams..which is okay.  I don't have bad ones...technicolor man!

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: OK, First Off.. This drug is Not for everyone. It worked for my like a MIRICAL! I have smoked 1 pack a day for 15 years at times a little more. The medication can make your stomach upset so take it with food. Also you will have crazy dreams but so vivid you would think you are there, so the scary ones are scary. When I woke up I would just think to myself ok it is just a dream and I am a non smoker.. moving on! I was on the drug for 3 weeks and each day I did not want a smoke more and more untill no more smokes. It does cost you money most insurances do not pay for it but, $140 for one month supply to save $150 works for me! Also it clearly states if you have any mental health issues do not take this medication so your MD should know not to put you on it, also if you read your medication information when you pick up the drug you should also see this and not take it. This drug it is by far the best thing I have done, I am a non smoker in just 1 month no cravings I am saving money and I will recommend this drug to all smokers.

column2: goodsurf, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: As far as I am concerned, This is a miracle drug. I smoked a pack a day for 35 years and Chantix enabled me to finally stop. I had some bad nausea but that is the only side effect for me. Stopped smoking Jan 2009.

column2: Marshall, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Works great at suppression the urge to smoke and lessens the withdrawal symptoms. The only side effects I have had are upset stomach for about 30 minutes after taking medicine, feelings of euphoria (not a bad thing just happy) and increase hunger.

column2: ajsal85050, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have never felt so depressed in my life, Good Lord I am lashing out on people, feeling very tired, mood swings, headaches, I have not smoked for about 28 days works great, side effects really stink. I feel like I would rather smoke 3 packs a day then to feel the way I do. I just cannot explain how awful this feeling is. I have not taken since this morning, I am done with this drug. I cannot go through feeling like this on a daily basis. No Motivation Just mentally distraut. Dont even want to do normal everyday activities.

column2: Firefighter16, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had my last smoke on November 30, 2009.  I admit, there are times now that I think I would like to have a smoke and then remeber how I felt for 17 years.  Best move and drug ever made for this.  I reccomend to everyone I know that is amoking.  Good luck to all.

column2: Nancy, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This drug has worked for me. I smoked a pack a day for 40+ years and have tried to quit many times.  Although I have had some of the side effects described i.e. mild depression and nausea, they were very mild.  I have not gained weight. I have one or two cravings per day but they go away very quickly.  I took Chantix for one month before quitting. It really works!! I had never been able to make it through a 24 hour period.  Now even when I'm stressed, having a glass of wine, around other smokers, I don't really want a cigarette.

column2: Nils, 65-74 on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Maybe it was my attitude, but the Chantix made a huge difference in my success at quitting smoking. The claimed side effects are the same ones that can occur from smoking cessation.

column2: cteel, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Made me unable to sleep and very restless when I took the evening dose,also very nausea in the morning

column2: Wasted $$, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Mood swings and depression too much to handle after less than a month. Biggest waste of money I have ever spent.

column2: Donna, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Dreams turned into nightmares and I just couldn't handle it.

column2: Smoke Free!, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have read/heard all the horror stories about Chantix, but wanted to decide for myself.  Man, am I glad I did!  Taking Chantix as directed and have been 100% smoke free since May 4, 2010!The only side effect I had/have is nausea.  I simply make sure I take it on a full stomach, and no problems.  No suicidal thoughts, crazy dreams, mood swings, etc.  And I smoked for over 12 years!People, the bottom line is this.  All medications effect people differently.  What works for one might not for the other.  Talk to your doctor and decide for yourself.  For me it was the perfect option.  My company payed for it 100%, so I have already seen a dramatic increase financially from not smoking. For me, I couldn't have done it (and I tried several times) without Chantix, so thanks Pfizer...you have saved me money, my health, and possibly my life!

column2: ChildlessMother, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: My 32 year old daughter, wanted to quit smoking.  She was on several psychotropic drugs, all were documented in her medical records. A ARNP prescribed CHAXTIX - I found my daughter in bed in full rigor mortise, after taking all her medications.  I warn everyone NOT to use Chantix.  I am a Childless Mother.

column2: Bobbie H,, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: 2eshui1.  It did NOT reduce my urge to smoke!!!2.  It made me sick.4  Strange tingling and feeling I might faint.  I almost went to an emgergency room one lunch time when my doctor's offices were closed for lunch.  5.  It is VERY expensive.

column2: nonsmoker31, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I took this drug for 3 weeks. After the first few days I was smoking 1/2 the amount I was before starting Chantix. After 8 days I decided I would not buy another pack of cigarettes. That was 7 1/2 weeks ago, I have not had 1 cigarette (not even a drag). I think what made it easier was the fact that I've wanted to quit for about 2 years now. I did have some minor side affects.. Headaches (slight), vivid dreams, sick feelings in my stomach and constipation. They all seem very minor when I look back. I am 100% happy with what this drug helped me to accomplish!

column2: cindy 61, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This medicine made me want to kill myself and very depressed 4 weeks into it.  I do not recommend this medication to anyone who has multiple health problems such as I.  Not worth the side effects for me.

column2: braveheart13, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: First, take this medication on a full stomach.  Secondly, or maybe first, YOU have to decide you want to put those nasty things down. Cigarettes are a drug.  We are drug addicts. If we have made this drug a part of our lives for years, and then choose to remove it, we WILL experience changes in every aspect of our lives..... it is up to us to equip ourselves with HOW we are going to deal with our emotion DAILY since we no longer have our drug (the cigarettes) to turn to. If you PREPARE yourself with a GAME PLAN on how you are going to deal with every aspect of your life when you would normally grab a cigarette THEN you will be prepared to battle this addition. Drinking coffee, stuck in traffic, screaming kids, burned dinner, late to the soccer game, tear jerker movie, your favorite team lost AGAIN, drinking a caffeine loaded drink, you're tired, you're happy, you need to relax, you need to have a bowel movement, the list goes on and on....you are LOSING one of your "dearest" friends. SO FACE IT and quit blaming it all on CHANTIX.  It takes drug addicts months and years of work to stay clean, welcome to the club of ex-smokers aka drug addicts. For the obese, you have replaced one addiction with another. Stern words but the truth from one addict to another.  Join a support group BEFORE you choose to quit. Have a STEEL plan to battle this demon.You wouldn't go into battle without armour.  BE PREPARED!!!

column2: Sad to say, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: Chantix was a miracle drug as far as quitting smoking. What is a nicotiene receptor? It sure wrapped itself around more than just them. I have developed severe anxiety attacks, become obese (and I don't eat any more or any different now) and I don't really care about smoking or anything else. I was given medication for the anxiety and that gets me by...I was hoping life would be a little better. I have a very hard time concentrating which causes some problems with my work. I developed Carpul Tunnel and had to have surgery. I don't want to smoke though....isn't that what is most important?

column2: mmboud, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: After some rigorous pep talk from our doc, my husband & I went on Chantix together to kick 19-yr habits.  The first few days I just felt sick with nausea & headaches.  My husband didn't have these symptoms.  Soon the sickness went away & the moodiness crept in.  We thought it was just nicotine withdrawal & tried to be patient with each other.  I developed severe muscle tension, extreme anxiety, paranoia & panic attacks.  I couldn't function. My husband got unrelenting muscle tension, anxiety, paranoia and uncontrollable outbursts of rage.  Not anger, very dangerous rage.   We've been married for 16 years, I didn't even know him & I was VERY afraid.Once we realized it was the chantix & not the nicotine, he went back to the doctor.   He repeated his claims that chantix has NO side effects.  He said that he was just a little moody from nicotine withdrawal.  I was told that 19 yrs of damage to my dopamine and serotonin levels was more to blame  than the chantix.We had had enough.  My husband quit taking it cold turkey.  I gradually decreased my dose.  Then came the withdrawals.   My husband's uncontrollable rage mellowed into a constant state of aggravated  moodiness & anger that was coupled with anxiety attacks, muscle tension, depression & vertigo.  I got what has been diagnosed as an acute case of PTSD.  That's right, shell-shock.  Our doctor then decided that it still wasn't the chantix, that we must have been crazy the whole time.  I received Lexapro, klonopin & Propranolol.  My husband was put on celexa.  Its been 2 yrs since Chantix.  We DID quit smoking.  But I'm convinced that it was not due to the drug but to sheer stubbornness.  We still experience problems with anxiety that we now try to control with dietary supplements & yoga.  We both became obese.   (something else our doctor swore wouldn't happen with chantix).  Very long story short.  DO NOT take this drug.  DO NOT take this drug with your partner.  DO NOT take this drug if you live with children.

column2: ohnoitso38, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Im only 5 days into taking Chantix and so far I only have had some headaches (mild) and mild Nausea, no dreams yet but I start next week taking 1 5mg pill twice a day. Now I have noticed a little irritability, but I also take xanax which I think is keeping my anxiety normal.

column2: pleased, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I keep on checking in about my progress. It has been 20 months now NO SMOKING.  Every time I have a craving which sometimes is great I think about it and the smell it now makes me sick. By no means does this drug take away your cravings.

column2: Julia, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I read all the horror stories about this medication, but had several friends who used it successfully without issues.  So, when I decided to quit I asked for Chantix, and I am so glad I did.  While it certainly didn't stop the cravings entirely, I have no doubt it made them easier to manage.  And looking back, I was definitely a more happy-go-lucky version of myself while on it.  I only took it for 6 weeks total, because it started giving me pretty bad headaches after a while taking it, and the last week I used a week 1 pack to lower the dose down (even though my doctor said there wasn't a need to).  It worked for me my first time quitting after 20+ years, I'm now almost to my one year anniversary of quitting.  I would recommend it highly to anyone not at risk for the more serious potential side effects.  Just make sure that the people who know and are around you know what warning signs to look for so you can stop taking it if you need to.

column2: atwhatcost, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: My now ex-boyfriend is taking Chantix.  He is irritable all the time when he is around me.  He is always getting mad at me.  We broke up over this medication.  He has no emotions what-so-ever.  He sees me crying and doesn't care at all.  This is not the man I know!  Just 3 weeks ago before taking Chantix, he was a normal human being.  Now, he is like a stranger but he is NOT smoking anymore.  So, I guess Chantix works...

column2: SB39, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was a little afraid to take Chantix after reading some of the side affects, but decided that I should see for myself.  I didn't have any of the side affects that others had mentioned, I didn't have vivid dreams, although I did dream more than usual.  I had read that some people experience side affects when getting off of Chantix, so I took half of the dose for one day and a quarter of the dose the next day.  I haven't had any problems getting off of it.  It's been 6 weeks now and, occasionally, I would like to have a cigarette, but it's not a craving, just someting I miss. I'd been smoking for over 50 years, I didn't think I would ever be able to stop, but, I did.

column2: Jus42DayMI, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am one of those low percentage folks, I guess. I was prescribed Chantix and jumped right in, followed all directions and experienced what I can only call complete disfunction. Every part of my body hurt after one week and by week two I felt as though I had the flu. Never mind the mental anguish of being in a continuos fog. Before you assume, NO I am not on any medication and besides smoking I am the pinnacle of health. Chantix did not work for me. I wanted it too and I was excited about everything I heard and read. But, I am in the minority. So, with the advice from my Dr. I stopped taking Chantix and re-focused on the quit.  Like all smokers, I want to quit. I just could not tolerate the Chantix. Good Luck and have someone close monitor your behavior if your going to take this drug and be mindful that it has been successful for a lot of people. Thanks,

column2: Cougar54, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Chantix does make the craving very small. Unfortunately, the emotional and physical side effects were more than I could deal with.  Sleep and dreaming problems, although unpleasant and energy zapping, were the least of them.  My hair stopped growing, my nails stopped growing, and my complexion got acne issues that I have yet to fully recover from 9 months later.  I cried over nothing, blew my cork, and yelled at my pets for no reason as soon as I got home from work. Maybe a result of having to hold myself in check all day at work (my boss was a real princess and made life a bit more stressful). I really wish it had worked!!  I had a plan and reasons, told my family, friends, co-workers, and was very motivated to quit.  The Chantix made me such an awful person that I called the nurse, from work, in tears...I am not a crier and this was totally unacceptable, especially at work(BTW, I changed jobs and didn't work for the princess at this point). I stopped taking it and the nicotine craving returned slowly.  I was still not emotionally all together.  I have unfortunately gone back to being about a pack a day smoker, but have not lost the weight I gained while attempting to quit.  I will keep trying, but never will I use Chantix again.  I tell people to be very careful and monitor all aspects of their heath (mental & physical) if they should decide to use that aid.  I called Pfizer to tell them about the hair and nails growth issue and they basically ignored me.  Didn't ecpect anything different... Anyway.  Good luck to those trying to quit. Cheers and warm regards.

column2: 35-44 Male  (Patient)
column9: severe anxiety attack after three days,dizzy.trouble catching breath,shaking,first night got a headache should have stopped then, if you are sensitive to medicine i would not take this

column2: kat472010, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: anger ,sleepiness,stomach pain after taking.trouble doing much of anything,housework etc.

column2: CraftyGem, 35-44 Female
column9: I was on Chantix for 35 days with no side effects while taking Chantix. I did not do the 9 to 12 weeks as recommended, just didn't want to eat breakfast everyday.I did have side effects after stopping Chantix.1st day after Chantix was like walking around in a fog.2nd and 3rd day I was feeling different with unusual emotions. 4th day was the worst, I couldn't stop crying. All the side effects were gone on the 5th day. 6th day I was "normal" again. It has been 36 days since I quit smoking. I couldn't have quit smoking  without the help of Chantix.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I started smoking again after quitting for about 4 years.  I smoked for about 17 years.  I attempted many times to quit "cold turkey", but could only last a few days, and was totally miserable.  I have been on Chantix for 2 weeks now, and I feel wonderful.  I have occasional cravings, but they are nothing compared to what they were without Chantix.I must take it on a full stomach, or I will get nauseous.  I do have vivid dreams, but they do not really affect my sleep quality.

column2: diamond, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: 100% WORTH IT

column2: lee, 45-54 Male  (Patient)
column9: I have now been smoke free for over 2 years by taking chantix, but at what cost? I now have to take medication to control my anger and feeling of depression something I feel I will be on for the rest of my life. and my dreams have yet gone back to normal! thank you chantix for ruining my life!!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had no desire to quit smoking. I actually loved it, but it was doing bad things to my face. I ordered Chantix from my Dr.(which was actually covered by my ins) followed the program and I am smoke free. They tell you to use it for a few months after you quit and I know why if you around people who smoke it is very testing. I had none of the nasty side effects they warn you about just had to make sure I took it with food. I smoked for 16 years and it worked for me!

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Tried chantix for the 2nd time. have been taking it for awhile this time, till my last dr. visit. The first time i had no dreams or emotions. just functioned. so i stopped the pill. this time i dreamed and felt normal. i'm down to 5 cigs a day if it is a bad day. MY BLOOD WORK SHOWED A REDUCED CHLORESTEROL LEVEL, BUT A SPIKE IN MY BLOOD SUGAR. I SUGGEST A COMPLETE BLOOD WORK UP BEFORE, DURING AND AFTER TAKING THIS DRUG. I HAVE REPORTED THIS DRUG AND SIDE EFFECTS ON ME TO THE FDA. I HAVE SMOKED FOR 31 YEARS.

column2: Matthew2000, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: With any medication, the benefit greatly out weigh the side effects... I quit smoking after the first week. I've had restless nights and interactive dreams. But, the overall sensation of craving isn't half as bad as quitting cold turkey. I've done that many times w/out success. Chantix has given me a new lease on life. I'm nicotine free and I feel great about it. I recommend this drug to anyone who wants to quit. I've encouraged my 72 yr old Mother to use it. But, she wont... Maybe I can lead by example. I encourage everybody to quit smoking, and Chantix can help. I can live with the restless nights for awhile. Good luck :-)

column2: Good so far, 55-64 Male  (Patient)
column9: I took Chantix for 5 months. I smoked the first month until all my cigarettes were gone. No problems transitioning to quitting. No Nicotine withdrawal symptoms AT ALL. You still get cravigs but they are short and manageable. It's nothing like going cold turkey when you are climbing the walls screaming you have to have a cigarette NOW! The cravings are nothing like that. I had most of the side affects. They were annoying but bearable. I chose to quit smoking over giving up the drug. I planned on going 2 more months on the Chantix but decided to quit after 5 months to see what would happen. I was tired of the side affects and wanted to give it a try. I spent 8 days tapering off the drug opposite to the way you start the drug. I've been off Chantix 2 weeks now. Cravings have not increased at all. I know a cigarette would probably taste good and I'm sure I could easily go back. But I'm not. I don't need them like I once did because I was so dependent on them. Chantix is an amazing drug for those who can tolerate it. I was up to two packs a day and have smoked since age 14. I had tried many things in the past and had nothing but failures. I didn't put much hope in Chantix but somehow it worked!! All of the side affects are gone. There are times you feel like reaching for a cigarette out of habit. I have put myself in all of the situations where I'd like to smoke in the past. A bar, driving, cup of coffee, doing projects etc etc. No problems. Even if others are smoking there still isn't a problem. Like I said before I'm sure one would taste good but I tell myself I don't want it or need it. I feel I've acomplished an impossible feat. Good luck to others and hang in there! Sorry for the long post but I just wanted to explain my complete experience.

my husband and i are on chantix. saturday april 2 will be our stop date! my husband was a 1+ pack a day. we are halfing the dose between us. and it is still working. im a little easier than he is on stopping. having some dreams, not bad ones just vivid ones. i had a little headache but now they are gone after 5 days on med. im hoping it stays this good even after we up our dose to the 1mg pack. i do agree with commment above on  packaging product so its not so exspensive, but we would be spending money on cig. we get our $200.00 bonus money to spend on whatever we want for not smoking at the end of april! new shoes or hand bag will keep me going.lol good luck to all.

column2: Jaja817, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: 25 years of smoking. Smoked the first week like I was told I could. Quit on my quit day and have not looked back. Still have the physical urge but not the nicotine need if that makes sense. I was worried about the side affects and have the dreams and don't sleep so well but I would take that over smoking, any day and the side affects from smoking (think about it). I think those that had suicide thoughts or other really bad affects probably have/had those anyway and this just brings it out more so and it might be just that you are trying to quit. Not right but just something else you need to deal with. Just take it one moment (not a day, a moment) at a time. Every time I have the urge I say to myself or out loud just one more moment. One more moment. Now I just have moments of those thoughts. And I am more into just one more day and it is getting easier. We think smoking controls our emotions but our emotions control our smoking. I know that to be true with me. Or was true as it was a lot of the emotions that made me reach for a cig...now I don't have that to reach for only excuses. So just get through the moment. You can...without smoking. I can. Be positive. Think about caring for yourself and just live in the moment and get through each one of those moment by moment. Next time you get angry and cannot reach for a smoke don't blow up either just take a deep breath, walk it off, and let go of the moment. Overall great stuff for me. I think though that the packaging doesn't have to be quite so fancy and it may be a little cheaper to bring to market. But I also think the higher cost makes me want to quit all the more as I don't really want to blow that much money on taking a drug...anyway...good luck, think positive and one moment at a time.

column2: ex smoker , 55-64 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: pack a day smoker for 30+ years. decided it was time to quit. started chantix 3/15/10 quit date 3/22/10. first 5 - 6 days I was slightly nauseous and fuzzy headed. since then only one side effect. waiting for others to start. no dreams, no depressing thoughts, no upset stomachjust gas and loose stools. havent smoked in 8 days. urges are still strong but managible. stopped coughing already and my sense of smell has come back. this has been awsome so far... i can do it / sp can you

column2: lp, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I started taking meds 02/26/2010 i have not had a cig for 27 days, but i had to stop the meds going crazy cant sleep feel like crap dont want to be living anymore i am fighting with myself  about life!

column2: Marie, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: After smoking heavily for 30 years, and trying to quit a dozen times, I've been smoke free for 3 months. Took Chantix for two months and at first I loved it. Once the anxiety and other side effects got too bad, I had to wean off it gradually because stopping suddenly was worse. The nicotine craving may be gone but I'm fighting the urge to smoke every day. I'm not the person I used to be: I'm now depressed, irritable, stressed, angry and screaming at my kids all the time.  I've put on weight, I can't sleep at all, and I can't focus at work. I've been seeing a therapist for a few years, and she's now trying to help me work through these awful side-effects that have completely changed my personality. My doctor doesn't really know what to do and Pfizer doesn't want to deal with it.  Two months ago I would have recommended Chantix to any otherwise healthy person, now I'd say find another way to quit.

column2: nats0811, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am on day 5 of the medication. I honestly have hardly ANY urge to smoke, but I need to learn how to break the habit of smoking. Yesterday was my first time with any side effects. I got really moody and had CRAZY dreams. Other than that I feel this drug is awesome. I have seen 5 others quit completly and still are not smoking to this day! I am very thankful for this drug and hope i can continue on strong!

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
