column9: I am suffering from peripheral neuropathy from taking this prescription for only one dose.  I may never regain normal use or function of my hands.  This is a horrible drug that does not list this as a side effect.  Be warned-it may happen to you as well!!

column2: Craig, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I started Chantix in Dec.2006 I took it for 3 months, It appeared to be working fairly well,although I found myself VERY quick to anger and just thought it was from not smoking(my family also noticed the drastic change in my emotions)I was so irritable i went back to smoking in July 2007 and continued to smoke for six months. The aggitation continued this entire time. I started to feel so phyiscaly bad I decided to stop smoking again in Feb. 2008 but since the Chantix was so expensive I went on the generic nicoteen gum. I am not smoking and it has been 2 years and 2 months!! But the aggitation continues just as much or more.I saw a comercial on TV about chantix several months ago warning about these side effects of anger and realized that it was the Chantix causing these emotional problems. I finally decided it was time to see my doctor about this and was told it was probally not the Chantix since it has been 3 years since I have taken it??? and suggested I see A Psyciatrist as they would have more knowledge about this. I feel certain it is the Chantix. Iwill be making an appt. in the next day or two. I just hope he doesn't prescribe something else to cause even more problems.I WOULD NOT ever recomend Chantix to anyone.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I took this medication to stop smoking..instead I became aggitated, depressed, paranoid, and had suicidal thoughts. I would never recomend Chantix to anyone who has mental or personality disorders--I would rather keep smoking

column2: Frances Scjhroeder, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I stoped smoking on chantix, but no one told me that I could have some memory loss. I am very up set.

column2: Lynn, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have smoked at least 1 pack of cigarettes a day for over 37 years, 3 weeks ago I started taking Chantix, I smoked with it for one week and commited to quiting on the 8th day, it has now been 14 days today without smoking and I can honestly say I have no nicotine cravings, right now I'm teaching myself how to break the actual habit.  Chantix has been very effective for me.  Be sure to take on a full stomach or you will get sick.

column2: chantix, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
Joyful, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am 37 years old. I was told about this pill by two close friends, wh has successfully stopped. I was thinking it wouldn't work, as I tried other things in the past. I was also afraid with all the side effects. But, I knew I needed the help and really wanted to stop. So, It's 3 weeks later. I feel good, I haven't smoked or even had the desire to smoke. I can't believe it. However, I am experiencing some constipation, but I'm drinking lots of water, yogurt and salad to help. I am happy I did this.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I became very lazy/lethargic on Chantix (but not too lazy to smoke!), which is not common for me for an extended period of time.

column2: deanna, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: i have smoked for over 30 years,and have no family left(they all died from cigs)i am very happy with chantix thus far i have been on it for 2 weeks, and my smoking has decreased to 2-3 cigs a day,the side effects,for me, is the same as withdrawing from cig (cold turkey)vivid dreams, but nice,be sure to eat something before taking the pill,and plenty of water,the urge to smoke is greatly reduced,good luck to everyone, you are doing a great thing for your body,dying because you cant breath,is a bad way to check out of this world,i am only 48,and as i stated,have no family left,

column2: quackergirl67, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: After I stopped using, I told my boss what she could do to herself and then I resigned.  I am being treated for anxiety for the last 2 years caused by Chantix.  It did make me quit and I haven't smoked since but I wish I could have quit some other way.  The side effects are terrible.

column2: ROBERT, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: it helped me from smoking  after 1 month Iam down to 3 cigs.but have side effects.dizzy,not sleeping ,agitation.troble breathing.I stopped taking it now I feel really bad.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I love this stuff!!! I am 36 years old,and I have smoked a pack and a half a day for 20 years. Because of my 6 year old daughter and health reasons, I decided to quit for good. I set my quit day for March !st. I took the pill, and smoked for the previous week like directed. The day came. It was easier than I thought. I will admit I have had 4 cigs since then, but I didn't get anything from it, and the last one tasted like an ashtray. I did not have any of the side effects. I was worried about that to the point, I almost didn't do this, but I decided what the heck??? I am so glad I did!!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am on day 5 with Chantix.  I have drastically cut back since day 1 of being on it.  Went from a pack a day to about 7.  So far, I have had an upset stomach and gas.  Also, my mouth has a nasty metallic taste in it.  I dont know if I will be smoke free in 2 days, but I hope I am.  I am still wanting to smoke out of habit with friends.  I am doing well on the side effects, but I am getting so scared of all these stories I am reading.  I am dreading week 2 and eventually stopping the medications because all of these experiences people are having.  I hope I will be alright.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was a pack a day + smoker for 23yrs. I started Chantix Tuesday 2/23 & by friday i was down to 3 cigarettes. The taste & smell were absolutely nauseating. I do need to make sure I eat when I take it though. If I take it on an empty stomach it is a stomach ache like I've never known. The dreams are pretty awesome, like dreaming in coloring book mode.. when I can sleep. I have had some issues with insomnia, but from what I've read nicotine withdrawl can also cause insomnia. I just started taking 2pills twice a day & have noticed a slightly jittery feeling, but when I 1st started with 1 pill once a day I had the same feeling that went away once I adjusted. No mood swings, not suicidal thoughts, no anger issues. I've been smoke free for over a week now & couldn't be happier. The cravings come & go, but I've noticed that it's usually in situations when I would normally have a cigarette... after I eat, 1st thing in the morning... But it is the best decision I've ever made! I'm one of 5 other people I know who quit smoking with Chantix, I would recommend to anyone

column2: murjone, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I tried Chantix 3 different times, but by the 2nd week I couldn't deal with the nausea any longer.  The nausea got so bad it would even wake me at night.  As soon as I stopped taking them the nausea went away.I was so disappointed.  I had really hoped that they would help.

column2: sooz558, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver)
column9: Except for the difficulty of getting the pills out of the packaging, it's all been smooth going.  Even though I had a heart attack, there is no way that chantix brought it on.  Diet and smoking did it all.  The dreams I had were awesome.  Some of the best I've ever had, and no nightmares.  Was on chantix for 4 months, more from worrying about not being able to stay smokefree than a real need as I found out when I went to the hospital.  My advice is have a good check up before starting chantix and don't go into it with preconcieved ideas of what to expect, good or bad.

column2: tobykins@aol.com, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I took Chantix for approximately 5 weeks and the cravings are very manageable.  I loved the medicine until I realized I was getting very angry over small things.  Weird dreams over the week 4 and 5.... depression is awful.    I nearly got fired over the anger issues.  luckily my boss is trying help me out.   more to come soon.

column2: none, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I smoked pretty heavily for 17 yrs.  I had some difficulty for the first week getting use to the dosage.  It took my 3 weeks to get to full dosage and then it was a breeze to quit. If it gives you stomach problems, take it with food or full glass of water (like the directions tell you) and it will stop.  Had some vivid dreams, but in general, they were very entertaining.  Had some minor depression--which is why I took longer to get to the full dose. All in all--a heck of a lot easier than going cold turkey or buying cases of gum.  Go for it.

column2: brian1katy2, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Chantix worked as promised, no nasty side effects.  I hope everyone remembers how bad quitting cold turkey is and how crazy you can become.  Nicotine is one powerfull drug and your mind will do anything to get it once addicted.

column2: Good so far, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This drug has worked for me. I have had a lot of the side affects but for me they were tolerable. Very annoying but tolerable. I haven't smoked for over 3 months. But I could easily go back to smoking. This took away all of the nicotine withdrawal problems. I had none. Cold turkey and other rememdies failed for me. I was going nuts. This makes the cravings bearable. I'm afraid the cravings could be there forever since it was a learned habit for 40 years. I am going to take Chantix for 6 months which I'm not crazy about. I haven't gained or lost any weight. But I don't feel better or healthier either. I just hope when I come off this drug I can stay off the cigarettes because I'll tell you that I'm sure one would still taste good!

column2: Smoke Free, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I smoked for 40 years and didnt want to quit , but my Granddaughter told me I smelled from "Yucky sticks". The Doctor suggested Chantix and I said OK I'll try it. I took my first dose on Monday and had my very last cigarette on Thursday night. I rook the medication for 4 more weeks and thats all there is.  I have been smoke free since September 2006.. I never even craved a cigarette since.  Yes, so I gained a little weight,but I never had a bad dream or a thought  of suicide, or even a mood change that I know of,( at least no one said any thing about my mood). The best thing is my Granddaughter doesn't say I smell like Yucky Sticks.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Chantix did help me quit smoking, but I did get very naucous and sometimes even started to vomit.  I am almost on my 4th week of no smoking.

column2: ahhhhh, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: 3.5 months without a smoke!!!  You still have to make changes in your life for stress relief etc, but Chantix helped me get started.  I took it for a month and got some smoke free time under my belt.  It helped me to believe that I did not HAVE TO smoke.  I still had some cravings with Chantix but they never got totally out of control (drive to the gas station) as they did in the past.  If you have been thinking about quiting, I would direct you to discuss it with your doctor and try it.  It worked for me.

column2: smokless, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: this is week 3 for me and I have been smoke free for 2.5 of them weeks.  I have a craving maybe 4 times in that 2.5 weeks but they are manageable.  This way is sooooo much easer then cold turkey.  Thanks Chantix.

column2: shhnster, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: 15+ year heavy smokeless tobacco user. If I had know that Chantix would have worked so easily and effectively, I would have quit sooner. I was a bit concerned about the warnings, but had no side effects.

column2: Happy Breather , 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I recommend Chantix to everyone.  I set my quit date the day after Thanksgiving in 2007 and have not had a cig since. I was on Chantix for 8 weeks and followed directions exactly.  I never had a craving for a cig, and when I thought about it, I would just tell my self that I didn't need it.  I turned my focus to other things like exercising, reading, etc.  The only side effect was nausea for a brief period of time.  Taking Chantix was the best decision I ever made in my life to date. Don't get discouraged, stay focused and realize you are doing this to save your life. Good luck to everyone trying to quit.

column2: Salamander, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am 29 years old and have been smoking for 7 years. I started chanitx only 6 days ago and I am a NON-SMOKER!!! YEAH!  I totally think that if you want to try anything, this will do the trick. I wasn't sure if I was really wanting to quit but I thought about my 3 year old. SO, I did it. Chantix did have a few side effects; headaches, fatigue,   nausea, and I had a feeling of Vertigo(seeing stars and spinning rooms)(that went away with food). Every thing was easily controlled, and all the side effects went away after I halfed the dosage. I do recommend trying Chantix! I now know 5 people that have QUIT SMOKING with Chantix's help!  Thats A LOT!   Good Luck

column2: Jagrules10@aol.com, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I still have my cravings but the medicine is helping. Just into my second week. To other usuers how long did it take for Chantix to work for you?

column2: scoop420, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was a pack a day guy for 40 years and it had a pretty good grip on me, had tried to quit many times and lacked the willpower to get it done. I quit on Christmas Day and have not looked back, I just hit day 50. I have had few side effects, you do need to have something on your stomach or it makes you a little quesy. My sleep pattern was screwed up, that is why I might be writing this at 3 in the morning...lol!No real vivid dreams or other bothersome side effects. I am very happy to say this pill worked its magic for me, my cravings were so mild that I could overcome them and now that I have the monkey off my back, he ain't getting back on! I am very proud to have accomplished something that 3 months ago, I did not think possible.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I smoked for 13 years and I am 25 now. I started taking Chantix and didn't even really want to quit smoking but my husband did. I quit 4 days after starting and it's been 6 monthes. I did feel a bit sick for about 5 mins after taking it in the morning but mostly if I hadn't eaten yet. I highly recommend it to all my still smoking friends!!

column2: pjcg, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: My daughter's fiance took this medication.  the first time he quit smoking easily, but had really bad nightmares.  About a year later he started it again as he picked up the habit again.  The second time he committed Suicide and was successful.  he was a wonderful man to loose him like this.  I answered the information below with my son-in-law to be's personal demographics .

column2: Heavenly9918, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I tried this medication and it was AWFUL!  It was working great until I had to increases the dosage of it.  Then I was VERY nauseous and tired.  I had terrible headaches and was consistently tired. And to make it worse, it was expensive, of course insurance didn't cover it.  $100 for the starter pack and I couldn't get through week 1.  I started taking Wellbutrin SR and it works GREAT!  I have been smoke free for 3 weeks. And i have no desire to start again.

column2: smokefree, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: nausea, headteacher, backache, joint pain. but so far manageable, so far.

column2: dolli, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I can't believe how well this medication is working for me after 4days the desire to smoke was almost gone then when I lit one up it tasted gross and gave me no satisfaction after a week I quit I have quit for 3 weeks now cut my dose to half the only problem I have experienced so far is if I take it on an empty stomach I feel sick for an hour or so but that is it I have not gained any weight yet with all the other methods I did. I have not been really edgy I have had some vivid dreams I kind of enjoy them and I do have some cravings but not nearly as many as cold turkey or the patch. If you really want to quit I think it is worth giving it a shot. I will let you know when I get off it if there are any side effects

column2: KristinTalley2010, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I started Chantix 5 weeks ago, and have been smoke free for almost 2 weeks. I started smoking when i was 13, and I am 29 now and I smoked about a pack to a pack and a half a day.I do not get scary dreams, just weird ones. my boyfriend wakes up because I am constantly moving in my sleep, sometimes pushing him out of bed. I find myself agitated at home, kind of short tempered but I chew gum or make myself busy and it goes away. I cannot say that being agitated is the medicine, I am blaming it on the withdrawl from not having a cigarette. Smoking has been my best friend for 15 years and it's really hard giving it up, but I feel so much better, I can breath so much better, and I actually have more energy. All in all, this is a great medicine, because it not only stops your cravings for cigarettes, it also decreased my coffee intake, from 4 cups a day to 2. I recommend this medication to anyone that is serious about quitting.My only suggestion would be to have the pills in a bottle, instead of a package; for convinience sake.

column2: fatty, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: chantix has worked well.any thoughts of smoking were quickly and easily run off.i have developed a out of control sweet tooth.

column2: lagrecaluanne, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: 50 yrs of smoking--over with.  no stress, worked great. husband and friends still smoked right in from of me and didn't bother me. been 3 yrs now. still no anxiety or cravings other than an occasional thought of when I did smoke.  I just say NO.

column2: desert rose, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Fortunately I did not have any severe side affects that some patients seem to have had.  I did have a few nights with vivid dreams, nothing scary and was a little short tempered at home and occasionaly at work.  I have been smoke free since August 2007 after smoking 1+ pack a day for 44 years!!  At times, far and few between, I think I want a cigarette but I smell an old ash try and that kills the desire immediately!!  Biggest problem for me has been the weight gain which I am now struggling with.  It is wonderful living in the desert and smelling clean fresh air and not wheezing while taking walks with my dogs.  Best money I have ever spent!!

column2: Single mom..., 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I quit smoking over 13 years ago but became addicted to the the nicotine gum.  I was told chantix could help.  The first time I tried it was in Oct 2009.  I was on it for about two weeks and had to get off of it.  I was very nauseated, aggressive and very easily aggitated. Not good for a mom going through a divorce with a 3 and 12 year old boys. I have to say I thought possibliy some of the above side effects/mood could of been due to my husband moving out.  Today is 01/26/10.  Last week I saw a new doctor he talked me into giving Chantix a try again.  I still had plenty left so I agreed.  Around 3:30 p.m. I took one pill that evening I was nauseated and moody..irritable.  Not good..I have kids.  I tried another pill the next day (Friday) and by Friday night I didn't even like myself.  I told my older son Saturday morning what was going on and that I would never take the medicine again.  I do not recommend this drug especially if kids are in the household!!  I do believe if I would of stayed on this medicine I probably would of lost my job and I don't even want to think about the rest.

column2: hopeful, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: well one week on the chantix and planned on quitting today but somked this morning??? dreams yes but not nightmares. 2 nights in a row had very bad night, my whole body jumps for hours,very uncomfortable, but got through it. I guess the urge to smoke will go away I hope. is it ok to still be smoking a little? gonna keep taking my med and see

column2: Ms Robbie, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I had smoked for 49 years when I began taking Chantix.  I started it on October 9 and have been smoke-free since October 25, which is now three months ago.  While I had vivid dreams, they were mostly entertaining; none was alarming.  My only difficulty was extreme heartburn (which is why I quit taking Chantix after the first 4-week packet) that has not yet (three months later) completely left me.  The heartburn is something I had never experienced before, and it's a real bear.

column2: JamieonWebMD, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Chantix made me suicidal.  It did nothing to curb the cravings.  I've had an easier (and equally unsuccessful) experience going cold turkey.  I was cutting myself, and I'm no teenage emo character.  I was frequently nauseated; I threw up in the middle of the aisle at my local supermarket.  Charming.  My experience with this drug was so bad that for once, I actually felt good at resuming smoking and tossing the Chantix.  I mean, how bad can this drug be if I felt good at resuming smoking?

column2: gotchie916@aol.com , 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I quit three days into my second week continued taking it for a nearly a month; didn't think I needed any more so I quit taking it, two days later I awoke with a swollen throat went to the doctor & they couldn't figure it out they tried steroids (38 pounds later)surgery & they want to try other things but I don't have the money or Ins. it's been eight months now; it is like being tormented daily to the point I have several times I have seriously considered death as my only way out, went to several doctors before I lost my Ins.I haven't had Ins. since Sept '09 so I can't get the help I need, had I known the out come I would not have taken chantix, I slip in and out of sad stages, feelings of anxiousness, anger... I asked about side effects and was told that "the ONLY side effects were the strange dreams and possible upset stomach" now that a few months have gone by all of a sudden these side effects have come to light. I think Chantix should pay for my medical care, thats the least they can do.

column2: Vinnie, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This is a follow up from a prior post in Nov 2009. Briefly, I started Chantix on Nov 3 and officially stop smoking Nov 23.  Stopped taking Chantix Dec 8 without weaning off.  Yesterday was officially 3 months smokefree.  I rarely think about smoking and if I do, it only last for a fleeting 1-2 minutes.  When I started Chantix, I had a very nonchalant attitude of if it works, it works, if not well, I tried. I would recommend this.  I had no serous side effects.  A little nausea and dream but no big problems.  Chantix made it so easy if fact too easy and well worth it.My daughter started shortly after I started and is now smokefree.  Now her husband has started and is down to 1 cig a day.  They are so pleased with Chantix.  They had both tried to patch but were so miserable and cranky.  The experience with Chantix is nothing compared to the patch.  Thank you Chantix.

column2: 81 gazelle, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This April will be 2 yrs. Took it for about 2mos. Still have sleep issues.Wake up every night. I think the trade off is worth it.Never made me sick.Critical to follow dosage rules.I started with the full dose because I got the remainder of a friends perscription.No Dr visit.Had to stop taking it after 3 days.Was having bizzare dreams and wake ups.Waited a week,then started taking the half pills that I cut w/ a paring knife.Did that for aweek,then full dosage.Maybe that's how I "earned" this sleep disorder.Never,ever,ever had trouble sleeping till this pill.Still think it was worth it.I'm now trying Melatonin.Been taking Ambien for 7 wks. and feel my resistance building already(habit forming).Have trouble sleeping on the weekends w/o it.After almost 2 yrs. of waking up in the middle of the night,I needed to make a move.The Ambien was a Godsend at first,but I'm starting to feel what everyone says about this drug.Will continue my quest for a good night sleep.STILL WORTH IT>hope this helps

column2: ddgemma, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have noticed that a lot of people are having issues with nausea. Nausea is a side effect, but only if you don't take your pill's durring a meal. Check with your Dr. and they will say the same thing....I have smoked for 16 years and this is actually my second time quitting with Chantix. The first time I was smoke free for 3 months, and then one of my friends had a cancer scare, another friend separated and divorced from her husband, I was suffering financial issues, etc... 9 months later, I am quitting again. I am 8 weeks in and only smoke 1 or 2 cigarettes a day and that is just because I still have so many left in my pack! As soon as this pack is done, so I am. I very much enjoyed being smoke free last time and found out that not only was I saving money by quitting, but I had so much more energy and time as a non-smoker. Good luck to all of you!

column2: liverpool8, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I smoked a pack a day for 29 years, and after 3 weeks on Chantix I no longer felt the need to smoke.  It has been 7 months at this point, and I honestly don't think I will ever go back to smoking.  I highly recommend this drug, apart from a little nausea (bearable) for a few minutes in the 2nd week, it was smooth sailing.

column2: chefmt, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: smoked a pack a day for 20 years! smoke free after 3 weeks on chantix! Little nauseous for about 5 min. after taking was my only negative side affect.

column2: larry, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: i sill smoke over a pack a day

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have smoked on and off since I was 18. I am now 36.  I have tried everything to quit smoking and nothing, until now, has worked.  I have been on Chantix for over a week and find it to be the best thing ever.  I have very small cravings every once in while but, they pass very easily.  The only thing that I have a very strong craving for is exercise.  I was leary at first due to all of the side effects  with this drug but, if you monitor yourself and ask others to look out for odd behavior you should be okay. I have also lost 3 pounds since I began taking it.   I would definitely recommend seeing how your body reacts to both starting Chantix and upping the dosage (2nd week).  I did find my second day I was a bit sluggish but, it passed by the 3rd.

column2: kelly, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: i did get arash on my hands and foot.  i still have the rash and pustul blisters on hands and foot and red marks it's very painful.  i started the chantix in april 2009, i've quit smoking in two month, but my hands broke out within that time period and are still having trouble with them

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: So glad I'm not experiencing the really bad side effects yet, but I have noticed a numbness in one of my fingers- kind of strange.  I did a search and found that others have had the same problem.

column2: mactrucker, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month
column9: On my 2nd week of taking the drug,my face swelled around my eyes,and my head itched.

column2: blunicorn47, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month
Heather in Ohio , 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have only been taking Chantix for three weeks now, but I have had the worst side effects. Vomiting, acid reflux, insomnia, just to name the worst. The good news is, I haven't had a cigarette for two weeks. but I'm afraid the cons are outweighing the pros at this point. Apparently Chantix isn't for everyone.

column2: Mich54, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: My quit date was Aug 12th 2009.I followed the dosing but when it came to taking 1mg twice a day I couldn't do it and didn't need to.I just kept taking 0.5mg twice a day and stopped the pills after two mos.After smoking for 40 years I have now been smoke free for almost 5 mos and have very few urges and get past them quickly.I did not gain any weight!

column2: sisabear, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: My husband and I both started Chantix on August 17, 2009.  The pills messed with our stomachs until we ate something.  He isn't a big breakfast eater, and neither was I, but we were committed to trying to quit smoking.  My husband lasted about 3 weeks, then stopped taking the pills because of the having-to-eat thing, and started smoking again.  I stayed on the drug for 2 months and have been smoke free for 4 months now, but I am not happy with the weight gain and I have horrible crying bouts for weeks on end and for no reason.  The drug itself works great to suppress the urge to smoke, but not so sure the side effects are worth it.

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This is a continuing followup. Been on Chantic 10 weeks now and haven't had a cigarette 6 weeks today. I have smoked 40 years and was up to 2 packs a day. Side affects: Stomach/nausea is fine if I take with food. Some days I feel depressed. It comes and goes. Still get strange dreams from time to time. These dreams by the way ARE NOT nightmares. Sleep pattern is a little screwed up. Chantix leaves a bad taste in my mouth from time to time. Sometimes the Chantix makes food taste different. I am doing much better than I could ever have imagined. There isn't any stress or anger like when going cold turkey. No withdrawl symptoms. Still get cravings multiple times a day but they are very manageable. I plan on using the Chantix until I haven't smoked for 90 days and then will start weening off of it. Will continue with followups.

column2: Pattygail, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I used Chantix along with a mild nerve pill and was in the ninth week of treatment. I quit smoking with success. I let myself run completely out of cigarettes and never bought another pack. I have been smoke-free now since April 9, 2009. But it really helps to remember the reasons for choosing to quit smoking in the first place. Now no more lying awake at night listening to myslef wheeze. My breathing is so much better and I am so proud of myself. Chantix really does work if you have made up your mind to quit. But you cannot make excuses. Just be resolved to never smoke again. By the way, I had smoked for 46 years.

column2: 35-44 Male  (Patient)
HangInThere, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I quit for a year and two months, then stupidly started again.  Quit again after 7months, also with Chantix.  The first time I had a horrible reaction after about 2mo off the drug.  I thought I would never get better - but I did, after about 4-5mo.  The second experience was not as bad and went through its cycle very fast.  After being sure that the bad reactions were from Chantix, I now believe that they are from nicotine (or other tobacco chemical) withdrawal.This stuff works, and works very well.  However, I didn't quit after a week, I just found that I knew when the time came - which was about 2 1/2 weeks.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: excellent to stop smoking, had to repeat sessions twice 2nd time only needed 1/2 tab for 3 mos. immediately gave me a mood lift but spiraled downward 2 days after stopping the treatment. was back to norm 3 days later. 11 days no desire to smoke.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I really struggled with the idea of taking a pill to quit smoking.  It took me awhile to get on board with that idea but I am glad I finally did.  Talk to your doctor and be aware and educated about potential side affects but if you really want to quit smoking and have tried all the other methods (cold turkey, nicotine replacement etc) please try this.  I am now over 2 months smoke free and have been off Chantix for almost 1 month.  During the first month, the normally off the charts cravings never happened.  Yes, I had cravings but they were not overpowering.  For me, making it through a few weeks gave me the confidence to see that, yes, I could make it through a day and lifes challenges without a smoke.  I am in no way trying to discount some of the negative stories on this site and others.  Honestly, it was those stories that kept me from getting the perscription filled for so long.  But if I had not finally given it a try I would be heading into 2010 with a Marlboro in my mouth!!

column2: GLAD I QUIT, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: IT HAS BEEN 14 MONTHS NOW HAVE NOT EVEN HAD A PUFF.  STILL WANT ONE BUT A PERSON QUITS FOR VARIOUS REASONS WITH THE HELP OF THIS DRUG IT MADE MY WISH TO BE A NONSMOKER EASY.

column2: Godsdaughter, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: After smoking for 42 years, I now enjoy the freedom of being smoke-free. This is an experience I thought NEVER would happen to me. I started when I was 12 & my last cigarette was 5 months ago. Even my cat thanks the new air he breathes.Although I took Chantix once before, I claimed it didn't work, because I kept on smoking and I ended up being nauseous a lot. Well, I wasn't working WITH the Chantix, I was expecting instant results without doing anything else but pop a pill.This time, I followed directions to a fault and I am so grateful that I did, and so are a lot of people who know me. I breathe better, I feel better, and I smell better (both in my nose and other people's noses).Thanks to my doctor and to Chantix for helping me accomplish what I considered an impossibility.

column2: eric in richmnd, va, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I've been smoking 1/2 to 3/4 pack a day for 20+ years.  I started Chantix on 12/7.  I reached my quit date on 12/15, and still had the desire to smoke.  The first few days were tough, I didn't smoke the first two days, but slipped up on day three.  I've had two smoke free days since then and the urges are still there, but lessening.Overall have been satisfied.  I haven't had any major side effects.  I've made sure to take it directly after meals and with a full glass of water, so no stomach issues.  I do remember more of my dreams, which I actually enjoy.So far so good.  I'm hoping to reach the point others have -- where I have no remaining desire to smoke.  I still have urges, but I feel can manage them.  I would suggest anyone considering to quit, consider this drug, of course weighing some of the potential side effects as well.

column2: UncleAl, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This is a follow-up from an earlier review dated 4/22/2009. After 9 years of smoking, 4/9/2009 was my last cigarette. I have not had another since. I feel better than I have ever felt in my whole life. What an awakening, and all thanks to the assistance provided by Chantix. My total time on the medication was a mere 8 weeks. The side effects were minimal and were worth every second. The results now, 8 months down the road, are proof that there is truly nothing pleasurable about smoking. You aren't even aware of the life you're missing out on until you quit. With the right frame of mind and the assurance that a life without cigarettes is not scary or miserable but a healthier, more positive life without chains, you too can quit successfully with the help of Chantix. Good luck!

column2: CrumpJ, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I took Chantix for 8 wks,Quit smoking on my sixth day, and during The first five weeks I had no side effects other than vivid dreams, and a little sickness if I didnt take it with food.Into the last 3 weeks I started to have small bouts of sickness everytime I took it, with food or not, I just put up with it as it would pass after about 10 or 15 minutes. So in the middle of the eighth wk I decided to split my last four days of pills into 8 taking one a day till they were gone. I smoked for 23 years, I tried every over the counter product you can buy, but with chantix I quit in 6 days - fact. All I really had to deal with was a little sickness and some cool dreams.  I have been off chantix for over a week and feel great. You still have your moments - Food, Attitudes, Boredome, etc but they all pass easily if you try. The real funny thing for me is I wasn't a beleiver from gate, So thanx Chantix for proving me wrong.

column2: Kat, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: It has helped me quit smoking, however, the side effects are horrible. I took Chantix for 8 weeks then had to quit because of nausea and severe itching (hives) which I still have after 2 mo. and numerous doctor visits and prescriptions which give me no relief.

column2: JM, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I am bipolar, so I was very leery about taking Chantix. But I've smoked 2 packs a day for over 25 years and enough was enough. Under my psychiatrist's care, I started Chantix and I quit smoking. It was a breeze compared to all previous efforts to quit.  The only side effect were vivid, but entertaining dreams. Yes, I still have cravings (more habit/situational) but they pass and they are few and far between. One thing: Don't quit the pills abruptly. That was when I had emotional problems. Under my doctors supervision, I had to buy another month and slowly taper off over a 2 month period. Chantix should put out a last month package. My experience was good. I think it is for most people, since the people who have bad experiences are more likely to post in this forum than people who have good experiences. That said, listen to your mind and your body and only do this under the care of a doctor who knows you well with support from your friends and family.

column2: 2Packs, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Been on Chantix almost 8 weeks. Been smoke free 24 days. Side affects are upset stomach unless I eat something. I feel somewhat depressed from time to time. Sleep habits are screwed up. There has been no nicotine withdraw at all and the cravings are mild. The drug is much better than I thought. I didn't think anything was going to cure my 40 years of smoking and I was up to 2 packs a day. I intend to use the Chantix for 6 months. I am disappointed that I feel no better since I quit smoking. I guess it takes months or years for your lungs to get better.

column2: Male  (Caregiver)
55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I STOPPED SMOKING AFTER 6 WEEKS. I HAVE BEEN OFF OF CHANTIX FOR 6 WEEKS. THE BAD SMELL IN MY NOSE , THE BAD TASTE IN MY MOUTH , THE MORNING SORE THROATS , AND THE VERY BAD BODY ODER ARE ALL COMING FROM CHANTIX .

column2: blonddove1, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I was able to stop smoking using Chantix but thought I had lower back trouble but after MRI it is my kidneys that are bothering me.

column2: ex-smoker, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I recently finished 3 months of Chantix. It works and I'm very pleased. I read all the bad reviews and was reluctant to take it. The only side effect I had was "vivid dreams", which for me meant remembering all the details when I awoke.Not a bad thing at all. I also made a point of getting something solid on my stomach before taking in the morning. Don't just eat a cracker and a swig of water!! I would eat something like an English muffin with peanut butter on it. Also drink a full 8oz. of water.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I started taking Chantix on a Friday and by Tuesday, I was sleeping 12-15 hours a night/day, crying on and off throughout the day and having feelings of worthlessness.  Since I had such a strong reaction to the medication, I stopped taking it.  I am Bipolar and have been on the right mix of medication to balance it, but since taking the Chantix, I feel even more depressed than I did before the Bipolar meds.  Chantix did not help me quit smoking.  If you have any history of depression or are Bipolar, please, please think twice about taking this drug...the side effects are nasty.  Ask you doctor if this med is okay for you to take and talk to your doctor immediately if you have any of the above signs.

column2: Littlerin007, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This is my 3rd time taking it in 4 years. I works. You will not smoke. However I have never been able to take it for more than 3 weeks because the side effects. I was fired from my job for acting angry toward a customer. THis anger was a side effect of the Chantix. I won unemployment in court beause I had no previous complaints in 2 years and had a note from my psychiatrist saying the medication made me so incredible angry. It makes me very irratable, angry, mad, and negative. I also suffer unbelivable headaches and my jaw hurts. I am bipolar and have never felt any suicidal thoughts or changes in my moods except the anger. I do not want to smoke while on the medication and I does truely work. As long as you can put up with the side effects, it will probably save your life.

column2: betterforyou, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Tapered off mysmoking the first week and have not had any urges to smoke except when I had a couple beers I made it through with support. no real side effects

column2: Momwithfreckles, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: The side effects are bad for me.  Depression and mood swings are what is making this hard.  I yell, scream and feel like no one cares.  I also did not stop completly but I have cut down to 2 a day.  Stopping the medication as I am writing this.

column2: Vinnie, 45-54 Female  (Patient)
column9: Wasn't really sure it would work for me. This is my 2nd time trying to quit from being a 23yr smoker (I'm 53). The 1st was with the patch but didn't work. Started Chantix Nov 3 and cut down smoking signicantly 4-5 cig/daily (1/2 at a time) and was only able to finally quit Nov 23 without even realizing that I didn't think about smoking for the whole day.  Today, it is 8 day without smokes now and all is going so well.  My heart wasn't completely 100% quit in the beginning of the Chantix, I just did it as an experiment and it really worked wonders. I forgot to mention that I smoked 10-12 cig/daily consistently.  I thought Thanksgiving was going to be a struggle and really a test for me and I came thru with hardly any cravings and do feel great (I'm so surprised at this too). My lung capacity is so much better that I can run/jog for 15-20mins withou stopping.  In the past I could only run/jog for only 3-5mins.  The 1st week I was nauseaus in the AM, but now I'm doing great. I even take it without a meal (not a breakfast person). I take the 10mg in the AM and only .5mg at about 4-5PM.  Don't really want the dreams to keep me awake. The cravings are minimal. I know it's only 8 days not smoking and will give an update each week or 2.

column2: Lorenzo, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: A little trouble sleeping, also dry spots on my hands.

column2: 2packs, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: After one month of Chantix I still had the urge to smoke but ran out of cigarettes and was determined NOT to buy anymore. This is the end of week 5 and my 6th day without a cigarette. I'm doing much better than I thought I would. So the Chantix must be having some affect. I get through the days much easier than I thought I would. Cravings and urges are not bad at all. My plan now is to continue the Chantix for 6 months. Side affects are not bad. The worse for me is taking it without food. After smoking for 40 years since I was a 14 I'm pretty convinced my smoking days are over. I'll check in again. Plus I also have been taking antidepressants for 25 years and there has been no problems taking Chantix.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I guess I am one of the lucky ones who has limited side affects.  Mine have been mainly "irregularity" and some nausea, but only if I forget and take it on an empty stomach.Bottom line so far is it has worked.  I took for 1 week and reached my quit date.  I still had a strong urge to smoke but thought "I have paid for the Chantix and am taking it.  I may as well try and see if I can make it until lunch."  I have not had a smoke yet and it has been 17 days.  The best way for me to describe it is it brings the obcession and the cravings down.  There have been times that I have thought about it but it has never gotten so out of control that I drive to the gas station to buy a pack.  The best part is that I know know that I can make it through a day, my job, my life without a cig.  If I smoke tomorrow, it is not because I need it.  It is because I choose it.  I meet with my doctor next week to make a decision on wheter I go on to month 2 or ween off of it.  Friends ask about it and I hesitate to recomment id because I know there are people who have had very bad side affects.  Some of the stories I read on the blogs almost kept me from trying it but I am glad I did.  It has worked out very well for me.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am on my 8th day of chantix, today is my quit day, I'm very excited.  I really haven't had any side effects.  If you take the medication as instructed you can avoid alot of the side effects.  I take at 6:30/7 then take again at 2:30.  I'm sleeping fine.  If you're a smoker you should try.  I've been a smoker for 30 years and it's time.

column2: nomoresmoke, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Best thing that has ever come along!  Stopped smoking within 7 days because they taste stale and it feels like I just don't need them anymore.  Have been smoke free for 8 months.  Stayed on the Chantix for about a month.  Side effects were minimal for me.

column2: GrYpHoNN, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Works but with  brutal side effects

column2: Robert, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I stopped smoking after day 7.  No cravings. All desire to smoke gone by day 21.  Only effect wierd dreams waking you up.

column2: Hokiegrl, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I took Chantix for 4 weeks, I stopped smoking & stopped taking the Chantix.. Since stopping I have had severe joint pain, hair loss, and extreme mood changes. Please be cautious of this med. I DO NOT suggest this to anyone.

column2: EVAN, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: THIS MEDICATION IS A GOD SEND!!! i HAVE TRIED EVERYTHING, AND NOTHING WORKS LIKE CHANTIX! AS LONG AS YOU ARE AWARE OF THE SIDE EFFECTS YOU SOULD BE OK. I HAVE A PSYCHIATRIST SO THE WHOLE DEPRESSION THING WAS ADDRESSED WITH SIMPLE ZOLOFT ADDITION TO THIS PILL!

column2: sheree, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Chantix should be taken off the market. After starting chantix 10 weeks ago and quitting it 2 weeks ago, I'm smoke free for 8 weeks now. I'm also a mental mess. At 51 and actually very healthy and fit, I have never experienced anything like this before. Alternating bouts of severe anger and depression ranging to hyperactive giddiness. My symptoms have steadily gotten worse since stopping the chantix. I have NO history of depression. I am under a Dr.'s care, waiting on test results now after actually beating on my husband. I got that angry because he went to use the bathroom. I have NEVER had a temper issue, and I am scaring myself. This doesn't even take into account the horrible nightmares (first few weeks were just vivid but good dreams) heart palpitations, nausea, gerd, gas, constipation, confusion, memory loss, insomnia, aches and pains, restlesness. Please, think long and hard, do a lot of research, and think long and hard again before taking chantix. Don't assume it'll be ok for you, just because a Dr. is willing to prescribe it. It is your body, your mind, and your health. I truly regret ever taking it, and would not suggest it to anyone.

column2: ROOKIE, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Hello , this medication is very harmful to i would sy to some people. It may work for some,but i would definatley take a look at the side affects,it makes you irratable,can make you mean,cloud your judgement,very sad,depressed,and thoughts of suicide.Dont take this medication without checking out the side affects.also if you do choose to be aware of your behavior or any changes in your mood ,or feelings.ONLY ON THIS JUNK FOR 7 DAYS .

column2: melanie, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I never thought s simple pill would help me quit but it did! The first two weeks were kind of hard but after that I didn't even want to smoke. Fast forward 14 months and I'm a non-smoker! YES!  I did have some side effects, vivid dreams and feeling aggressive so ended up taking Chantrix for only 6 weeks but that was enough. This was my chance to be free from the smoking demon and I won! (I smoked 2packs a day for 30 years)

column2: 2packs, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Just finishing day 16. Haven't cut back at all. Cravings are still there. No strange dreams. A little bit of upset stomach if you take it without food. My antidepressant medication may be preventing Chantix from working. Going to continue with the Chantix.

column2: crumpj, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I didn't want to be so easy when it came to rating this medication, but there is no doubt its just shy of a miracle. I am beginning my 4th week pak and have been cigerette free for 16 days, the first 10 days i went by the book and suffered no side effects except very cool dreams ( no Nightmares). During the last 6 days my schedule has made me take my pills at slightly different hours and still no major side effects except dreaming. It seems if you take chantix without food you'll feel a little sick, but only for 10/20 minutes and the other catch for me was even though I have been trying to watch what I eat I still gained a few pounds. Chantix is my recomendation to anybody who wants to quit leteraly pain free, and I have tried most all of the other methods to know.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Fantastic,maybe Doctors should do exams,instead of calling the meds.in.I think Doctors should see their patients and talk to them,even herbs can change medication resultsGO TO THE DOCTOR>

column2: optimistic, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month
column9: Have been on this for about 10 days. No side effects and I have reduced my consumption of cigarettes from 2 packs to 3 or 4 cigs a day with zero effort. I just dont feel like I need them. I am hoping this will continue to work.

column2: thunbergia, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: horrible!  Increased GERD, Insomnia, nausea, headaches and mean as a snake

column2: 2packs, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Just finished my 10th day on Chantix. No change at all in smoking. Don't notice any side affects. It should have started working by now. Starting to get discouraged. Afraid my antidepressant medication is interfering with the Chantix. I'll continue to take the Chantix and give another update.

column2: noname, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had a horrible cough for 3 months...could not get rid of..scared me..have taken chantix for 6 weeks..and smoke free..cut back to half dose a day for the last 2 weeks.now stopping..having light headed feelings..but that is all..i have been smoking for over 40 yrs...and this stuff works if you are serious about quitting..i have never felt better...

column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am a military member.  I smoked when I woke, ate, and slept, and every moment in between.  I married a woman who smoked, and our life was scheduled around smoking.  We recently decided to attempt pregnancy.  Our first step was to quit smoking.  The base where I am stationed offered a smoking cessation program with Chantix.  They provided every side effect up front and released the medication the first day.  We smoked for the first week, the first pack of Chantix.  By day four, cigarettes were tasting stale and cravings were minimal.  We were able to quit on day seven.  Irritablility, increased dreaming, and nausea are our primary side effects.  All are worth quitting smoking.

column2: crumpj2322, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I thought it was going to be a rough ride, but I have just finished my first seven days without a cigerette. I have not had any sickness, insomnia, or nightmares and the dreams i have had were pretty entertaining to say the least. I have tried everything to quit prior to chantix, its really a true solution - just fallow the instructions to the T.

column2: 2packs, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Don't let this rating mislead you. I've just finished my 6th day. No side affects as of yet. Also there has been no change in my addiction so the drug hasn't started working yet. I smoke 2 packs a day and have been smoking for 40 years. I have tried the other things on the market with no luck. I am hoping this will work. I also have been on antidepressants for 23 years after having severe depression. So this drug is of great concern to me. I plan on making several posts on my progress.

column2: teskay, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been taking this for 8 days now and have dramatically cut down on smoking. I am no longer smoking almost a pack a day but am down to about 3 a day. I only notice the nausea of if i don't have enought ot eat before I take it. But I definately have been having unusal vivid dreams to the point that I wake my husband up. It's kind of drifted off the last 2 days though.

column2: mike, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am on day 13 of chantix & my 6th day of being smoke free after 35 years @ 1 1/2 packs per day.this drug did scare me a bit do to all the side effects that are possible , however I have not had any so far. so if tou are serious about quiting I would say see your doctor and give it a try .

column2: Crumpj2322, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Ok, i have completed the first week, taking one pill at 8am and 1 at 5-6pm. I had  realy clear unusual vivid dreams for the first three days and unusual but normal the rest. I couldnt really tell if it was helping or not helping, only that by the end of the week i was smoking less, but that also could be because I am a little more self aware at the moment. I was instructed to pick a quit date 7 days from the start of my program and smoke till then, but on the morning of the sixth i ran out of cigeretts, so i just stopped. what I hav noticed in the last day and a half without cigeretts is im not really having any withdraw symptoms just lots of habits. I find myself ending up at the spot i would always smoke for no reason, also when the habit arises to go to that spot and i circumvent the urge I end up in the kitchen. my point is there is a difference, but you still have to fight the habit, if that makes sense.(will write again in a week)

column2: Crumpj2322, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am into day 5 of using Chantix, very vivid and unusual dreams, but no real effect other than that.

column2: zanesgirl, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been taking chantix for 2 weeks and I have almost completely stopped smoking.  It does make me very irritableand short tempered, but no suicidal houghts or bad dreams.

column2: JC1982, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am on day three of taking chantix and really I have only a few side effects one of them being nauseated but only for a few minutes. I have cut back from 2 packs a day to 1 and its only the third day. I have noticed that I have trouble waking up in the morning and some stomach issues but nothing that has stopped me from continuing on Chantix.

column2: nita, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I quit smoking after one week of starting Chantix.  It really made quiting seem easy.  Immediately, I had very strange vivid dreams but they didn't seem to interupt my sleep much.  During the 3rd week of taking Chantix, I began to have severe abdominal pains and nausea after taking Chantix, even when I ate.  So bad, that I decided to take a break.  I discontinued taking the drug on day 5 of the 3rd week.  After about 3 days of discontinued use, I became very irritable - almost unbearable to live with.  I don't know if I should take any more of my perscription or not.  I want to stay stopped, but I don't want to have these weird withrawls again...

column2: tj, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I smoked for 48 years up to two packs a day when I tried chantix.  I had no problems with its use and have been smoke free for a year now.  I may have been the exception but I had on side effects.  My biggest problem was finding a use for my hands not holding a cigerette.

column2: ashlie6963@yahoo.com, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: I have not started yet, just received the medication

column2: jjanicet@yahoo.com, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: insurance will not help--is there any resources foe this

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been smoke free for 8 months. The side effects were minimal, and well worth it.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: i suffered insomnia, intense anger.

column2: lisaneptunes, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am a smoker. I have been smoking for 6 1/2 years (started late). When I began smoking it was social, gradually working up to 2 packs a day. I am now on my 6th day using Chantix. My desire to smoke has lessened throughout the day. I am still struggling with my problem areas which are in the morning when I tend to smoke the most, & at night while relaxing. The taste is getting worse by the day, slightly metallic. I seem to be smoking more out of habit than enjoyment at this point. I have had some of the stated side effects... very vivid dreams, and feeling disoriented & not well rested for quite some time after waking up. I have not felt any nausea, aggitation or depression thus far. Hopefully I will be smoke free by the 8th day. I will keep everyone posted on my journey!

column2: tally, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: best thing out on the market for quitting smoking.

column2: straw578, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I took this medication in july 08 and it is now sept09 i am experiencing horrible side effects still i get really anxious to the point of passing out ,always fatigued ,my body aches all the time and i have chest pains and my back of my head is always feeling like it is crawling .I would not recommend this medication to any one !!! I have just discoved why I am feeling this way after a year of being tested by my dr for everything you could imagine .Now I am heading back to the dr with reviews to show her why I am feeling this way .It is the most horrible thing I have every been thorough .

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: had some wild dreams but it made quitting almost too easy after smoking for 36 yrs

column2: KatyInLasVegas, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: For quitting smoking Chantix has worked for me. Not only has it let me quit smoking completely but the smell of cigarettes has changed which helped me to not smoke during visits with smoking family members. The biggest thing is that I didn't really want to quit but HAD to quit and it still worked out for me. I'd recommend this to anyone.As far as side effects, the dreams have not been bad for me. I just tend to remember them more than I used to and they're slightly crazy but nothing along the lines of nightmares or strange. Also, from time to time I get a crazy stomach ache when taking my pill. Not enough to throw up but it's not great. And the last thing, dry skin is a very rare side effect and it's all over my face. My skin has become very dry and scaly everywhere but it is at its worst on my face. And for that reason, I cannot wait to finish taking Chantix and be done. There isn't enough lotion to get my face looking and feeling normal again.

column2: lydwnsal, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I am a 43 yr old female who smoked for over 20 years - the exact age & smoking history of the test subjects. I smoked my last cigarette on the 26th day after starting Chantix.  The urge to smoke subsides quickly although it does reoccur from time to time but it is easily discarded. The dreams are really wild and vivid, luckily no nightmares. Just finished my 4th month and have been smoke free for 3 months which I never thought would be possible. Started noticing during this last month that the side effects (especially the hostility and emotions) have really intensified. I have become very easily agitated by issues that I deal with daily at my job and I LOVE MY JOB! My doctor wanted me to take it for 9 months but I said no way would I live through 5 more months of this! Not suicidal at all but have thought about whacking a few OTHER people! I will begin the weaning process this coming week and pray that the side effects go away.  I would recommend this medication for some people but do not believe that it will help everyone due to the side effects. If you DO decide to take it, listen to your body and mind because you know it better than anyone. The nausea can be curbed by taking it after a meal and with a FULL 8oz of WATER. THEY ARE NOT KIDDING ABOUT THE FULL GLASS OF WATER! It still made me feel a little nauseated but it subsides quickly if you just give it a chance. This medicine really works if your body AND mind can handle it.

column2: josieaka, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had my last smoke on June 22, think I was about three weeks into the Chantix. I stopped the pill when I had ten days left due to nausea. Very happy, had tried and failed to stop several times, smoked for over 41 years. I also started walking and only gained 6 pounds, did get the vivid dreams but they will stop. Feel so much better, did not think that it would work.

column2: Tena, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I quit because of Chantix and the program that came with it. The drug reduced my cravings and the website and emails were packed with encouragement. It is tough, but it was doable.

column2: ChantixMakesMeSleepAllDay, 13-18 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I started Chantix a little over three weeks ago. The first week was just fine. I smoked my cigarettes during the first week like my doctor instructed me so the medicine would "build up" in my brian. In the middle of the second week I started to get insomnia really bad. I coulndt go to sleep untill about 7 or 8 in the morning. All I would do is sleep all day 'till about 5pm. Luckly its still summer or I would miss school. Ive been smoke-free for almost 2 weeks. It works for me but I dont think that I can handle sleeping all day. I want to sleep at night and I'am considering getting some ambien. I would remcomend this product but only to people who can handle the horrid side effects that come along with it.

column2: B Blake, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Started April 16th, 2009.  Started to feel a loss of cig desire VERY soon thereafter. To date I seldom do I even feel the urge! Only side effect I had were dreams...SOME NIGHTMARES (as usual) MAINLY VIVID FROM MY HIGH SCHOOL DAYS, CHILDHOOD, ETC. I ACTUALLY LIKED THEM!!Sorry to hear some people had a bad experience. Maybe some latent pre-existing condition exercised by Chantix is the cause?

column2: Franky, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: your sleep is not very rest full. you go throught a time where you feel at your wits end. I only took it for one and a half months.

column2: NDgirl, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I just started my 2nd week of Chantix.  Smokes taste like metal.  Have some gas and feel tired all the time.  Could sleep 12+ hours a day and have very vivid dreams.  All I have read about side effects is making me nervous...  One positive side effect I have had- beer no longer even SOUNDS good! lol

column2: Texas67, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I started taking chantix in Aug/07' for about a month and it worked really well but in Sept/07' i started being extremely thristy and urinating alot, i went to my Dr. and they tested my sugar level and it was really high he started me on insulin pills, after testing myself a few times a day with taking the insulin pills it wasnt going down i told my Dr. and he put me on insulin shots twice a day(it was horrible bcause i dont like needles or the feeling when a persons sugar levels get low after an insulin shot). During the same time i became very depressed so he started me on depression medicine(which i'm still on). So sometime around March/April of 2008 my Dr. tested my sugar and it was normal(like i never had diabetes so i know that it was from this med) and he stopped me from taking insulin but i have to test myself 3 times a week to make sure. But if i'd known that i'd get diabetes i wouldnt of taken it and its not a warning on the medicines commercial and labeling. So be careful!

column2: okgirl, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have smoked a pack a day at least for exactly 20 years. I finished my chantix yesterday and  haven't smoked a cigarette in 11 weeks! My Mom quit smoking with chantix as well. If you really want to quit chantix will help you do it.

column2: Ann, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I tried Chantix for months last year. Two months was all I could stand the constant nausea, given that I was no closer to stopping smoking than I had been to begin with. I'm bipolar, accustomed to a variety of psych symptoms, so tend to blow them off now, at my "advanced" age. Plus, at that time, I was nursing hubby back from injuries from a serious car accident. So I don't remember anything other than nonstop nausea and no help quitting smoking. 3 packs a day for 35 years. I felt like it was my last hope.

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Great dreams no nightmares. A little nausea for about 10 minutes thats all. I might have to take ritalin again though I just cannot concentrate on anything. Us ADD people need our stimulants.

column2: susan, 45-54 Female  (Patient)
column9: It worked,never had any side effects what so ever, then starting to go down to 1 pill a day that's when the problems started I started having severe neurolgy problems all the sudden and quick, could not walk (legs felt like jello) double vision basically all that were around me thought I was having a stoke or seizure,could not speak righ at all this went on for 3 hrs (was taken to hosptal by ambulance) the doctors informed me they have seen such adverse reactions to chantix at all different phases of patients taking chantix. It was not always at the beginning or middle or even end of taking chantix. Thank god I do not smoke anymore, I would rather go back to smoking then see my life pass in front of my eyes!!! I pray to god NO ONE ever has to go through this side effect...you will truly believe that you are at the end of your life!!! Only on chantix for 3 months!!

column2: brown bear, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was not a heavy smoker but definitely had dependency for about 10 years.  I took Chantix for 3 weeks (at half dose - I'm about 100 lbs and had alot of nausea at normal dose) and have successfully weaned myself off.  I stopped after 3 weeks due to some increasing side effects - what was weird dreams in week one became crazy dreams and not sleeping more than 4 hours/ night later.  Same with anxiety, the gas/bloating, sadness... it was the equivalency of 3 weeks of intense PMS.  Not sure if related to the drug or just quitting but I am much better now that I am off of it.  I still have some dreaming, not crazy just vivid, but from other posts I expect this will go away shortly.  Good luck to you about to take it- just make sure you have a support system to watch out for any mood changes- if it weren't for my husband I would still be taking it and who knows how I would be!  To me, I was being normal, to everyone else I was being very strange.

column2: Arlene, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Like many others, hearing about the side-effects terrified me. But, the only side-effect I encountered were really messed up terrifying dreams. I didn't feel depressed (no more than I did last time I tried quitting without Chantix anyway), and it definitely helped ease a HUGE amount of anxiety. It seriously made quitting practically EASY!! I was a little crabby here and there of course, but nothing like I was when I tried to quit without Chantix! lolI stopped smoking with Chantix on November 1, 2008 and only took it for 3 weeks (that's including the one week prior to quitting) and in the 3rd week I was only using half of the dosage (one pill in morning) to try and ease the crazy, terrifying dreams. Unfortunately the dreams remained even after I stopped taking Chantix altogether. But they dissipated more and more each night and only remained for maybe 7 days at the most after stopping Chantix. Totally worth it though because I am still smoke-free on August 18, 2009. I definitely wouldn't be this far along without it!  Oh, and the online support really helps to push you further and further too. So definitely register for that! They provide you with what to expect, and offer ways to cope and things you can try to ease the brief encounters of wanting a cigarette. Best thing I ever tried to kick the habit. Totally amazing stuff! THANK YOU Pfizer!

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: While I was nervous about all of the side effects I read about, I'm happy to say the only one has been vivid dreams - sometimes nightmares but also good dreams, just more intense. I'm a younger person than most of the reviewers here but have smoked about a pack a day for 10 years. I've quit off and on before but always restarted after a few months. I've tried cold turkey, counseling, patches and the gum. I'm happy to report no cigarettes and SEVERELY reduced cravings after 4 weeks on Chantix. Of course when I want one I still want one, but I found that after the first week I don't think about cigarettes for hours at a time. This was inconceivable before and certainly never happened while on the patches or the gum. I can still have a few beers or cocktails, no upset stomach, and while I have had depressive tendancies before, I've experienced nothing like the violent mood swings or other issues others have reported. The pill itself is small, easy to remember to take, and very very effective for me. It's completely worth the cost and I wish I tried it sooner. Good Luck!!

column2: jerrymartint, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have been taking chantix for 8 months, started with 1/2 mg am and 1/2 pm then 1 mg am and 1 mg pm now at 1mg per day with no side effects whatsoever. I smoked 55 years nothing worked until now, I am happy as a lark to be done smoking.

column2: Briggs, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have been smoke free for 6 months after 35 years of smoking this I attribute to Chantix. But I would never recommend this drug to anyone. I am now on anti depressants and anxiety medication and in counseling for anxiety and panic attacks. I am unable to work at this time and am unsure if I will be able to return to my job.

column2: frankiekisses, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This medication helps me alot although when I go off of it I tend to start eating more and if I have a drink I tell myself it is ok to have one smoke.I need to have a little more self discipline.All in all it helps alot .I do only take one pill for about a month and then go off of it all together, not reccommended unless your will is strong but I figure the nicotine should be out of my system by then and don't like to be on drugs.

column2: missouri, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: significant stomach upset and panic dreams on full dose so decreased to one half tab before i gave up.  i was able to still quit smoking in 12 weeks with minimal g i problems and just stressful dreams and i had smoked every day for 43 years.

column2: thumper, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was a 2.5 pack a day smoker for more than 30 years,in just over two weeks on chantix I was able to stop smoking. Smoke free for over a month now, no signifigant urges either.Now for the down side,,,If you are at all a aggressive/hostle personality or moody and/or depressive, be very careful while on this drug,Very glad to be smoke free,but if I had to do it again,,I would try cold turkey,not chantix.

column2: David, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I had to quit taking Chantix after the second day (one 1/2 mg tablet).  It made me feel horrible (sore, exhausted), irritable, and it gave me hours and hours of headaches.  I don't know how to describe the horrible feeling, it's kind of like if you breathe too much bug spray.  I was not nauseated or sleepy from it, and I did not take it long enough to have vivid dreams.  I did have to pee a lot, including during the night.  To be fair, I am sensitive to medications and I take other meds for fibromyalgia which may have affected the way Chantix made me feel: Lyrica, Buspar, ibuprofen.  If you are otherwise in good health, these things might not be an issue.  If you start taking it, I'd recommend starting on a non-working day in case you get similar effects.

column2: buzz, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: strange Dreams but no cigarettes in 6 months after 50 years of smoking

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Began to lose desire to finish cigs within 4 days of the first week.  After stopping have had a couple of minor urges, but no cravings.  Smoke free for 6 months plus with no indications of relapse.

column2: 25-34 Female
column9: Chantix has been absolutely wonderful for me. I have smoked for about 18 years (a pack a day) The first day I had to quit I thought it was going to be difficult. It was very easy. Almost as if I never smoked a day in my life. WOW. I love Chantix. I found the drug to be very effective and have had no issues. The dreams are vivid but I love them!!!!! My stomach hurts after taking them but it makes me feel full and not hungry so I dont have much of a appetite so have actually lost alot of weight because of it as well. Overall, I love this drug and would highly recommend it to everyone.

column2: jenn, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: PEOPLE WITH ANXIETY DISORDERS, PLEASE READ THIS! i have been smoke free for over 2 months thanks to chantix! Letting go of cigarettes was very easy, even after smoking for 13 years. i experienced some side effects, headaches nausea, vivid dreams. The nausea and headaches were not bad and were gone after two weeks. The vivid dreams are my main complaint. i have had several dreams while on this medication, in which i believe i'm experiencing real life and wake up, only to find out after waking a second time that it was a dream within a dream mimicking real life.  VERY disturbing when it's a nightmare! I've had two vivid nightmares that i'm blaming on chantix. (i've never had so many dreams in such a short time frame, until taking this med). I have a history of severe panic attacks, and depression. though quitting on chantix  has been an emotional roller coaster ride, i have not experienced any attacks or bouts of depression. Just a few really bad days. Though i think the cause for the bad moods is really lack of nicotine, and having to learn new behaviors to cope with stress rather than the medication itself. if you have a anxiety disorder, don't be afraid to take this medicine. It's worth a few bad days and weird dreams to be smoke free and healthy.
