If you have understanding family and friends supporting you through the ups and downs of quitting, you can't lose! tell them you might be a pain to deal with for a week or two but it's not permanent, you'll be back to your old self in no time! Good Luck!

column2: Geno, 45-54 on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Was on Chantix for 3 months beginning Feb 07.  I did manage to quit with the help of this med.  I wanted to quit as well.  I didn't think I would ever quit until this med came to the market.  I smoked for nearly 30 years and enjoyed it immensely (or so I thought).  My experience with this med was good and bad, some aggression and weird dreams, vivid dreams of smoking.  That could be nicotine depravation though, who knows really.  If you decide to try this, do give it a chance to work, I was on for 3 months.  After 2 months, I thought I didn't need it any longer, but opted for another month and GRADUALLY came down from this med .. this I recommend greatly.  Don't just taking this med overnight, come off of it like you started, this I urge.  Good Luck..you can do it, if I can anyone can.

column2: karentranch, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I read some horror stories, so I decided to add excercise to my quitting process. I think that might be the key for me. I am not having any side effects at all. I love my new life without smoking!

column2: Jade, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I took Chantix for 7 weeks and have been smoke free for 2 months now. Unfortunatly I experienced some of the issues with anxiety, depression and suicidal thoughts that others have. Even though this medication does what it's intended to do; those 7 weeks were the scariest of my life. I was terrified to leave the house and thought people were watching me constantly. Even when I thought it might be the medication, I didn't want to stop taking it because it was working- I wasn't smoking and it was so dang expensive I didn't want to waste what I had left of it.  One day I had a panic attack and out of no where I thought of killing myself. I knew this was completly out of my character and immediatly (though somewhat begrudgingly) threw out the rest of the medication. I've been recovering and so far only have very slight anxiety since taking Chantix. However the experience that I had is always in the back of my head.  BE CAREFUL ON THIS MED. It seems like 50% of people who take it are ok and the other 50% have this very serious reaction (among other things- the gas was almost unbearable-ugh!). If you have any predisposition to depression, anxiety, bipolar-DO NOT TAKE THIS DRUG.  The scariest feeling in the world is knowing that your brain isn't functioning right and that there's nothing you can do about it. But to those who have had this reaction, just know that there is hope and the side effects were not permanent. I'm back at my job now and functioning normally again. But it was one hell of a journey to quit smoking with Chantix.

column2: Mrsarcazim, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been taking this for almost 6 weeks now.  I only wish that I knew that the good sensation that most of us enjoy was going to stop after a few days on the pill.  So make sure to get those last few smokes in before taking Chantrix.  Even though you continue to smoke for a week after starting the pill, the cigarettes stop doing what they normally do and are a bit strange.  I was able to go down to one a day after 5 weeks to conserve and also the mental desire is still there to smoke (no one really talks about this too much).  The physical need went away in week 3.  I have had no side effects from using Chantrix and definitly recommend this to others.  This was my first try to quit and so far so good.

column2: shayboo, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been on this medicine for almost a month and it does have some bad side effects. I have experienced vivid nightmares that sometimes continue even after I wake up and go back to sleep-which by the way is evasive on this medication. I have lost a few pounds because I forget to eat. I no longer feel the urge to smoke-I don't feel the urge to do much at all...the medication is doing its job but it sucks the world of color.

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was going through 1 to 2 cans of smokeless tobacco a day and after taking chantix for 2 weeks I have all but quit altogether. I have had only some side effects which is head pain, but I take a couple of advil and it goes away. overall anyone who is wanting to give up any kind of tobacco whether it be smoking or smokeless i would highly recommend giving this a try.

column2: happy, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I took this drug for six weeks although I was supposed to take it for 8 weeks, the nausea bothered me a bit.  I have smoked in 5 months, and I was a pack a day smoker for 20 years.  This drug really has made it alot easier for me to quit smoking, I recommend it to anyone who has tried smoking on there own found it too difficult.Thank god for modern medicine !!!

column2: Blessed, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Please Read this!!! I wanted to quit smoking and started taking Chantix. It worked well and did what it was supposed to do. BUT after 2 months I had a panick attack out of the blue that was so severe I went to the hospital. I found out that it is an antipsychotic and people who are prone to depression, worry and anxiety should steer clear. I still had the newly developed "panic disorder" moths after quitting the drug. It has been a year and with the Good Lords help I am attack free. However, I still have problems with insomia which started then. I am a totally different person now too. I no longer enjoy the things I used to. I would watch your mood and how it changes on this drug. Even though the drug is long gone out of my system I am forever scarred. I had to have CBT therapy which really helped. I now know my brain and chemical makeup cannot tolerate alteration by these types of drugs. Im doing well now and am very much closer to God.

column2: tolly, 55-64 Female  (Patient)
column9: Chantix is a dangerous drug like so many others on the market. column2: brandomonkey, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had given up on the idea of quitting smoking - nothing had worked for me and I tried everything.  A friend had been successful with Chantix and I decided to try it since I had nothing left to lose.  I have had NO problems with Chantix.  The nausea can be easily avoided as long as you take it with food.  The dreams are vibrant but not unpleasant.  The best part is NOT SMOKING.  So far it's been 7 weeks.  This doesn't make quitting perfect, you will still have your moments and urges, but those pass quickly.  The first week was the hardest, but it was quite bearable.  Since I've never actually made it a full week before Chantix, this was quite tolerable!  I know the warnings all sound scary, but if you really want to quit, discuss it with your doctor.  The majority of people do just fine on it!

column2: Leave this crap alone!, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: If I knew then what I know now.......I quit smoking but the side effects were NOT worth it. If you have anxiety issues DO NOT TAKE THIS DRUG!!!! I have always had bad anxiety. This medication makes it worse! I was irritable and reclusive. I didn't sleep well because of the vivid dreams. Long story short- I stopped taking this crap yesterday. I feel a lot better today. My anxiety got so bad I had to be put on Klonopin to calm me down. Unfreakin believable! Chantix made it seem like Prozac didn't work. I'll never take this again. Look up stories on chantix on the web.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I'm on day 9 of the starter pack. No nightmares, just a couple of crazy (fun) dreams. The urge to smoke is almost completely gone, and my general mood has improved drastically!

column2: Celulure, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I began Chantix 4/6/09, quit smoking on 4/13/09, and have not smoked since.  I stopped taking Chantix after about 6 weeks because of the side effects, primarily headaches, nausea, acid reflux, fatigue, some mental confusion & loss of concentration, agitation, agressive behavior, tightness in the chest, palpitations, weakness and tingling in the arms.The good news is Chantix has been 100% successful in my quest to be smoke free.  I smoked 2 packs/day for 45 years -if I can quit anyone can.The bad news is after quitting I feel now worse than when I was smoking as many side effects continue .  So far all tests have come back "normal" however these continued symptoms (they are now diminishing) are distressing.  I believe my error was to stop Chantix cold turkey.  I now realize that a weaning program should have been followed which wass not advised by either my doctor or pharmacist.  Chantix worked for me but please be aware of the side effects and utilize a weaning process when quitting the med.  Good Luck To All

column2: MisawaMarlboroMan, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Today is day 17 without tobacco (25 days on meds) and still completely smoke-free.  Had smoked steady for 30 years.  Read all the data and accounts I could find before asking my Doc for a prescription.  The potential side effects is very scary, but the only one that has stuck with me so far is the sleep stuff.  I dream like crazy, which makes it impossible to get any solid sleep.  I find that if I take a nighttime sleep aid every 5 or 6 days, I do get rest that night (I won't use a sleep aid more than that).  I changed up to a half-dose after the first 10 days of being cigarette free; that took care of any other lingering side effects.  I recommend it to any smoker, but only under a doctor's supervision, and only if you live with someone that can note any significant behavioral changes.

column2: ed, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Starting on my 3rd week of being smoke free using Chantix.  I had been a smoker for 22 years, at times almost 3 packs a day.  When I stopped I was down to 1 pack a day before taking this drug.  Had tried to quit seriously about 3 - 4 times in my life.  I am currently 47 years old and I feel good.  Taking this drug has caused me to have sleepless nights.  Before taking Chantix I was sleeping like a baby.  I am constipated like no other time in my life.  But, the side effects have yet lead me to quit taking the meds, so I guess they are not that bad yet.  I would not be sleeping good anyway if I quit cold turkey.  I don't seem to have the anxiety that I use to, but I don't seem to have the motivation to do many things as much as I used to.  I am tired all the time, either from the lack of sleep or not having any energy.  Because of these two things I don't want to work out as most of the time I can't even get up off the couch.  I am not sure if not wanting to be social is because of the meds or because I am just upset that I can't smoke again and I have not gotten over that yet.  I can't and don't want to smoke, so it is a catch 22.  The gum and the patch did not work for me, so here I am and I just want to get through this process so I can quit taking the meds and remain smoke free.  I know that the first puff will be my downfall and again, one day at a time.  I have to say, it amazes me I made it this far.  I WISH YOU THE BEST IN BECOMING SMOKE FREE TOO, if I can do it so can YOU!!!

column2: UncleAl, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I am a 24 y/o male, smoker for 9 years in good health otherwise, physical and mental. I just began week 5 yesterday and have had amazing results. Been smoking at least a pack and half per day for the last 3 years. By week 2 on Chantix, I was down to around 4-5 cigs per day. By week 3, I was completely cig-free and still am, not even one slip-up! I highly recommend this drug. It truly does curb cravings and prevent withdrawals 100%. You may experience side effects initially - slight drowsiness, nausea, changes in sleep, etc., as did I. I would definitely suggest eating a full meal right before taking the medication, and space your doses out evenly by 8-12 hour increments. I believe the idea is to keep a steady level of Chantix in your system to constantly curb the cravings. If you take them too close together, I believe you will have much stronger side effects. I keep seeing where people say they have all these terrible side effects from it, and obviously different people resond to meds differently. However, I had only mild side effects and they tapered off very quickly once my body adjusted to the medication. A word to the wise, if you are experiencing serious or bothersome side effects from any medication, you should always call your doctor and speak with him/her about the problem. A physician can properly tell you whether the benefits outweigh the risks in a case like this. Two thumbs up to Chantix, it has changed my life forever!

column2: PATSY, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I TOOK CHANTIX FOR 9 FULL MONTHS AND QUIT AFTER JUST A FEW WEEKS; STAYED ON IT SO I WOULD NOT RELAPSE. I HAD NO SIDE EFFECTS WHATSOEVER DURING OR AFTER ADMIN, AND IT'S BEEN 2 YEARS. I  LOVED THIS DRUG. DO NOT WANT A CIGARETTE AND WHEN I TRIED ONE LAST YEAR IT TASTED AWFUL. AFTER 35 YEARS OF SMOKING...I AM SO HAPPY I TOOK THIS DRUG.

column2: DECKS, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This is day 9 of being smoke free. This stuff is amazing! I did a lot of research on this drug and was terrified by all the side effects. I take it with food as everyone advised and I am fine. The dreams are ususally really amusing and can be remembered vividly upon waking. One thing I did as I am 125 pounds and can be sensitive to drugs is that I would break the starter pills in half and take part in the morning and the other in the evening. I did that for about at week. I am now taking the 1mg tablets but only in the morning and not at night. I feel that I am doing good right now, why risk it by taking the evening dose and getting side effects. Also, my meds will last me twice as long. I still have mild cravings but usually just when drinking alcohol which I am baby stepping back into. I can even go on my deck where I used to smoke and take the puppy out! I don't even think about it! I am feeling better everyday! I really enjoyed smoking and didn't want to quit but knew I needed to. So, this works even if you aren't into 100%. Come one, give it a try. Good luck to everyone!

column2: bbeehler, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I started taking Chantix 4/4/09, stopped smoking 4/11/09 and so far so good. I was  down to a couple a day and each day I decreased by at least 1/2 a cigarette a day until quit day. On the 1 mg I have seen an increase in the duration and strength of the nausea. I have not yakked yet which would be better than waiting for almost 2 hours for the feeling of wanting to yak to go away. I took it at 7:30 am and my tummy is still hard at 2pm. I read taking it with high protein meals is best and thinking about it, over the weekend I took it with eggs and it was not as bad as this morning (cereal)and milk helped some. I told my boyfriend to watch me just in case. I cannot wait to cross the finish line on my first triathlon this summer as a non smoker! Hoping the yakking feeling goes away or I get used to it fast!

column9: I developed a GI bleed from useing this drug.  I would never use this again.

column2: hopelessandhelpless, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I took Chantix for just over three weeks, while being treated for depression at the same time. This drug interacted with my anti-depressant in such a way rhat it seemed as though I wasn't even on it. The depression and agression became so severe that not only did it cost me the relationship I was in, but I am now being charged criminally for stalking. I dont recommend this drug to anyone for anything, haven't taken it for 4 weeks now and wonder if I can outlast the side effects. It is a horrible thing that something that is supposed to be helpful can destruy your life in a matter of weeks.

column2: No Smoking for Me!, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Checking back in, after over a year.  Still smoke free.  What a great way to live, never thought it was possible.  I agree with so many of the positive posters here, if you really want to quit, you can do it, and Chantix can help.  Don't read too much into other people's symptoms, each one of us is different, you may be the one that has success, as I and many others have.  I hope that others will see the benefits & hope that we have & use this.  This message board helps, it presents all aspects of what can occur, good & bad.  Good luck & keep trying, you can do this.  I'm living proof.  Smoke free for over 16 months, after 35 years of smoking.

column2: spunky, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I did great the first week, really cutting down. I did have some nausea and extreme constipation. The 2nd week, although I am already being treated for depression and  did have some stressful things going on in my life, I began experiencing tremendous anxiety and sleeping problems. By the beginning of the 3rd week I was in such a depressive state I felt suicidal and absolutely miserable! I felt like I was having a nervous breakdown and needed to be committed. Needless to say, my smoking had not decreased anymore. I stopped taking it before the 3rd week ended and within 3 days felt like a new person. I guess I will have to try something else and make up my mind to really do it. I had hoped Chantix would be my 'miracle'....

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had smoked for almost 20 yrs, thanks to Chantix I am no longer a smoker.  I only took the meds for one month, I know I should have taken it longer, but the lack of sleep from the dreams was awful!  Good luck to everyone, and never pick a cig up again. That is the key! It isn't worth it. I wanted to quit smoking so my husband and I could start trying to have children, so it was a really motivating reason to quit. Chantix is a great product, trust in it, keep taking it, and believe in yourself. You don't need those cigs to live, you will not die if you don't smoke, you could if you keep smoking.  Anyway, enjoy your Chantix journey, it is so worth it on the other side!

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: stop smoking couldn't have been easier

column2: healthnutnow, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Although I've only been taking it for 3 days, I can already tell that this is going to work for me! I've been a smoker on and off for about 20 years and the only other time I quit was for a surgery date (one year before). I'm on day 3 and I have only had 2 all day!

column2: tjm19, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: 40 years smoking. Two years smoke free since using Chantix. Only side effects were vivid dreams. I still think about smoking multiple times a day and know if I tried 1 I'd be back smoking. Putting 100+ miles a week on my bike where, when smoking could not climb 2 flights of stairs.

column2: liz, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I am on week 6 of taking this medication. but am still smoking about 5-6 a day.I have cut down from a pack a day....but am really struggling. On the other hand I don't want to give up...Did anyone else quit later on in the program??>...most seem to have quit in the first week or so....I am getting discouraged

column2: SmokeFreeInLasVegas, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am just getting ready to start my 2nd month of treatment. I was a smoker for 14 years. I lost the desire for a cigarette on my eighth day of the medication. Cravings have been there - but are gone as soon as they come on. I was extremely tired on this med each time my dosage increased but after 2 days on the highest dose, I am doing much better. I have had the constipation and gas. Nausea only if I didn't each first (so I make sure I eat first). I am having more dreams or just remembering them more...but they have all been good ones (like flying to Tahiti with a check for $1 million). I am a bit spacey at times and the 2nd and 3rd week - everyone got on my nerves...not so much any more. I also fall asleep fast at night now...no tossing and turning. These are all minor things to put up with in exchange for a smoke free life...(PS - today it was so windy that my hair blew in my face and it was wonderful to smell my hair...it didn't smell like cigarettes...it smelt like coconuts and mango)

column2: bella, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: thank you! thank you! if it was not for chantix i never would have been smoke free. i tell everyone if i can do it so can you. but im sad to say i may have to stop taking the meds because i have developed a rash almost looks like small chickenpox, i have yet to call dr's because i have  been trying to see if anyone else has had this type of reaction. i really dont want to stop taking this, i dont want to smoke. it has been 2 weeks since i have had the nicodemon in my system and i am hoping that the craving will not be bad after i stop taking this.. the vivid dreams are pretty fascinating though i always did have an imagination they have gotten better, something to look foward to at bed time, wondering what planet i will be on lol. thank you again and my lungs thank you.

column2: NOTNHIDING@YAHOO.COM, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I am 50 yrs old and have been smoking for over 30 yrs.  This is the only time I have quit that I feel like I have it under control.  My quit day was 2/28/09, up until 3/17/09 I smoked about 1/2 a cigarette a day, they tasted disgusting but I HAD to do it!!!  I have gone the last 8 days with out that 3-4 puffs from a cigarette and I feel very strong.  I still consider myself a non smoker for 26 days today because going from 1&1/2 pack a day to 1/2 a cigarette is a miracle in itself. The only side effects I have experienced is the nauseau if not taken after eating and felt like I didnt sleep at all at nite because of the dreams.  I now take .5 mg in the morning and .25 mg (1/2 pill) at nite which has helped immensley.  People say this is worse than kicking heroin, I wouldnt know that, but it has definitely been the hardest thing I have done.  I take it 1 DAY at a time and check in at the website every morning and it gets easier and easier!!!  Thank you Chantix!!!!

column2: Jule's, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: hard at first getting on the med but, great after that...

column2: chantix oral, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have written before about this medication.It has been over 6 months of not smoking it has been great!!!!For this whole program to work you have to have a goal in mind because after you reach that goal through the use of this medicine a whole lot of other improvements will happen with your health.If you can tolarate some of the side effects then it will be a benefit to you!!!

column2: dskitty, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I am 44 years old and I am 35 days quit today after 31 years of smoking!!! The Chantix definately takes away the craving to smoke.  I find that if I don't eat and then take the Chantix, I get nauseated - I do have constipation, which is addressed easily with daily fiber intake and I am experiencing vivid dreams. I know that we all have dreams every night, it seems as though the Chantix just helps remember them - some are good, some are weird and only a few bad.  I have gained 9 pounds already but the weight is worth it!  I am also attending a "Group" meeting every other week which also helps as the support from others is very important when it comes to quitting.  It felt great to go into a dr appt yesterday and tell my Dr. that I am a non-smoker (even if it is only 35 days).  I have read some of the reviews about some people's side effects using Chantix and think that the medication has different effects on different people, we are all not the same.  I have multi-level degenerative disc disease and am taking Lortab 500/7.5 and Robaxin 500mg daily for the pain.  I also take 20mg Prozac daily for depression, .25 Xanax for anxiety, along with my Chantix and yes, it may sound like I am a prescription drug addict but my meds allow me to work my 45 hours a week and function as a "normal" person. After reading the reviews though, I am concerned about when I go off the Chantix, will I have adverse reactions?  If anyone out there is on the same regimen as me and has experienced any reactions, please feel free to leave me a message.  I wish all those that are taking on the challenge to quit smoking the best of luck as it is the hardest thing that I have done in my life and everyday I go without a cigarette I thank God for giving me the strength (and Chantix :-)).

column2: Just a mom, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Has anyone else experienced severe coldness with this drug?  I mean bone chilling cold, where you can see the thermostat reads 79 and you are wearing sweats and still freezing so you turn the heat up more?Thankfully this has been my only problem with this drug, I've just started week 2.

column2: Non Smoker, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This is my 2nd time on Chantix, the first time I quit smoking after a month and also quit taking it which was a mistake.  As soon as the med was out of my system the craving came back so I'd definitely recommend taking it for a month or two after you've quit.I've been on it a little over a month so far this time.  The worst side effect for me both times is the nausea I'd get within 5-10 minutes of taking the 1mg dose.  It's a very intense nausea where I literally have to keep myself from vomiting.  It lasts about 10 minutes.  I always take it in the middle of meals or after a meal, NEVER on an empty stomach or I would uncontrollably vomit.  No matter what I take it with I can't avoid the nausea.It's definitely effective in helping you quit.  Ciggarettes taste terrible after a week or two and then you don't even want to smoke them.  I'd forget to smoke after meals etc.  While on Chantix I have very strange and vivid dreams.  Mine have all been humorous however I could see if you were prone to nightmares this could be bad because they also could be very vivid.I'd recommend this treatment to anyone serious about quitting.

column2: 25-34 Female  (Patient)
column9: sick w/flu like simp

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I really think this is an effective way to quit smoking, but I still find myself trying to reason with my brain about why it would be okay, just to have one more cigarette...but of course its never okay. I guess I never realized the damaging effects on your body from one cigarette, let alone smoking for 15 years. I guess I have realized that I am a real drug addict, which is sad, because it seems sooo easy to give in. Which it is. I decided to quit when I was taking care of a patient in the hospital and they where dyeing of Lung Cancer, from smoking, and no matter what treatment we gave him to help him breathe, it didn't help at all. He would cry and ask himself why he did this to himself and his family. Why was the big question for me. I had no answer. The man died in the ICU unit two days later. In nursing school, we where taught that COPD and Lung Cancer are like taking a deep breath, hold it, take another deep breath, hold it, and do it one more time and that is what it is like to breath with these diseases. How terriable! You feel like your sufficating. So, I finally decided that I'm quitting. Enough is Enough!!! And all of the side effects that come with this drug..Well I had some, but I decided to take it anyway. I would rather have nightmares, than lung cancer. Don't give up. If it doesn't work for you, try something else. Its all up to you anyway. Your the one who puts the cigarette in your mouth, so your the one that needs to take it out, permatly! Good luck!!!

column2: julieb, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: i'm on day five and still smoking but not as much.So far the only side effect is a burning sensation in my left  shoulder/neck area.Am hopeful as most of the reviews have been positive.I have been a smoker for 30+ years and i really want to quit.

column2: Mike, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Chantix really will help you quit if you really want to quit.  But it's just like any other quit smoking drug, you have to really want to quit for it to work.I do notice that I get depressed for about the first week of taking Chantix.  After that the depression seems to go away for me.  The vivid/unusual dreams also go away after the first week or two.  The nauseous feeling sticks around, but I've found that if I wait about 30-45 minutes after I eat (protein heavy meal, anything else doesn't cut it) to take my dosage, then it's not that bad.There's no guarantee that you won't start smoking again -- this is my second time to take Chantix to quit (quit for quite a while after the first time), but even with all the nasty side effects, I'm grateful it's available because I hate smoking.I've also noticed that after the initial "starter" pack, that if I just take one a day instead of two, that it does the trick just fine and the side effects aren't as bad.But yeah, getting past that first week or two of feeling depressed can suck.  To me it's a small price to pay for the ease that Chantix makes quitting smoking.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Bad side effects had to stop after 3 weeks.Pain in every joint of my body ,vivid dreams ,depression and severe vomiting.Helped with wanting to smoke,but I also didnt want to eat ,drink coffee or do anything.I'm still in pain daily sometimes I can hardly walk and its been weeks since I stop taking it!!!Try something else it is very bad.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I just started taking about two weeks now.. Have not fully quit but cut down dramacally.. Smokes a pack a day now only 5-6 a day...I am starting to notice feeling very nausous when i do smoke so hopefully i will be down to zero by next week!! I don't have funky dreams but have notice being very moody.. But hopefully that will subside.. wish me luck!

column2: rainbow, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I started with the starter pack 5 days ago.As of right now i haven't seen any changes. No vivid dreams,only noticed i feel a little shaky. Worry a lot, so depression,is what concerns me at this time. Have a friend who is helping monitor my behavior. It's very important that you have someone who knows you well,and will tell you if you are out of character. Been smoking 30 yrs...hope it works for me,won't to quit so badly.

column2: Susannkyym3, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I quit taking the drug four months ago.But the vivid freaky dreams are still occuring. I do not feel refreshed after sleeping 6-10 hours.It is because the dreams are so weird that I really do not rest. Have started talking, crying, and shouting in my sleep.Have written Pfizer asking if they ever go away, still waiting for reply.Was told they will get back to me. My husband experienced severe heart palipatations and was afraid of having a heart attack.Sadly I am smoking again, but if it keeps me calm after some of the bizarre, scary dreams, so be it. I got rid of the drug after just finishing the starter pack four months ago. The dreams are still happening and sometimes I feel like reality and fiction are merging together to the point that I can't remember if I just dreamt something or that it really happened. I take Cymbalta, but do not know if any studies were done to see if the two drugs together can cause this. I will continue to take my Cymbalta forever if only to help me maintain my sanity.
I have just started to take this medication. This is day 2 and already feel the need for a ciggarette dispaiting Been smoking for 39 years so wish me luck

column2: Steve, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Started 6 weeks ago with the RX, but no longer. Stopped smoking 5 weeks ago (great).However, having dreams, constipation, tired, blackouts (memory-have no idea what I have for supper) and now feel I have had a STROKE. The left side of my body is numb and tingly. Drag my left foot. But.. no smoking. "Jumped out of the skillet and into the fire".

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: I took this medication for 2 months and it helped tremendously. It took me 3 weeks to stop the cigarettes, I substituted rolling gum wrappers with my hand to help with the hand habit (I don't like gum much but the wrappers are prefect for rolling). It completely helped and I have been smoke free for about 1 year now. I smoked for 10 years. The only complaint was the severe mood changes for about 3 months after I got off the medication and I too had very vivid dreams but not scarey. My advice be careful with this medication. Have friends and family around to support you and keep you grounded.

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I'm not sure how much credit to give in assisting my smoking cessation, but I have been tobacco-free now for nearly two full years.  The medication caused horrible and terrifying dreams that picked up from the night before until I stopped taking it.  I gave the remaining inventory to a friend who didn't have the same side effects but has also managed to stop smoking for a lengthy period of time.

column2: brady51h, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Smoker 47 years, many years 3 packs a day.Started pills 4/20/07.  Quit smoking 4/27/07. Not a puff since.Took pills with food.  Did have very vivid but not scary dreams. Took pills for 12 weeks.Had myself down to one pack a day prior to quitting by only smoking on back porch. When I quit I stayed away from the back porch.Did not know of other peoples horror stories prior to using.  Had I known then what I know now I would have had second and third thoughts about using product.  But I do know that for me I would never have been able to quit without Chantix or something like it.  I also know if I have one cigarette I'll be back to where I was before quitting.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: it works until you quit taking it.  I now have numb hands and feet and aching joints.  however i am happy to say that i have quit on my own.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This is my 4th day on Chantix and also my quit day.  I have been smoking for over 20 years.  I could feel the medicine working even after the 1st day.  I have had some side effects though including vivid dreams, difficulty sleeping, nausea and now I have a head cold that feels like it is turning into the flu except that I look the flu shot. I don't have any cravings for cigarettes though.  I think I'm going to start to slowly ween myself off over the next week and hope I don't have any cravings.  So far so good except for side effects.

column2: H1234, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: not very effective gave me weird thoughts reality and dreams blurred

column2: Piequeen, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I smoked for over 40 years!  If my family had bet money on my quitting, they would have all bet against me.  I tried gum and patches, more than once.  This worked because you are still smoking when you go through physical withdrawl.  Then, you only have to get over the "hand to mouth" addiction.  I chew plastic straws and eat sugar free candy.  I am smoke free for 2 months and I feel great!  After week 2, I did have odd thoughts, but cut my dosage to half a pill, once a day.  That took care of the problem.  The vivid dreams were not bad at all!

column2: doctor, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: My beautiful 31 year old daughter, Mother of a 7 year old, who was a lab technician in a major hospital started taking chantix in December 30, 2007. On January 13,2008 she committed suicide by hanging. This is not a good drug. She went to the hospital 4 times the week before she died with all the symtoms of the drug and was sent away. The Er in our Town now knows why people are having these strange symtoms. Tradjic. Don't take it. Go cold turkey, or just keep smoking Death is not worth it. I am sure her little lonely boy would tell you that.

column2: iowagirl11, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: stopped smoking in no time and still not smoking 4 month after the meds were gone. did make me a little sick to my stomach but not if i ate crackers and sat completely still for about 10 minutes.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I took Chantix for 13 days; the last week at a half dose. The nausea was terrible but I learned pretty quickly how much I needed to eat with it. 2 pieces of PB toast and a small glass of milk would do it if I wasn't super hungry. I had my last cigarette in the morning of the 4th day and I haven't picked them up since. Not a single drag or "cheat" and today is day 76!! I feel like a new person! Honestly I haven't even thought about taking smoking back up again. This was the best thing I could have done for myself. All my friends and family are now starting to follow my lead, and we had all tried numerous smoking cessation methods before this. Nothing worked before. I am thrilled with this medication.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: depression/suicidal thoughts, agitation, aggressiveness, or other unusual thoughts or behavior...very frightening medication

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: It took about 2 weeks for me to quit,but I did and am very grateful. I smoked for over 10 years. The only thing bad is the Vivid dreams. I have to eat when I take it also.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have smoked for 22 yrs. A pack and a half a day. I started taking chantix. On the 8th day I put down the cigarettes. On the 10th day I thought that I would try and smoke a cigarette. I got sick from the cigarette. I said no more. On day 12 I stopped taking the chantix also. I have been smoke free since January 1st without the desire to smoke.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been smoking since the age of 18. I finally decided to quit and asked my dr. about Chantix. Been on the program for about a month, and am smoke free! I have had severe nausea after taking Chantix, but now I eat something before each dose and am fine. Dreams are vivid, but nothing terrible. I have tried the patch, 'Smoke Away', Wellbutrin, and trying cold turkey. This is the only thing that has worked. I was worried starting the drug due to my depression history, but have had no problems. My only complaint today is that I feel that I am forgetting something when I leave the house in the morning. Only then do I realize that I am 'forgetting' to grab my cigarettes and a lighter! I have truly forgotten what it is to be a smoker.

column2: StephLK, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: For 13 years I smoked AT LEAST a pack a day.  If I was out with friends I could go through a pack within hours.  To say I was addicted would be an understatement.  For me it was more than a nicotine addiction.  It was part of my life.  Chantix didn't make quitting easy.  But, it made it possible and I don't think I could've quit without it.  The first week I noticed that I wasn't getting the fix that I normally would get from smoking.  After that I cut back to 3 cigarettes a day but even that was for a short time because it didn't take long before the taste of cigarettes made me nauseaus.  I didn't have the depression or suicidal thoughts that some people have.  The only negative side effect I had was feeling sick to my stomach if I didn't eat enough before taking it but that was a small price to pay..I'll take an upset stomach here and there for a while over a habit that could potentially kill me.

column2: anixon, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I smoked for 23 or so years, started Chantix right after Christmas. It has helped me tremendously!!  No bad side effects yet, maybe some weird dreams, but nothing bad!  I've had a sore tongue, not sure why that's going on though.... It really curbs your cravings!!

column2: Sue, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I stopped smoking immediately, then I developed the shingles, which was complicated by the Chantix. A year and a half later I am still suffering from Post Herpes Nueralgal. I suffer joint pain, burning under my skin, my nerve endings everywhere in my body feel like tingles, sometimes my lips even tingle. I have started smoking again too. I had one doctor diagnois me with fibromyalga. Im not sure any doctor truly knows what is wrong with me.

column2: Jeff, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Unbeleiveable!  It is as though cigarettes never existed!  I am now in week 2 of the dosage and I have to say it is like a miracle.  I tried the patches, and the Wellbutrin to no avail.  As soon as the patch was gone, I wanted cigarettes, and Wellbutrin worked as intended by making them taste bad, but I wanted them just the same.This on the other hand is just purely God sent.  My first few days of quitting were riddled with tough spots, because I saw myself as more of a habbit smoker, as opposed to nicotene craving, thus situations which normally constituted smoking, and the lack thereof, were troublesome.  But I must say, as my shining moment thus far.  I woke up this morning and made it about an hour and a half without even thinking about a cigarette, and even then it wasn't in a wanting sense, it was just a random thought.  For anyone who needs proof it works, I am it.  I had tried the other methods, but this one works!Did have some leg cramps and general bodyache the first few days though, but I would have taken a brain annurism to feel like I do now, free of those nasty cigarettes forever!You can do it!

column2: otiswally@aol.com, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: My husband took Chantix for 3 1/2 weeks, quit smoking and Chantix the same day and  also became depressed that day, cries easily. Had never been depressed before. How long will the depression last? He is taking 40 mg. Paxil daily and Klonopin as needed.

column2: raytm131, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have tried various methods to quit - this time it was so easy!!  I didn't even want to smoke any more after about the 5th day!!

column2: Sophie, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver)
column9: altered mood and personality.

column2: Beth, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I started taking this medication right after Christmas.  It put me in most down and depressed mood.  I woke up crying one day and could feel the actual depression.  I would rather take my chances at COLD TURKEY than go through this.  I stopped it immediately and within a day felt better.

column2: noneofyourbusiness, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I smoked for 11 years, tried Chantix in May 2008 and quit completely after 8 weeks.  I had vivid dreams.  I also had intense stomach pain after taking a dose, but this only occurred if I did not eat beforehand.  I had a bought of severe depression several years ago, but had no psychological reactions to Chantix.  The medication is expensive if your insurance does not cover it, but it is well worth it--I am presently taking care of a loved-one who has lung cancer.

column2: IAMABENZBOY, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I took this for 6mos, and although I still didn't quit smoking, I cut back tremendously. However, the side effects are miserable (except for the vivid dreams, which I still miss having now!). I experienced severe depression and suicidal ideation, never attributing it to the drug while I was taking it. And this side effect worsened after I stopped taking it. I was a month or more of psychological hell going through withdrawal, and I had never experienced anything like it, and hope to never do so again. I also have kidney problems now, that I can only attribute to this medication. I'd rather keep smoking and risk dying of cancer, than destroy my kidneys by ever taking it again, or end up killing myself. I recommend that if you take this, tell your friends, family and co-workers you are on it, and to ask them to note changes in your mood or behavior that you may not be aware of yourself while on it, or after discontinuing it. I wish I had told people, so perhaps someone could have prevented the hell I went through taking it, as it was so not worth it. While I understand many people have had success, as far as I'm concerned, it was no wonder drug at all, and could have cost me my life much faster than smoking. Never again.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I smoked for almost 20 years heavily, and had tried to quit many times before (once quit for 2.5yrs.) but always craved cigarrettes and was one puff from being hooked again. Chantix has been a miracle. I did have stomach ache with it so we halved my dosage, and I was able to quit within a few weeks completely, and had no adverse side effects. I have been quit a year and a half BUT the difference this time is I could care less about smoking, I can't believe I EVER smoked and I have zero desire to ever smoke again. It has been a wonderful miracle for me. I would like to note I started exercising (not overly, maybe 30 min. 3x a week on elliptical) to offset any depression, I had no depression. Before when I quit I was distraught. I took Chantix for a little under 6 mos. b/c I wanted to make sure I was quit forever. And I am! My counselor suggested Chantix to me. I also take Wellbutrin so that probably helped with no depression as well. Another great drug.

column2: fbcclaire, 25-34 Female  (Patient)
column9: I smoked a 10-15 cigarettes a day and I took Chantix for 1 month and quit.  The first week on Chantix, I was smoking less because I did not have any urges or cravings.  The first couple days that you don't smoke were hard for me, but got easier just as fast.  I found that if I took the Chantix exactly 12 hours apart, I had no problems (the first week you don't smoke).  I recommend this medication to anyone wanting to quit smoking.  It works!  I have been smoke free for 4 months now and I have no problems being around people who smoke (I quit Aug 2008)

column2: angelique, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I had smoked for about 30 years. I took chantix for about 6 months. I was told I could take it up to a year. I quit smoking July, 4. Now I'm crying one minute and the next I'm hollering. The mood swings are terrible.

column2: Carla, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I am on my fourth week of Chantix. I do feel it is helping, but I feel as if I have an ulcer.  Only had one or two wild dreams.  The nausea has pretty much gone away now that my stomach is killing me all the time and I seem to have a headache even when I wake up in the morning.  Maybe it is the lack of the cigarette.  My father quit smoking years ago without drugs and was plagued by canker sores in his mouth for two solid years, so that is probably not the drug either.  I have a large one in my throat and one on the end of my tongue. Hoping all this is due to lack of nicotine and will go away.  Last weekend had the muscle and joint pain severely, thought I had the flu. Gonna try and stick it out.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: If you or any family members have a history of depression, do not take this medication. (My mother and father both suffer from depression.) I have never had a problem with depression myself until I took Chantix. I did quit smoking but when I quit taking the Chantix, I fell into a deep and very scary depression. I started smoking again and am now on Lexapro for depression. I have been on Lexapro for a year now. I was the type of person that said I would not be affected by side effects, but I was wrong. During this I missed two weeks of work and temporarely moved back in with my mom because I never wanted to be alone. I couldn't sleep, couldn't focus on anything, didn't eat, lost 10 pounds. It was really bad. It was a complete waste of money and very terrible experience. If I could go back in time, I would have never taken Chantix. Please be careful and make sure you go back to your doctor right away if you start felling different at all.

column2: Mary, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am 3 mos smoke free after smoking 45 yrs.  I could'nt take Chantix longer than three weeks due to the worsening side effects, but it worked anyway.  now have anxiety to deal with, but that's happened every time I tried to quit smoking.  Alprazalam is helping with that.

column2: galaxylove, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been a chain smoker for 10 years. I tried everything and nothing could help me stop. I have now been completely smoke free for 2 months thanks to Chantix! The 1st couple of weeks were the toughest because I was severly short tempered and would go on a rampage for nothing, but I believe that was because of no cigaretts; It would have happened without the medicine! My family understood and supported my need to shut myself in my room for a while and it passed in about 2 weeks. And the vivid dreams are Great! Like going to cool, weird movies. Ever so often I may have a craving, but I can turn my thought to something else very easily and the craving will be gone! I Highly recommend Chantix if you really want to quit! It sure helped me! I feel much better now. My husband and my kids are very proud of me. As I am proud of myself and the Chantix! I send Thanks and my deepest gratitude for the developers of Chantix for helping me take control back in my life. Thank You!

column2: lindalammer, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I'VE BEEN SMOKE FREE FOR 7 WEEKS I WAS A SMOKER FOR 35 YRS. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND CHANTIX, BUT I BELEVE YOU HAVE TO WANT TOQUIT I HAVE HAD NO SIDE EFFECTS I THINK SOMETIMES PEOPLE THINK THEM SELVES INTO HAVING THESE SIDE EFFECTS, I AM GREATFULLTO CHANTIX FOR HELPING TO QUIT  THANK YOUGOOD LUCK TO ALL LINDA

column2: rod, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: caused me to have seizures.

column2: ZYNE, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Been smoking for 16 years, the last 3 years in excess of 2 packs/day.  Finally decided to try chantix since my prior attempts to quit has failed.  In 12 days I went from 40-45/day to zero.  I have very little, if any real cravings .. The side effects of the drug itself includes vivid and often bizarre dreams, often good for a laugh or two the following day.  The stomach upset is easily addressed by taking the medication with a real meal in the morning and the same in the evening.  Have had no bad effects of Chantix after the initial "almost 2 weeks" and I'm very pleased with the results so far.

column2: camiol, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: I've been on Chantix since mid September.  I love it!  My only complaint is that I had severe nausea after taking the second pill each day so I cut back to just taking the morning pill.  I do have dreams but they're not as vivid since I only take one pill a day.  I go through a bit more withdrawal not taking the recommended dose, but it's tolerable.  I'll just continue taking the pills until the prescription runs out, even if I'm taking them longer than the prescribed time.  Alot of people have commented on being constipated with this pill.  I've quit smoking several times before and constipation is part of it.  To avoid this I have a slimfast shake in the morning with about 4 tbsp of ground flax and 3 tbsp of hemp mixed into it.  Not only does it keep the plumbing working in top form, it's very filling.  I've been smoke free since October 27 and feel great!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: this is the best way. If you can't guit on this then you really dont want to quit

column2: albfine@yahoo.com, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: this drug did work.  However I am now under the care of a psyciatrist because of extreme anxiety and loss of mental function.  The doc wont admit to any connection to Chantix even though Ive never had any problems before.  I am hoping to find others with these problems through other forums since this one is just a review. I was on this drug for six months, and have been off for three and the problems wont go away.

column2: ardscoil92, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I took it for two days and had an allergic reaction to it. My chest and back had an itchy rash on it, as well as my face. My lips dried out. Very uncomfortable experience. What a waste of good money.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Hello to everyone and congradulations on trying to quit smoking... I really did very well with this drug, but the dreams that I had where terriable!!!! I would wake up in the middle of the night and think that I was dieing, or sufficating. It was very scary. The drug is diffenitly not for everyone!! But, it was worth it.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have tried the patch and quitting cold turkey before and this is by far the best way to quit smoking. I due deal with sickness after I have taken it, even if I take it with a full meal. But I have found that eating a light snack helps. I tried taking this medication a year ago but had to get off it. I have anxiety problems and I had recently gotten off Lexapro and found that chantix alone made my anxiety worse. This time I am taking my lexapro with it and it hasn't affected my anxiety. I do have strange and vivid dreams, but nothing scary. I've started talking in my sleep as well. It definitely helps with the cravings. I still get them but I can easily occupy myself until they go away. But these seem like small side effects to deal with when I think of the greater benefits of being a non-smoker!!

column2: snow81, 55-64 on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: I goofed,it was june 16th of 2007 that I had my last cigerette, not 2006 as I wrote in previous text

column2: snow81, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: I took the whole 12 weeks.I could have stopped the drug sooner but thought i'd just go the whole 12 weeks. I had no weird dreams. I really didnt have any side effects I think because I was taking wellbutrin  also.I stopped June 16th of 2006 and havent had a cigerette since then.

column2: on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: My dad strated taking Chantix about 1 month ago and he was doing fine, he stopped smoking but he had all the sideeffects listed. If anyone has had the same symptoms please let me know im very worried.

column2: joy56, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: As long as I was on chantix, I didn't smoke.  Terrible stomach upset after each dose, constipation, headaches constantly, crazy dreams and mood swings.  I have had to stop taking it and have found other ways to stop smoking.

column2: chantix oral, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Started this medication Oct 5th 2008. Haven't smoked for 6 weeks and planning on the full 12 weeks program.  I have had some problems like getting sick after the meds but accually it helps because everytime I see a smoker or smell smoke I get sick, still want one but it offsets it.

column2: Happygirl, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: One year ago, I tried Chantix and had to stop taking it because I was so nauseous in the morning.  Three weeks ago I started it again and found that if I eat 10 minutes before taking the pill, I don't get nauseous at all.  I have been smoke free for two weeks and will never smoke again.

column2: Raechel, 25-34 Female  (Patient)
column9: I started Chantix 3 weeks ago. I put the cigs down that very night after smoking for 14 years. One thing that I have noticed is that when it comes time for the night pill, if I am late taking it, I have an intense craving until it gets into my system. The only real side effect I've had, like many others, is the vivid, but awesome dreams.

column2: Summer, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am on my third week of taking this medication. Eventhough I am only smoking one cigarette a day (sometimes zero), the side effects are killing me. I have had every side effect listed. If there is one thing I can advise anyone thinking about taking this medication is, if you have any history of depression or anxiety PLEASE make sure your doctor knows. I haven't been able to leave my house in over a week.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: In the beginning I really wanted to quit smoking, so I was determined to use the drug, set my date, etc.. After I started taking it, I was under the impression it would make the cravings go away and I wouldn't want a cigarette. What it did, was make me sick. I did have the vivid (but good) dreams and the nausea right after I took it. I had to ween myself off smoking and smoke less and less each day. After I had gone one wk without smoking, I knew I was doing good. Chantix helped a little with actually quitting, but it did not take the cravings away. It was all on me that had to do the work. Chantix really just made me sick when I did smoke a cigarette.. Overall.. I quit myself. Chantix just gave me great dreams and made me really nauseas and moody

column2: John, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: It seems that I have possibly contracted type 2 diabetes following this use of chantix.  Diabetes does not run in my family and blood tests prior to taking chantix were good ... Seems that I may have traded one evil for another.  Has anyone else had this happen and if so, has it gone away or am I truly now a diabetic for life?

column2: Ow, my head!, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I managed to take 3.5 days worth of Chantix before I had to quit taking it.I was willing to tolerate the headaches and restless sleep, but it became apparent on day 4 that I was nose-diving into depression and was much more irritable than usual.    It's worth a try...Chantix may be a 5 star experience for you.

column2: Sue, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Started taking Chantix 9-9-08 wih a quit date of 9-15-08. I stopped taking Chantix 11-01 due to severe headaches. Headaches are still occurrung even after stopping dosage.  I rarely had headaches prior to taking this drug. Hope they go away soon.Sill smoke free though.

column2: sherry, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: this really worked for me, i stopped smoking on the 14th day, still smoke free with no desire to smoke after 20 years. the only problem i have is the nausea is overwhelming. this is the 2nd time ive took this, as the first time i started chantix, i quit taking it after a month because i couldnt handle the sickness of the nausea, and yep, started smoking again. this time i am sticking with it and suffering through the nausea because i know it will be worth it. i am on my 4th week, and am so proud of myself!

column2: beanana, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I could not have quit if it weren't for this drug.  ANY drug you put in your system has side effects.  Common sense would tell you to contact your doctor if you are feeling anything other than acceptable side effects.

column2: Wgusone@msn.com, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: smoked 50 yrs plus and finally got a drugthat really did work and not have any sideeffects.I recommend this to anyone that really want to quit.No urge to smoke or hit anyone while on the pills.

column2: My2Livers, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: To THE SCARED MOM whose son had ASTHMA: I've been trying to decide myself whether or not to try this drug, as I'm an older female on antidepressants and who has had an organ transplant!  I've noticed that young males tend to report better results than anyone else, and males in general seem to do better than females. The question of drug interaction is not really addressed much here, though. Perhaps you should ask a really good neurologist. Good luck to your son. I worry about my son, too, and it's much harder than worrying about your own health. My prayers and best wishes are with you.  Chris.

column2: DEE-DEE, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This stuff was never tested properly Don't take it, PLEASE if I could save one person from the hell i went thru it's worth it it. it is VERRY!!dangerous I became gravely ill from it for a long time until finally it left my system in about 6 months and now I'm dealing with what it's done to me the only way to quit is with a doctors help the old fashioned way cold turkey trust me a miracle pill,lozenge ,patch all BS won't work you will go back to smoking!! I cannot make my point strong enough don't take it its a scam it's better to smoke then to DIE!! very dangerous drug you could have side effects and not know it you are all human guinea pigs on this horrible drug I went thru hell detoxing from it, it delivers soo much dopamine to your brain it's unbelievable meanwhile you are smoking adding more dopamine to your brain! I was sooo very sick I thought I would die take a good look at the warning inside the package you'll be scared and shocked some people have lost their lives  over this drug!!

column2: lavj, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I am beginning week 5 smoke free after being a 30 year smoker. I have had very few side effects from Chantix and it is really helping me to quit. Believe me I have tried EVERYTHING !! I am having a few sleeping issues, but I don't know for sure if it is the Chantix or menopause issues! I would love for anyone that might have had a problem with kanker sores in the mouth after starting this medication would post it on this site. I have been having these for 2-3 weeks now and my doctor can't seem to figure out what is causing them. He does know it is NOT oral cancer. Never had this problem before, so thought it might be a side effect of taking the Chantix, but want to know if anyone else has had this problem. Except for that I am happy to finally find something that helped me to quit.

column2: lori, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Not smoking but can not sleep more than a couple hours at a time and slightly moody/sensitive.

column2: retired, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: only thing I've had is the dreams. guit smoking after 45yrs of trying. on my 3rd month. no problems...........

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: After many years of trying to stop I never thought Chantix would help. I have been smoke free for 12 days and not taking the medicine at all. I only took it for 2 weeks. NO CRAVING, NO WEIGHT GAIN. I did have some side effects like headache,body ache and upset stomach but went away when I ate a pack of crackers and than took my medicine early in the morning than took it around 5. Never had any problems with sleeping. NEVER had bad dreams,moody or sucidal thoughts. I can't I have been wanting to be smoke free for a long time and when my granddaughter was mocking me smoking that was it. You have to want to QUIT to do this. I would recommend it to anyone, by the way 5 other employee's have started this week. Good luck to you all. If I can help with any questions or advice email me at dana.bullard@comcast.net

column2: ihpaex, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This drug is pure evil in my eyes! I reaaly was looking forward to no more smokeing with the help of this med but WOW the side effects just changed me. I became bizzare and felt like crying one moment to wanting to smash everything in sight the next moment to being unexplaining happy. And this is all in addition to the intense headache which remains with me evan after stopping this medication.Avoid takeing this stuff

column2: KP, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was so excited when I asked my Doc to prescribe Chantix!  I made sure that I asked him and my pharmasist about any drug interactions that may occur (as I was taking Cimbalta) I was assured that none had been reported.  Within a week the side effects were so severe that I took myself off of the Chantix immediately.  The depression was so intense that it mimicked a PTSD episode; I was afraid to sleep except during the day, hypervigilant, startle reactions were extreme.  I was close to suicide and would have welcomed death at that point.  These side effects went on for about 6 weeks and I feel that they were due to damage to the brain receptors that occured while taking it.  If I hadn't been so familiar with my depression (as most people are not) I may have commited suicide.I contacted Pfizer and talked to a nurse who was a Quality Department employee to report what had happened.  They gave me a full refund for the RX that I had purchased with no argument at all.We all have to be aware of what our bodies/minds are doing, the doctors don't always know everything and they can learn from us.  I'm lucky because I have a doc that actually LISTENS to me.Please do your research before you begin taking meds that effect your brain function and that may have drug interactions.  We are responsible for our own health.Good luck to you all that are trying to quit smoking!

column2: HH1, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: I did have some of the side effects from it but it worked for me. I had been smokeing for 50 years,ln 4 months I had stop. thank you for this treatment,and I thank God also.                                   HH1.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)

Not to mention on the new medical expenses.

column2: painter1111, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)

column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: The only side effects I got from this drug were wierd dreams (extremely vivid but not scary) and nausea if I did not take CHANTIX with food. Pass the news on to family and friends about this perscription.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Was a 30-year, pack-a-day smoker. Today is Day 92 of quitting.  No problems quitting, altho think I would like one now and again (but that's not an option for me, because I'm totally committed to quitting).  You have to still want to quit, Chantix can't do it all.  First month went great, but noticed increased agitation in months 2 and 3, and a bit of depression.  I'm usually upbeat and laid back!  Also had nausea regardless of eating beforehand for all three months.  Dreams were cool!  I'm not sure if I'd recommend it or not, but so far, it IS the only thing that has worked for me.  Good luck, everybody!

column2: Helpmequit, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have been taking Chantix for over a year now. I do not feel as though I need to smoke but I do still want to smoke. I still buy a pack a week. The side effects are killing me. I cannot take the full dose every day due to the nightmares and insomnia. I don't want to take this medicine anymore.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I'm on Day 3 of treatment, the urge to smoke has disappeared.  I'm still smoking (plan to stop on Day 8 as instructed), but every cigarette I have is one I want, not need. column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: 10x Better than bupropion/Wellbutrin!!! I've been taking Chantix for about 4 weeks now. BE CAREFUL and read everything you find on chantix.  Chantix is worst then smoking.  OH MY GOD, i hope my thoughts are not like this forever.  Good Luck

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)

column2: Waffle, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)

column2: Lisa , 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I quit after the first week. I;m in the middle of the second week. So far So great !

column2: lowpsi, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Chantix blocks your body's ability to absorb nicotine, causing you to go through withdrawl - even if you continue smoking! Amazing to experience. I continued Chantix and smoking until the last dose, then quit. I had my doc prescribe welbutrin for the emotional withdrawl. I've been smoke-free for 2.5 months after having smoked for 39 years and don't miss it.

column2: sekan97, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had smoked a pack a day for 20 years. I started Chantix on 7/19/08 with a quit date of 7/26/08. I am smoke free for 8 full weeks and I feel wonderful. My husband loves the way I smell now. As soon as I quit, the smell of cigarette smoke made me physically ill. Now I can tolerate it. It certainly isn't tempting. My #1 complaint is that if I miss a dose of Chantix, I find that I become quite irritable and have little to no patience at all when normally I have tons of patience. Another mildly annoying side effect was the nausea if I didn't eat enough food or drink enough water with the dose. Simply solved though by drinking plenty of water & eating enough food. Yes, I have gained 16 pounds but I find that is due to the fact that I am now eating more when I am bored. Whereas I used to smoke whenI was bored instead of eating.  My doctor suggested 6 months of treatment but I am going to start weaning myself off. I have a feeling I have already become dependent upon the meds to stabilize my moods. BUT.... as others have said before me, in the grand scheme of things, I would do it again in a heartbeat. I feel 100% better being smoke free.... I suggest Chantix to every smoker I know that is thinking of quitting. Thank you Chantix!!!

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: 8 weeks into taking Chantix I developed severe muscle and joint pain in my leggs, feet and neck.  Difficult and painful to walk.  I got off from the drug and will now go cold turkey.  I just hope the pain goes away.  I have read some reviews where 8 weeks have passed and the pain remains.

column2: scared mom, 45-54 Female  (Caregiver)
column9: I have a son 19 years old that has been prescribed Chantix.  He as ADD and takes Concerta.  He also had asthma as a baby but no problems since.  Do I help him stop smoking or do I risk harming my baby boy? Can anyone advise?

column2: cancer vs psychosis, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Took Chantix briefly to stop smoking. It caused severe nausea and vomiting. In addition, around the time I took this medicine, I had what I could only describe a psychotic episode, unlike anything I had ever experienced. My behavior became uncharacteristic of my personality. I was so utterly depressed that I missed a week of work and even sliced my forearm repeatedly with a razorblade one night while my family was sleeping, and then went back to bed, streamed blood drying on my arm. Never before and never since have I felt or behaved like this.  This drug is scary for me personally.  I would rather die early from smoking than feel this type of mental anguish again.

column2: unchained1955, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Iused this drug and have been smoke free for 21 months now. It worked, but now my doc has me on generic Paxil for a mood disorder.  I am sure my condition is related to taking the Chantix.  I noticed within the first 2 months of taking it that I was having wild episodes of mania.  I thought that I was just so elated to be quitting smoking.  I realize now that this drug had some kind of effect on my brain.  I wish the "powers that be" would really study this and find out how many people are affected this way.  Anybody else?

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I did 3 complete 12 week cycles of Chantix and I haven't smoked for 18 months now.  My stomach felt quizzy most of the time and I lost 30 lbs too.  I did all this while going through a divorce!!  Yeah to me!!!!  If I can do it....you can!!!

column2: Todd, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Committing myself to this program, added to some significant desire to stop smoking, I'm 14month cigarrette free and don't even mind when others light up.  I just have no desire to ever smoke again.  It works.

column2: ChrisGracey, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I took Chantix back in March of 2007 and quit smoking 03/28/07 I took the pills for the 3 months.  I am still smoke free even though I would love to have one now and then but OMG the depression.  I thought I was before taking chantix but now I think it is about 3 times as bad.  Does anyone have this problem also?

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
