column9: do not take this medication I am here to tell you that I am suffering do not take it...please go cold turkey so mamy brain problems now

column2: J, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Easy to want to stop smoking on this drug and few side effects.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: The dreams that it does cause. In my case are mild and funny. wierd but funny.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I wonder if any ladies are experiencing light periods? Thats the only side effect I've noticed. I've quit off and on many times since I started smoking at age 16. Chantix is most effective, I work with a smoker, and I didn't want one even though he smoked in front of me! (jerk) I'm almost done with my 2nd week and am smoke free x 7 days!

column2: stevenatrojak, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
niijii0111, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: while being treated for severe back/hips/joint pain, i was telling the nurse in triage that this was the best drug I have used for the purpose of stop smoking. 15 minutes later the Dr. took me off the drug three days before completing the starter pk. a week has gone by and it appears i still decide when and if i smoke. the back/hip pain is almost unbearable. so now i am taking a muscle relaxer,hydrocodone and noproxine. since the Dr. visit i have developed a rash on my chest and back. since being off the drug, i have using nicorette gum and that does get me through a day. will be taking MRI to see if there is really something there,inflamed disk or deterioration of them. honestly, if i knew of that i would suffer like this, i may have just kept on sleeping on my pack of cigarettes as it is not as painful!!!!!

column2: LABRADAD, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: It's been 1 year since I finished my final pill and I'm still smoke free! I smoked three packs per day for 25yrs. I tried everything from acupuncture to zyban. Forty-three differant methods to quit. I had nausau and head ache and some wild dreams on Chantix, But Today is 8-8-08 its my independence day from nicotine 1 YEAR!

column2: artva, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been on this medicine since the last week of april 2008.My husband had a heart attack so we both wanted and needed to quit smoking.Before we started the medicine we were smoking 2 to 3 packs daily,and now after a little over 3 months of the medicine i still smoke,but only 6 cigaretts a day,but my husband has only went down to 1/2 to 3/4 a pack daily.We both have been wanting to quit smoking,even before his heart attack.Now we are slowly taking our selves of the medicine because for me i have been depressed,hopeless,sad,and wanting to kill myself,I had instant weight gain upon taking the medicine but i have less of an appetite,i always feel bloated,occationaly sick  or upset stomach.My husband has experienced anxiety problems,short tempered or moody,upset stomach all the time having trouble sleeping.We both wanted so much to quit smoking all together,but we both can not handle any more of the problems we are haveing since we started taking the medicine.We are looking in on some other way to help us quit smoking.but it is sad that after3 months we still smoke,after reading how alot of people have quit with in 2 to 4 weeks.This medicine may be good for some people,and we are happy for them but we are not happy with the medicine.

column2: punkie, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I didnt have any side efects yet.i am on 2 blue one twice aday.dont want a cigerett it was the easiestthing i did. tried it before but with patch .Dont do that.Everyone that wants to quit should take chantex.smoked for 39 years.t

I know it's kind of dumb for me to post on my expierence already because it's only my 3rd day but after 1-2 packs a day, I really don't even want a cigarette. Unfortuneatly, I am having some problems with depression...hoping that is normal and will go away shortly but so far I am pretty impressed with this drug!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year
column9: Chantix worked very well for me but I still have difficulty with the habit. The addiction is gone but I feel like I lost a part of my personna.

column2: Jen Lov, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: It worked for me in as little as two weeks.  I was a pack a day smoker. First of all you have to really want it.  Then commit yourself to quitting.  The med made me a bit sick to my stomach the first week- then headache and constipated.  I stopped taking the end of the second week. I am now into the 4th week and have no urges to smoke.  You also have to change some social practices.  Mine was in the morning i drank coffee and smoked-  So i also gave up coffee.  I hate smoking and i really hope to never pick up this gross habit again.  I hate having something that dominates me or controls me like smoking did.  I wish everyone lots of luck.  And the benefits far out weigh the risks in my opinion.... just get on it, quit, and get off ASAP.  Dont drag it out.  God Bless

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: As a smoker for more than 10 years, I was also a quitter numerous times. None being as succcessful as I was using Chantix. I am the type of person with a ton of allergies, and a weak stomach-I will react to anything, yet I experienced hardly any of the side effects, have not once had withdrawal symptoms, and am completely and thoroughly turned off by smoking. It disgusts me that I even did it for so long, that is how well this drug works. I finished one and one half weeks of treatment and was done. I still have two full dose packs left! I am very very amazed by this drug, and would recommend it to anyone who is seriously wanting to quit.

column2: Jwest, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Chantix does what it says.  It helps you quit smoking.  When I decided to quit, I consulted my DR.  He recommended Chantix.  You start off with the "Week 1" pack, which is 0.5mg of the drug once a day for 4 days. (I took it in the morning, but make sure you take it with food.) Then, you take 0.5mg twice a day for the next 3 days.  On day 7, you are supposed to acutally quit smoking.  I smoked 1 cigarette that day, and it was my last.  Then for the next 3 weeks, I took 1mg twice a day.  I experienced little to no side effects, except for the extremly random and vivid dreams. (One person explained them like this, "I love going to sleep now. It's like going to the movies!")  Chantix was so effective, that for a full month after I quit, I drove around in my car with a full pack of cigs and never smoked ONE!  It even was not uncomfortable to go to the bar, or be around smokers.  If you are really serious about quitting, then I urge you to talk to your doctor about Chantix.  Good luck quitting!P.S. Chantix comes with a mediocre support program. Having said that, I really think it was worth the read.  (http://www.getquit.com)

column2: Linny, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: If all you care about is quitting then this is IT. This drug more effectively and more thouroughly breaks ones dependence on nicotine.  The problem is that in altering the brain chemicals it could also possibly break ones relationship with all other items in life. I threw up the morning dose if I did not eat A LOT! I've gained about 30 lbs, woke up crying several times from dreams, am VERY angry, and I have very little will to live, but the good news is after 2 weeks without the drug I'm still not smoking (even when I want to).  I AM STILL NOT SMOKING and if I can stay out of the pen and out of the morgue, I MIGHT even have a life again at some point...MAYBE... But I'm NOT smoking and after all, that's what is important, right?

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Headaches, irritability, anger.....of course. Ever try and quit before? It's called withdrawl!! The drug works great people. You just have to get through the chemical withdrawl. Because of the drug you're body doesn't get any effects from the nicotine it's been getting for 20 plus years. It's normal and goes away after a few days. Chantix works much better than any other treatment I've tried. The dreams are vivid but if you have a good dream it just makes it better. If you have nightmares go to a psychiatrist, don't blame the drug. You were messed up before you started taking it.

column2: azjln, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: 38 years a smoker and many times a quitter, the longest during my pregnancies and nursing my children, and even hypnosis didn't work as Chantix has for me.  My big problem with the drug is constipation which is hitting me big at the end of my 10th week.  I've neither had nor wanted a smoke although the scent outside the grocery store is inviting.  My husband quit after the hypnosis that didn't work for me over 2 years ago and it's wonderful to enjoy the shared kisses now.  I consulted my doctor and received physical tests prior to being prescribed this drug.  There have been no mood swings, no behavior problems, nothing like that, but I've had restlessness and vivid, odd dreams that have had no effect on me after waking.  Consult your doctor and be honest with him or her before you decide on this option to stop smoking.  I'm happy I did.

column2: JimK, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I took Chantix from July 31, 2007 through August 28, 2007.  On or about my third week I started to experience facial numbness.  Early in September the right side of my face became completely numb; was tested for a stroke it came back negative.  I also started to experience a burning sensation in my hands and feet; muscle aches in my hamstrings; and periods of total weekness particularly on my right side.  I was visted the ER four times in 2 months.  Prior to taking Chantix I had not visited the ER since 2001 and that was got a head injury to my son.  I was subsequently diagnosed with diabetes and sub-clinical hyperthyroidism.I remained smoke free for approximately 3 months but with the ensuing problems I encountered I continually recommend anyone from taking Chantix.I was also extremely angry at the FDA for allowing Pfizer to include a patient information sheet that lacked full disclosure of the side effects associated with Chantix, even the updated patient information sheet is inadequate.  Although the patient sheet informs the user about the possibility of suicidal ideation, the warning sheet mitigates this particular side effect by claiming it may be linked to nicotine withdrawal.  I did experience panic attacks and as I said other physical problems, none of which are listed on the Patient Warning Information.  My overall opinion for this drug is that it is overrated.  Also it was poorly tested prior to its introduction to the market place.  The drug from which Chantix is a derivative, cytisine, has been around much longer, over 50 years(Europe Only) and I don't think there have been as many problems associated with cytisine as there has been with Chantix.

column2: Beth, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This drug almost killed me by hypokalemia. I hate Pfizer the FDA and the doctors for allowing a drug they call medicine which is really a poison. I quit cold turkey and it was much better. The harm this drug caused is still effecting me and there is no cure. DO NOT take this drug but do quit smoking.

column2: Msprof, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have not had a cigarette in over 9 months, but, I wish I still smoked.  I have been through hell with Chantix.  I got very depressed, aggressive, etc.  I stopped taking it in December, and then absolutely fell apart by the end of January.  I still have problems with depression, concentration, mood, temper, etc.So, if anyone wants to do the "you're just mad you didn't quit smoking" thing, I can counter that argument.  I DID quit smoking, but at an incredibly high price.  Quite frankly, right now the main thing that keeps me from smoking again is because I NEVER EVER EVER want to have to take a medication that makes me that depressed and hopeless.  This medication DEFINITELY works for some people, with no side effects.  And I realize that people who are anti-smoking think the benefits outweigh the "risks."  But, the real problem is no one KNOWS the risks, yet, because they didn't study them long-term.  There is still information we don't know.Meanwhile, I have a very "intellectual" job.  I can do it from a wheelchair if I have to, but I absolutely have to have a sharp mind, and I haven't had one in almost a year.  I do not recommend this drug for people who need their brains to earn a living.

column2: CVTJen, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I smoked for over 20 years and I feel great the medication works very well.

column2: Deceived, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I took Champix for 3 months (started february 1st to end of april), while i was on Champix i had the common symptoms: nausea, lost of memory, headaches, weird dreams and sleeping problems and some joint and muscle pain.After I stopped Champix the joint and muscle pain got worse and did not leaved me yet 8 weeks after I stopped the use of this drug.  I still can hardly walk in the morning as my legs and feet hurt so much and during the day i have much pain in upper back, elbows and shoulders,  tingling and numbness in my arms and hands.  In the few days after i stopped Chantix I also experienced muscle spams from my thorax, every 30 seconds, and pain at the eyes.The ratio of people experiencing joint and muscles pain is 1/100.  Pfizer did not tell it in its documentation when i started to take Chantix.  If I knew the risk i was taken, i would not have used this medication for sure.  Now more than 40 000 of people are suffering from those joint and muscle pain.

column2: phxeyes1, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: I acquired something NO ONE warned me about. Perfectly healthy UNTIL I took this poison. Now I have diabetes, just one of the horrible side effects they don't tell you. I also experienced problems with remembering things, depression, thoughts of suicide for no reason, aggression & easily aggitated, some of which I still suffer from. Chantix has a history of over 3000 reported serious injuries to the FDA. Check out whyquit.com & search Chantix. I WOULD ADVISE NO ONE TAKE THIS DRUG UNTIL FURTHER RESEARCH IS DONE.

column2: exsmoker, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)

I had vivid dreams initially, not any more. The side effects are worth being smoke free. Chantix is awesome!!

column2: Eyeore, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
